A few reports from the ground from between 31 March to 10 April seemed to suggest that this is the case with not many people understanding how the virus spreads. In fact, there have been criticisms of the government's "denial and approach" and "failure to communicate fact-based information on how severe, contagious, and challenging this virus is." Listing it as a 1 for these reasons.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200508171359/https://www.hrw.org/news/2020/03/31/burundi-any-covid-19-cover-will-put-lives-risk  https://web.archive.org/web/20200508170523/https://www.france24.com/en/20200410-burundi-shrugs-off-pandemic-citing-god-s-protection  https://web.archive.org/web/20200508170510/https://allafrica.com/stories/202004030423.html
notes_H3: No policy change
notes_H2: First two people test positive for COVID-19 in Burundi:         http://web.archive.org/web/20200416094548/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/burundi-confirms-first-2-covid-19-cases/1787083     NB Both individuals had returned from abroad, but it is unclear whether this was a necessary criterion to be tested.
notes_C8: According to the website Travelbans.com, Burundi’s international airport and land borders have reopened from 1 August.    If you’re eligible for entry, quarantine requirements are subject to the following conditions: If you arrive into Burundi with proof of a negative COVID-19 test from the last 72 hours. After registering with the Ministry of Public Health and a United Nations clinic doctor, you will be allowed to travel to your place of residence without entering into mandatory quarantine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200817172121/https://travelbans.org/africa/burundi/
notes_C4: No policy found
notes_C1: No policy update, School open but with COVID measures including social distancing   /web/20210118181250/https://www.unicef.org/burundi/stories/back-school-burundi-2020
notes_H6: The health minister issued stronger guidelines, saying that people visiting patients at hospitals must “be supplied with masks and health personnel be equipped with protective masks.” He also said that taxi drivers should clean seats and that passengers should wear masks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201029213235/https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/burundi-starts-taking-covid-19-begins-screening-71635099
notes_E2: /web/20201207222905/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  The authorities continue to monitor the impact of the COVID-19 shock on loan performance as part of their efforts to protect financial stability. In particular, they are working with banks to encourage, on a targeted and time-bound basis, an extension of loan maturities to borrowers in hard-hit sectors, applying existing regulation in a flexible manner. They have also asked commercial banks to reduce bank fees for electronic transfers, and mobile money transfers in order to reduce the need to go to banks.
notes_E1: As a result of the pandemic, Burundi’s economic growth projection for 2020 was revised down by 5.3 percentage points to -3.2 percent in 2020. The pandemic has exacerbated pre-existing economic challenges and created significant external financing needs in 2020 and 2021, mainly as a result of lower exports, elevated imports needs, and reduced remittances inflows. The European Union [provided] financing [to] the country’s health sector to combat the pandemic [in 2020].

name: Belgium
notes_H1: Belgian government launches Coronavirus information homepage, starts daily messaging on twitter and Facebook; https://web.archive.org/web/20200430193034/https://twitter.com/SanteBelgique/status/1223259642928590848
notes_H3: Note that contact tracing is handled by the regions.    H3 is set to 2 as of 18 May 2020 because:  -As of 11 May 2020 contact tracing has been fully operational in Flanders.  -As of 18 May 2020 contact tracing is operational in Wallonia:  "405 call center agents and 21 call center supervisors as well as 135 field agents and 8 field supervisors were recruited."  (http://web.archive.org/web/20200806150003/https://www.wallonie.be/fr/tracing)    However the press regularly comments about that the capacity is insufficient.  From a press article in "The Bulletin" of 20 May 2020:  "Since their work officially began on 11 May, Belgium's contact tracers have managed to get in touch by telephone with about 60% of people who have recently tested positive for coronavirus."   (see http://web.archive.org/web/20200530160643/https://www.thebulletin.be/coronavirus-how-does-belgiums-contact-tracing-operation-work)
notes_H2: Belgian Government decided on April 29 2020 to extend testing    http://web.archive.org/web/20200530155506/https://huis.vub.ac.be/corona/kennisbank.php?ID=174 reports: "In the context of the exit strategy, the intention is to test the population more extensively for covid-19. From May 4, in principle, all people who have complaints that possibly indicate a COVID-19 infection can be tested. However, it is always the doctor who determines whether or not a patient is tested. Given that the test capacity will be further expanded during the week of 4 May, GPs must take into account the capacity that is available locally."
notes_C7: The measures taken in certain coastal towns ended on 12 August 2020.  (http://web.archive.org/web/20200813063839/https://www.tijd.be/politiek-economie/belgie/algemeen/dagjestoeristen-vanaf-woensdag-weer-welkom-in-knokke-heist/10244578.html)    Moving to "0" as the recommendation made by the governor of the province of Antwerp on 28 July 2020 has not been repeated since and are not documented on an official government web-site.
notes_C8: The federal immigration office informs on travel restrictions:  "The travel restrictions apply to all non-essential travel to Belgium. Only travel for essential purposes can take place.  The travel restrictions do not apply to:  Nationals of EU Member States and Schengen Member States, for the purposes of returning to their homes;  Third-country nationals who are in possession a residence card (or D-visa) delivered by a Schengen Member State, for the purpose of returning to their homes;"  (see http://web.archive.org/web/20200530141916/https://dofi.ibz.be/sites/dvzoe/EN/Pages/Travel-to-Belgium.aspx)    In addition, there are two additional restrictions for people who do enter Belgium under the above conditions: "The person places himself in home isolation for 14 days; and  The person has a ban on working outdoors during those 14 days (even if he / she is employed in an essential sector), but teleworking is still allowed.  These two conditions always apply to the returnee and apply to all possible transport modes (air, land and sea) used on his / her return."    (see http://web.archive.org/web/20200530142717/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/nl/faq/)
notes_C4: At the federal level the social bubble has been restricted to 5 people, fixed for the next 4 weeks: "A family may allow five more people into its social bubble for the next four weeks, not including children. And above all: that bubble should remain the same for the next four weeks."  (http://web.archive.org/web/20200729105618/https://www.standaard.be/cnt/dmf20200729_91848859)    C4=4G is chosen as a family of e.g. 2 people can only meet with 5 other fixed people implying a restriction on gatherings of fewer than 10 people.    Gatherings of up to a maximum 10 people are possible in case social distancing / face masks are used.
notes_C1: •	Classes for all levels of education will be suspended on 12 and 13 November. Classes will resume on Monday 16 November.  •	For secondary education, pupils in the second and third grades will switch to a maximum of 50% contact education until 1 December. We will evaluate whether going back to 100% contact education is possible again before 1 December.  •	For higher education, remote teaching is provided:  o	For first-year students: until 1 December, when they will be able to follow contact education again.  o	For senior citizens, at least until the end of the calendar year.  •	Teachers can only meet online; the same goes for teacher training courses.  •	No in-person teambuilding activities are allowed    https://archive.vn/V0qYS#selection-571.0-631.48
notes_H6: "Since Thursday 1 October 2020, wearing a face mask is mandatory in Brussels when it is not possible to respect the safety distance.    Next measures apply in the Brussels Capital Region:    obligation to always have a face mask with you  wearing a mask is compulsory in all cases when it is impossible for its holder to respect the safety distances"  https://web.archive.org/web/20201010014418/https://www.brussels.be/face-mask-brussels
notes_C2: •	Non-essential stores are open again, under strict hygiene conditions  •	Hairdressers, restaurants and bars remain closed    https://archive.vn/sek2R    https://archive.vn/4pm3D
notes_E2: •	The self-employed can also benefit from support regarding their social security contributions in the form of a reduction, delay or exemption of payment. If you are obliged to interrupt or stop your activity because of the crisis you can apply for a replacement income.  •	Walloon:  Taxpayers will benefit from a suspension of the tax payment deadlines during the crisis. Deadlines for claims against assessment will be frozen.    https://archive.vn/8a0RE
notes_E1: •	Full-time employees are entitled to 70% of the (possibly capped) salary, regardless of the family situation.  •	The self-employed can also benefit from support regarding their social security contributions in the form of a reduction, delay or exemption of payment. If you are obliged to interrupt or stop your activity because of the crisis you can apply for a replacement income.  •	Walloon:  Taxpayers will benefit from a suspension of the tax payment deadlines during the crisis. Deadlines for claims against assessment will be frozen.    https://archive.vn/8a0RE
notes_C3: •	Funerals: up to 15 attendees, but no reception allowed after funeral  •	Places of worship open, but no services allowed. Attendance restricted to maximum 4 people.  •	Wedding parties not allowed, only the couple to be married and the witnesses may attend the ceremony.  https://archive.vn/EW4CZ    •	cultural venues closed until at least 13 December  https://archive.vn/bGOwD    Cannot find any information that attendance rules at professional sports events have changed nationally, only that sports venues have closed in Wallonia.  https://archive.vn/bGOwD#selection-1497.2-1497.50
notes_C6: COVID-19 alert level 4 goes into effect nationally    Prohibition to enter public spaces between 24.00 and 5.00am, except for essential, non-procrastinating movements, such as urgent medical reasons, professional movements and commuting.  https://archive.vn/22FVR#selection-531.0-531.183
notes_H7: Which groups: A,C  Which vaccines: Pfizer and Moderna    Along with vaccinations of Residents and employees of residential care centres and collective care institutions vaccinations of healthcare staff in hospitals started as well.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210119133139/https://www.brusselstimes.com/news/belgium-all-news/150273/belgiums-covid-19-vaccination-state-of-play-dirk-ramaekers-pfizer-moderna-centres-hospital-staff/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210123161403/https://www.vaccination-info.be/maladie/covid-19/    The first elderly people to receive the Pfizer jab are getting their second dose today. The first Moderna vaccines are being administered at hospitals in Ixelles, Eupen, La Louvière and Antwerp. And the mass vaccination of Belgium's healthcare personnel also began on Monday.  https://archive.vn/JC7p4#selection-1741.0-1741.348

name: Benin
notes_H1: Government posters on best practice regarding hygiene. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20200511035054/https://www.gouv.bj/actualite/529/coronavirus-point-des-mesures-prises-par-le-gouvernement/
notes_H3: For example, following the first case in Togo (who had travelled through Benin), a SitRep was initiated i.e a report situation which allows us to trace the whole circuit and identify all the contacts. So, we already had the telephone contacts of the parents in Benin and we are in the process of locating them all because we have to trace them all and trace all the contacts they may have had also in order to proceed to quarantine and monitoring for 14 days to make sure they are not also developing the disease. This is done and all the rapid intervention teams that we have at the Atlantic and Littoral level have already been deployed and are hard at work to fully finalise the identification of all these contact cases. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20200511041051/https://www.gouv.bj/actualite/541/coronavirus-point-de-la-situation-au-benin/
notes_H2: Testing those groups who are exposed or symptomatic. https://web.archive.org/web/20201214184337/https://www.gouv.bj/coronavirus/
notes_C7: Per US Embassy, there are no restrictions on internal movement within the country of Benin. https://web.archive.org/web/20201108165803/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/
notes_C8: International airport is open, although screening is required. Most land borders remain closed. https://web.archive.org/web/20201108165803/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/
notes_C4: Cordon is lifted, but nationwide ban of gatherings of more than fifty (50) people remains in place; https://web.archive.org/web/20200605173350/https://sgg.gouv.bj/cm/2020-05-06/ https://web.archive.org/web/20200605183802/https://www.france24.com/en/20200517-benin-votes-in-controversial-elections-despite-covid-19-threat (For corroboration)
notes_C1: Per the embassy site everything appears to be generally open with a government enforced mask rule.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117215551/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/
notes_H6: Face coverings are required outside the home at all times. Fines imposed for non-compliance. https://web.archive.org/web/20201108165803/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/
notes_C2: Per the embassy site everything appears to be generally open with a government enforced mask rule.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117215551/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/
notes_E2: to cover 3 months of electricity bills for hotels and travel agencies up to 4.1 billion FCFA (~70m USD)  and a subsidy for all citizens on electricity and water tariffs (~97m USD)
notes_E1: It seems that the income support specifically covers formal sector employees. See: On June 10, the authorities announced a FCFA 74 billion (US$ 124 million) stimulus package to support formal enterprises, craftsmen and small service trades in the informal sector, in addition to the most vulnerable segments of the population. Measures included in the package are expected to cover 70% of the gross salary of all formal sector employees over the period of three months. https://web.archive.org/web/20200706192006/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Recent information describes church services as being permitted to occur. No information on other types of public gatherings were identified.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201221133938/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221134024/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/benin/coronavirus
notes_C5: Public transport to resume on 2 June  http://archive.vn/dUNjY

name: Burkina Faso
notes_H1: Video on official government website providing advice to public.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200511105917/https://www.sante.gov.bf/detail?tx_news_pi1%5Baction%5D=detail&tx_news_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=News&tx_news_pi1%5Bnews%5D=165&cHash=553848326e0511204c14d95bf6870bb8
notes_H3: In the response plan, it is stated that 100% of alerts were investigated. https://www.humanitarianresponse.info/sites/www.humanitarianresponse.info/files/documents/files/plan_de_riposte_covid19-revise_def.pdf
notes_H2: COVID-19 testing is free in Burkina Faso. All centres performing COVID-19 diagnostic are contracted by the government. See: https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ (web archive unavailable, accessed 21st September 2020)
notes_C7: There is currently no curfew in place in Burkina Faso. There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel. See: https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ (web archive unavailable, accessed 21st September 2020, website last updated 14 September 2020)
notes_C8: Updating dur to the fact that land borders are closed. So passengers at airports must present test results and if they don't have them, they are taking a rapid test. All land borders remain closed. So it is not a total ban on travel. https://web.archive.org/web/20210117203422/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: Per the US Embassy site there are no restrictions site is sited to have been updated on November 27th.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201213211405/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: No change
notes_H6: Per the US Embassy in Burkina Faso as of November 27th - Face masks are required.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213211405/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: Bars, Maquis, theatres, restaurants, gaming, cafés are allowed to reopen with the application of social distancing measures and sanitary precautions including wearing face masks, using single use dishes and providing soap and water for handwashing https://web.archive.org/web/20200517203948/https://www.sig.gov.bf/actualites/details?tx_news_pi1%5Baction%5D=detail&tx_news_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=News&tx_news_pi1%5Bnews%5D=414&cHash=dadef64399ce076c2f18a9ea7bbe917e
notes_C6: Burkina Faso has lifted stay at home orders, according to a travel advisory issued on the 6th of August 2020 (this seems like a national measure, so coded as 0). See: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/traveladvisories/burkina-faso-travel-advisory.html (accessed 21st September 2020, web archive unavailable, travel advisory issued August 6 2020)
notes_C5: Measures have been set up to limit infection on public transport,  This Tuesday, May 5, 2020 marks the resumption of passenger-passenger transport activities throughout the territory. At the Gare de l'Est where we were on this first day of resumption of activities, the crowds are not so much there.  The Executive Board of the High Council of Transporters of Burkina Faso (HCT-BF) informs the Burkinabè population that, due to the quarantine measure still in force, the resumption of passenger-passenger transport activities, initially scheduled for Monday, May 4 is postponed to Tuesday, May 5 throughout the territory.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200503184151/https://www.sig.gov.bf/details?tx_news_pi1%5Baction%5D=detail&tx_news_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=News&tx_news_pi1%5Bnews%5D=379&cHash=763a0815f061dfeac65be6af7a1bd80c  https://web.archive.org/web/20200511104331/https://www.burkina24.com/2020/05/05/reprise-des-activites-de-transport-a-ouagadougou-constat-a-la-gare-de-lest/  https://web.archive.org/web/20200511104428/https://www.burkina24.com/2020/05/04/covid-19-au-burkina-faso-reprise-des-activites-de-transport-de-passagers-voyageurs-annoncee-pour-le-5-mai/

name: Bangladesh
notes_H1: While the originally linked press release (https://www.iedcr.gov.bd/index.php/component/content/article/11-others/227-pressrelease) is no longer available, this photo from GettyImages shows Bangladeshi students wearing facemasks on January 29, indicating that a public health campaign was in place. https://web.archive.org/web/20200604225455/https://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/news-photo/bangladeshi-students-wear-masks-for-protection-against-news-photo/1197376807#/web/20200604225455mp_/https://www.gettyimages.co.uk/  There is also this leaflet from unicef that seems to be from early February; https://web.archive.org/web/20200604225319/https://www.unicef.org/bangladesh/media/3506/file/Coronavirus_leaflet_Bangla.pdf (linked in an article dated February 8: https://web.archive.org/web/20200604225903/https://www.unicef.org/bangladesh/en/stories/coronavirus-disease-covid). Hence 2G is maintained as coding.
notes_H3: Bangladesh FETP fellows and graduates are working in all of the processes associated with meeting these objectives, including: responding to health hotline calls from airline passengers 24/7 and collecting clinical and epidemiological data from the callers, identifying suspected cases and sending rapid response teams for sample collection, preparing and managing the day-to-day activities of quarantine camps for Bangladeshi citizens returning from Wuhan, developing guidelines and standard operating procedures (SOPs), and preparing daily press releases. Bangladesh FETP fellows are ready to conduct case investigations and contact tracing if the need arises. Since this is a secondary source, coded as more cautious 1. https://web.archive.org/web/20200604230344/https://www.tephinet.org/fetp-activities-in-response-to-coronavirus-disease-19-covid-19
notes_H2: https://web.archive.org/web/20200430181602/https://www.thedailystar.net/frontpage/news/avoid-public-transport-1877749
notes_C7: Restriction of movent in Red zones (Uttar Kattali) where lockdown was enforced. Movement remains free in the rest of the country. Source: http://archive.fo/WfkIM
notes_C8: http://caab.portal.gov.bd/site/notices/e9172346-d6db-425c-854d-75007c5529fa/Suspension-of-Schedule-International-Flights-To-From-bd
notes_C4: Public gatherings prohibited in red zones.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200626224334/https://unb.com.bd/category/Bangladesh/covid-19-govt-issues-directives-for-red-zone/53146  https://tbsnews.net/coronavirus-chronicle/covid-19-bangladesh/govt-finalises-red-zones-curb-covid-19-93121
notes_C1: https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/searo/bangladesh/covid-19-who-bangladesh-situation-reports/who-ban-covid-19-sitrep-04.pdf?sfvrsn=69b6d931_8
notes_H6: Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201007094615/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  Since May 30, the Government of Bangladesh has made wearing masks and social distancing mandatory when outside the home
notes_C2: In red zones under lockdown e.g. Wari:  - The residents are not allowed to move around except for essential work  - "Also due to this lockdown, I won't get paid this month for not being able to go to my workplace. But it's not just me, I personally know quite a few people who are facing this sort of economic hardship,"     Source: http://archive.fo/5fpjF#selection-773.0-773.214
notes_E2: 4 April – Waiver on Credit Card: The banks are instructed not to deduct any fees/charges/interest against late payment of credit card bill from 15 March 2020 to 31 May 2020. In addition to the already formulated regulations on March 19, this raises to the level of a broad contract relief, hence upgraded to 2. https://web.archive.org/web/20200604203924/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/bangladesh-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html
notes_E1: Since there is no evidence for any ongoing support other than the one time cash payment announced on April 14, downgraded to 0 after one month
notes_C3: Targeted: According to the US Embassy Website in Bangladesh as of Nov 11, 2020 https://web.archive.org/web/20201111005505/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/:   "Currently, only certain sectors located within the Wari jurisdiction of the Dhaka South City Corporation are designated as ‘lockdown/containment’ zones. In these areas, the City Corporations will facilitate emergency response services.    It is important to note GoB officials have confirmed that the list of Red zones does not mean the areas are or will be under lockdown restrictions.    Restrictions on Designated Lockdown/Containment Areas:  - Pedestrian and vehicular movements controlled through secured entry/exit points.  - Residents should remain within their homes except for emergencies or for essential needs.  - No indoor dining services allowed. Delivery food service options are available.  - Grocery stores and pharmacies will remain open.  - Residents will be allowed to shop in bazaars only when necessary.  - Residents must work from home.  - Transportation will be suspended. Rickshaws, vans, taxis, auto-rickshaws, and private vehicles are not permitted inside the demarcated areas during the 21-day lockdown.  - COVID-19 tests will be available to residents, and home isolation or institutional isolation will be arranged for patients who test positive.  - Shopping malls, gyms, sports complexes and recreation centres will be closed.  - No public gatherings of any kind are allowed.  - Only people who are ill may go to hospitals.  - Mosques and other places of worship are closed to residents. Only official staff are permitted to enter.  - ATM services will remain open. Banks will operate in a limited capacity.  - Factories in towns will remain closed, but factories and agricultural production-related factories in rural areas can remain operational.  - Agricultural work must be performed under strict health and hygiene regulations."    This information has not changed as of Nov 18, 2020: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122221519/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/      IN GENERAL: COVID19-related restrictions seem be removed, although with strict adherence to mask wearing.  Dhaka Tribune: "On October 31, the Cabinet Division sent notices to all public offices of the country, asking them to restrict entry and to refuse service to anyone without a mask. The notice further said masks have been made compulsory for all offices, courts, shopping malls, bazaars, state or government buildings and **social events**."  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122215536/https://www.dhakatribune.com/health/coronavirus/2020/11/02/no-restriction-on-public-movement-to-curb-second-wave-of-covid-19    Nov 12, reuters.com: "“The decision has been taken considering the second wave... We can’t play with the lives of our children,” said a senior official of the education ministry, who declined to be named. **The government however, has lifted most other restrictions**"  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122212335if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-bangladesh-educati/bangladesh-extends-school-shutdown-over-second-covid-19-wave-idUSKBN27S26A
notes_C6: Stay at home required for red zones.     Outside the red zones, all the government, semi-government, autonomous and non-government offices would remain open in their respective arrangements on a limited scale while no one would be allowed to go out at night from 8:00pm to 6:00am without an emergency during the extended restriction period effective from today.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200626223155/https://www.newagebd.net/article/108471/general-holiday-for-red-zones-announced
notes_C5: Targeted: According to the US Embassy Website in Bangladesh as of Nov 11, 2020 https://web.archive.org/web/20201111005505/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/:   "Currently, only certain sectors located within the Wari jurisdiction of the Dhaka South City Corporation are designated as ‘lockdown/containment’ zones. In these areas, the City Corporations will facilitate emergency response services.    It is important to note GoB officials have confirmed that the list of Red zones does not mean the areas are or will be under lockdown restrictions.    Restrictions on Designated Lockdown/Containment Areas:  - **Transportation will be suspended. Rickshaws, vans, taxis, auto-rickshaws, and private vehicles are not permitted inside the demarcated areas during the 21-day lockdown.**  - No public gatherings of any kind are allowed.  - Pedestrian and vehicular movements controlled through secured entry/exit points.  - Residents should remain within their homes except for emergencies or for essential needs.  - No indoor dining services allowed. Delivery food service options are available.  - Grocery stores and pharmacies will remain open.  - Residents will be allowed to shop in bazaars only when necessary.  - Residents must work from home.  - COVID-19 tests will be available to residents, and home isolation or institutional isolation will be arranged for patients who test positive.  - Shopping malls, gyms, sports complexes and recreation centres will be closed.  - Only people who are ill may go to hospitals.  - Mosques and other places of worship are closed to residents. Only official staff are permitted to enter.  - ATM services will remain open. Banks will operate in a limited capacity.  - Factories in towns will remain closed, but factories and agricultural production-related factories in rural areas can remain operational.  - Agricultural work must be performed under strict health and hygiene regulations."    This information has not changed as of Nov 18, 2020: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122221519/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/      IN GENERAL: COVID19-related restrictions seem be removed, although with strict adherence to mask wearing.  Dhaka Tribune: "On October 31, the Cabinet Division sent notices to all public offices of the country, asking them to restrict entry and to refuse service to anyone without a mask. The notice further said masks have been made compulsory for all offices, courts, shopping malls, bazaars, state or government buildings and **social events**."  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122215536/https://www.dhakatribune.com/health/coronavirus/2020/11/02/no-restriction-on-public-movement-to-curb-second-wave-of-covid-19    Nov 12, reuters.com: "“The decision has been taken considering the second wave... We can’t play with the lives of our children,” said a senior official of the education ministry, who declined to be named. **The government however, has lifted most other restrictions**"  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122212335if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-bangladesh-educati/bangladesh-extends-school-shutdown-over-second-covid-19-wave-idUSKBN27S26A
notes_H7: 1 A  AstraZeneca  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118012609/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-vaccine-bangladesh/bangladesh-to-begin-covid-19-vaccinations-next-month-idUSL4N2JM2YX

name: Bulgaria
notes_H1: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs recommends that the Bulgarians refrain from attending public events, avoid crowded places, and comply with safety measures such as wearing a protective medical mask, maintaining personal hygiene, and avoiding direct contact with strangers. Since the PM also addressed the public on the same day and because of the previous presence of a hotline, I rate this as 2G for being the starting point of the public information campaign stage; https://web.archive.org/web/20200503234833/https://www.bnt.bg/en/a/foreign-ministry-with-recommendations-on-italy-and-china-travel-over-coronavirus
notes_H3: Bulgaria seeks passengers from Amsterdam flight after 3 test positive for Covid-19  web/20200604222325/https://sofiaglobe.com/2020/04/29/bulgaria-seeks-passengers-from-amsterdam-flight-after-3-test-positive-for-covid-19/
notes_H2: Currently, no specified policy even though testing is taking place. 30th March: Bulgaria has ordered 600,000 PCR tests and 400,000 rapid tests for mass testing.
notes_C7: The restrictions on intercity travel in Bulgaria end at midnight, Health Minister Kiril Ananiev said on May 5.    source: https://sofiaglobe.com/2020/05/05/covid-19-in-bulgaria-may-5-intercity-travel-restrictions-scrapped-as-of-wednesday/
notes_C8: "A temporary ban has been introduced for the entry into the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria of all persons, regardless of their citizenship, through all border crossings, by air, sea, rail and road transport. The ban does not apply toThe United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, or a Schengen country (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and members of their families. They are definedand other exceptions, which you can find in the order of the Minister of Health. Exceptions are also allowed for certain transits.  (Order-RD-01-405 of 15.07.2020)  All persons who are excluded from the ban on entry into the country described above and who come from the Kingdom of Sweden and the Portuguese Republic, as well as from all third countries, with the exception of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Iceland, Kingdom of Norway, Switzerland, Principality of Liechtenstein, Republic of San Marino, Principality of Andorra, Principality of Monaco and Vatican City State, People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, Australian Union, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Kingdom of Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Republic of Rwanda, Republic of Thailand, the Republic of Tunisia, the Oriental Republic of Uruguay and Ukraine are admitted to the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria upon submission of a document showing a negative result from a survey conducted up to 72 hours before entering the country.by the polymerase chain reaction method for the detection of COVID-19. Persons who do not provide a document showing a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction test carried out up to 72 hours before entry into the country for the detection of COVID-19 shall be quarantined for a period of 14 days at home or elsewhere, in which the person has indicated that he will reside, with a prescription issued by the director of the respective regional health inspection or an official authorized by him. (Order-RD-01-405 of 15.07.2020)"    http://web.archive.org/web/20200720085354/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki
notes_C4: On 22 December, order RD-01-718 went into effect.    It is not allowed to organize and hold gatherings and celebrations of a private nature (weddings, baptisms, funerals, etc.) with the presence of more than 15 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki
notes_C1: Schools closure based on UNESCO; no mentioning about universities; source: /web/20201221112932/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H6: "Wearing a face covering outside is mandatory when it is not possible to maintain a social distance of at least 1.5 metres. Exceptions to this measure include:    customers at dining and drinking establishments;  participants in conferences, when speaking;  those exercising outdoors/indoors; and,  children under six years old."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201028144611/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bulgaria/coronavirus
notes_C2: On 22 December, order RD-01-718 went into effect. Order RD-01-675 also remains in effect.    Employers and recruitment bodies are to organize the work process of employees in remote form (teleworking / home work), where possible, allowing the presence of a maximum of 50% of staff.    The work process of the collective management bodies and the employees should be carried out, if possible, in remote form (home work / remote work) or to establish working hours with variable limits or work in shifts. Employers to approve a schedule for the use of regulated holidays, where applicable, as well as to apply other preventive measures and methods of work, depending on the specifics of the respective work activity, which will provide a better level of protection of workers.    Visits to shopping centers (representing one or more buildings in which shops, restaurants and other commercial sites are located) are suspended, except for grocery stores, hospitals, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet stores, banks, insurers, payment service providers, offices of telecommunications operators and other providers of communications and utility services and dry cleaning services therein. Visits to gambling halls and casinos are also suspended.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki
notes_E2: As of 22 December, the loan repayment moratorium remains in effect.    Borrowers are able to negotiate with lenders until 31 March 2021 to delay payments of both interest and the principal for nine months. Those who have already had six months of loan repayment holidays can negotiate three additional months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102210418/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/972
notes_E1: On 23 December, the 60/40 measure in support of business and workers was extended until September 2021    "Eligible applicants for the measure are employers from the sectors of passenger and urban transport, passenger land transport, hotels, restaurants. Self-employed persons with activity in the same sectors, as well as freelancers and sole traders are also entitled to assistance in this line," said the Minister of Labor and Social Policy Denitsa Sacheva.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102205533/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1039    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102205415/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1069
notes_C3: According to the Order RD-01-677/25.11.2020, the holding of congress-conference events, seminars, all collective and individual sports events, all cultural and entertainment events (cinemas, museums, galleries, stage events, concerts, dance classes) are suspended. Also, visits to gambling halls, casinos, and shopping centers, trips of tourists are suspended.   Link: https://archive.fo/wip/5NRBG
notes_C6: All open-air activities permitted, with indoor activities in malls, cafes, etc. allowed on 1 June 2020. Source: https://coronavirus.bg/bg/391
notes_H7: A:    On 27 December, the immunization campaign against COVID-19 in Bulgaria began.    The Minister of Health was the first Bulgarian to be vaccinated against coronavirus infection.     163 medical staff from 12 hospitals in Sofia also received the vaccine. Another 440 medics will be immunized in the coming days.    Apart from Sofia, the immunization campaign against COVID-19 in the country started simultaneously in Plovdiv and Burgas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103050522/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1058

name: Bahrain
notes_H1: A multilingual national campaign to combat the novel Covel Cornonavirus (COVID-19)  has been launched in the Kingdom of Bahrain to enhance public awareness and beef up prevention measures.    Health Minister Faeqa bint Saed Al-Saleh announced the plan in lined with the directives of His Royal Highness Prince Salman bin Hamad Al-Khalifa, Crown Prince, Deputy Supreme Commander and First Deputy Premier.    The wide-ranging campaign would be channeled through the social media, the press, Radio Bahrain and TV, the health centres, labour camps and in cooperation with the Labour and Social Development Minister and the Labour Market Regulatory Authority (LMRA). https://web.archive.org/web/20200607213428/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/3805
notes_H3: Bahrain records first case and starts extensive contact tracing as per press release. Bahrain later issues database of all positive cases and lists the contact tracing undertaken, usually up to the point "all known contacts traced"; https://web.archive.org/web/20200607220703/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/3753; https://web.archive.org/web/20200607220901/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/ContactsTracing
notes_H2: Dr. Al Manea emphasized that the Ministry of Health has recently begun random medical tests, via mobile testing units, across the Kingdom. Dr. Al Manea further extended gratitude to all the authorities collaborating with the Ministry of Health to contain the spread of COVID-19, and in particular the Ministry of Interior, represented by the General Directorate of Civil Defence, who have disinfected various areas and provided awareness campaigns across the Kingdom. Since this presupposes general availability, upgraded to 3; https://web.archive.org/web/20200607234542/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/4068
notes_C7: “Is a curfew in place? No. Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200903121009/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: On September 4, the Government of Bahrain resumed visas upon arrival for eligible nationalities, including U.S. citizens.   All arriving passengers will be tested for COVID-19 at their own expense. These tests cost 30 Bahraini Dinars ($80), and passengers may be required to take two tests, which would double the cost to the passenger.  Passengers under six years old are exempted from testing on arrival.     Beginning August 20, passengers who test negative for COVID-19 will no longer be required to quarantine for 10 days.  Passengers remaining in Bahrain for 10 days or longer will be required to test again on the tenth day in country.   All incoming passengers at the Bahrain International Airport or at seaports arriving from countries with COVID-19 cases will be given a health questionnaire and screened.  All travelers must comply with the requirements of the Government of Bahrain.   Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? No    But all arriving passengers will be tested for COVID-19 at their own expense. These tests cost 30 Bahraini Dinars ($80), and passengers may be required to take two tests, which would double the cost to the passenger.  Passengers under six years old are exempted from testing on arrival.   Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes    All arriving passengers will be tested for COVID-19.   All incoming passengers at the Bahrain International Airport or at seaports arriving from countries with COVID-19 cases will be given a health questionnaire and screened. All travelers must comply with the requirements of the Government of Bahrain. https://web.archive.org/web/20201105173340/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: Any gathering with more than 5 people banned; https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.moh.gov.bh/Content/Upload/File/637205444806738000-COVID19---Press-Conference-(22-Mar-2020)-EN-copy.pdf
notes_C1: Schools and unis are reopened, although they are required to comply with social distancing restrictions (e.g. reducing class size), and are strongly encouraged to develop hybrid formats of teaching  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104170524/http://www.tradearabia.com/news/EDU_167236.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104170627/https://www.moe.gov.bh/pdf/advert/back-to-school.pdf
notes_H6: “Starting at 7 p.m. on April 9, per the Government of Bahrain’s official efforts to combat the spread of COVID-19, it is mandatory for all individuals to wear a face mask in all public venues.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200903121009/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ “Larger quantities of masks will be made available at pharmacies and supermarkets by 9th April, by the time of opening of other commercial establishments.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200903134915/https://www.gulf-insider.com/bahrain-face-masks-must-be-worn-by-all-in-public/
notes_C2: Some businesses reopen, but: ·  Movie theatres are to remain closed  ·  All commercial sports gymnasiums, fitness studios, swimming pools and recreational activities are to remain closed   ·  The activities of all restaurants, tourist facilities and places for serving food and beverages are to remain limited to external orders and delivery services  ·  Shisha Cafes are to remain closed. Services offered by these cafes are to remain limited to takeout and delivery of food and beverages only  ·  Salons are to remain closed  ·  All non-essential medical services provided by private health clinics are to remain suspended.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607234941/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/4101
notes_E2: No change per Ministry of Finance and National Economy Website & Central Bank website after Sep 20 note.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200919083650/https://www.mofne.gov.bh/  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.cbb.gov.bh/
notes_E1: Under the leadership of HM the King and under the direction of HRH the Crown Prince, the ministers announced an eight-point economic package that commits the government to: 1. Referring a draft law concerning paying the salaries of all private sector employees for three months from April 2020 from the unemployment fund, following constitutional procedures and in line with the Social Insurance Law.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607231055/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/3969
notes_C3: All public (and private) events with more than 20 people banned; https://web.archive.org/web/20200607225910/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/3967
notes_C6: no change per Ministry of Health website.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/News
notes_C5: It is now mandatory to wear face masks in public, including on all public transport and while travelling in taxis, with fines of 5 Bahraini Dinars for failure to do so. But no reports of public transport operating at significantly reduced volume/route/means of transport available. Source: http://archive.fo/gUlDg
notes_H7: There are now multiple sources of evidence that the Bahrain government is fulfilling its promise for free universal vaccine  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104174047/https://healthalert.gov.bh/en/category/vaccine  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104174353/https://www.arabianbusiness.com/healthcare/456328-bahrain-says-to-launch-free-coronavirus-vaccine-jabs-on-friday  https://web.archive.org/web/20201230213424/https://healthpolicy-watch.news/while-europe-celebrates-israel-bahrain-vaccinate/

name: Bahamas
notes_H1: The government’s ‘Covid Bahamas’ website, dedicated to publishing up to date Covid-19 information, was first updated on the 27th February. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201116173746/https://covid19.gov.bs/bahamas-covid-dashboard-27-february-2020/
notes_H3: On the 18th March, there was a “Communication on COVID-19” “by Dr. the Hon Duane E. L. Sands, M.P., Minister of Health.” “Mr. Speaker, the National Reference Laboratory confirmed a positive result in the late hours of 14th March, 2020.” “Many health professionals and other Bahamians are working very hard, often long hours, to limit the spread of COVID-19. The Ministry’s Surveillance Unit has aggressively undertaken contact tracing activities for this case.” “This first case triggered the operationalization of our Health Disaster Plan, and the full activation of the Health Emergency Operation Centre (EOC)”, which includes testing “suspected cases and close contacts of confirmed cases”. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123180533/https://www.ub.edu.bs/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Communication-to-Parliament-COVID-19-in-The-Bahamas.pdf
notes_H2: The Ministry of Health COVID-19 Frequently Asked Questions and Answers document published on the 4th March declared testing capacity: “If cases of COVID-19 are confirmed in The Bahamas, is the country prepared? Yes. The Ministry of Health has developed and distributed the Novel Coronavirus Preparedness and Response Plan to healthcare facilities and stakeholders. Meetings to discuss the plan with multiple agencies are ongoing. Personal Protective Equipment and laboratory testing is available, quarantine/isolation sites are continually being identified. The Ministry of Health will keep the public updated.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201110124205/https://www.bahamas.gov.bs/wps/wcm/connect/6c416b87-180f-48ef-b034-a8dad4097822/FAQ+COVID-19+Revised+04.03+%281%29.pdf?MOD=AJPERES
notes_C7: “21. Domestic travel.  Effective 7:00 pm on Tuesday the 28th day of July, 2020 no person there shall travel inter island except -  (a) in respect of an emergency  (b) for the transport of essential goods or services; or  (c) (i) prior to travelling undergoes a RTPCR COVID 19 molecular diagnostic test and obtains a negative result; and   (ii) upon arrival on the other island, submits to mandatory quarantine at a government identified facility or any other appropriate facility as determined by the Ministry of Health, for a period of fourteen days.”   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201116104145/https://opm.gov.bs/emergency-powers-covid19-pandemicno-3order2020-pdf/
notes_C8: “Beginning November 1, everyone entering The Bahamas will no longer need to Vacation-in-Place”. However, “Everyone travelling to The Bahamas must obtain a negative COVID-19 RT-PCR (swab) test taken no more than 5 days prior to the date of arrival.” Also, there are “temperature screenings for passengers” upon arrival to The Bahamas. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201115235743/https://www.bahamas.com/tourism-reopening
notes_C4: “Emergency Powers (Covid 19 Pandemic) (Lockdown) Order, 2020”, made on August 4th, applies to all Islands of The Bahamas. It “shall expire at 5:00 am on Wednesday the 19th day of August, 2020” on all islands, except for the island of Grand Bahama because “this order shall cease to apply to Grand Bahama at 5:00 am on Friday the 7th day of August, 2020”.  “No person, except an essential worker for a business or establishment specified in paragraph (2), shall leave his place of residence for any purpose whatsoever, other than for —  (a) the purpose of seeking urgent medical care at a hospital specified in paragraph (2); or  (b) travel to secure groceries, gas, pharmaceuticals, water or to any businesses or undertakings permitted to open in order 5; or  (c) any activity permitted by this Order.”  Permitted activities don’t include private gatherings. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102195629/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Emergency-Powers-Covid-19-Pandemic-Lockdown-Order-2020.pdf  Also, from the 10th of August the “Order shall cease to apply to islands of Inagua, Mayaguana, Crooked Island, Acklins, Long Cay, Long Island, Chub Cay, Rum Cay, and Ragged Island”. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102200158/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/EMERGENCY..ORDER_..NO_.3.pdf
notes_C1: On August 31st, it was announced “Monday, October 5, 2020 is the targeted date for the opening of public and private schools throughout the archipelago. The Hon. Jeffrey Lloyd, Minister of Education (MOE) in a report to the nation, announced that a substantial increase in the infection rate of the novel coronavirus in New Providence and other Family Islands, has forced the Department of Education to engage in more urgent planning and considerations. Schools were previously scheduled to open on September 21, 2020.”  The Minister of Education, “emphasized that in New Providence, Abaco and Eleuthera, schools will have a virtual format while schools in Grand Bahama and other Family Islands will offer face-to-face classes.” Source: https://archive.vn/9i0u2 It was confirmed again, on October 7th, in an address by the Prime Minister Dr Hubert Minnis, that “schools on New Providence and Abaco, may only proceed via virtual means. For now, there will be no in-person schooling for students.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201115191745/https://opm.gov.bs/house-of-assembly-communication-7-october-2020/
notes_H6: “Emergency Powers (Covid 19 Pandemic) (No.2) Order, 2020.” made by the Prime Minister on the 22nd July states:  “(4) A person is not required to wear a face mask while —  (a) exercising but is required to have a face mask visibly in his possession and easily accessible;  (b) on a beach but must wear a face mask when approaching and after exiting the beach.”   These are new exceptions to the face mask wearing requirements which were already in place:  “(1) Every person who leaves his residence shall, while away from his residence wear a face mask, which fits securely to his face, covering his nose and mouth.  (2) Any person who is found not wearing a face mask in accordance with this order commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of two hundred dollars or to a term of one month imprisonment or to both such fine and imprisonment or to both such fine and imprisonment”  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201116124705/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/EmergencyPowersCovid19PandemicNo.2-Order-2020-Final.pdf
notes_C2: “Emergency Powers (Covid 19 Pandemic)(No. 6) Order, 2020” was made on September 10th.  Non-essential workplaces are now permitted to open on Second Schedule islands except   “(a) a casino, bar, discotheque, cinema, museum, library, historical society and other cultural or entertainment facility;  (b) a regatta, festival, fair, play, performance art and other cultural or entertainment event;  (c) the occasional sale of prepared meals commonly known as a cook out, steak out or souse out;  (d) a spa;  (e) a gym; and  (f) a craft or straw market vendor, and a jet ski operator.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102203048/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Emergency-Powers-Covid-19-Pandemic-No.-6-Order-2020.pdf
notes_E2: No debt and contract relief measures found that remain in place at this time.
notes_E1: No income support evidence was found over this time period.
notes_C3: “Emergency Powers (Covid 19 Pandemic) (Lockdown) Order, 2020”, made on August 4th, applies to all Islands of The Bahamas. It “shall expire at 5:00 am on Wednesday the 19th day of August, 2020” on all islands, except for the island of Grand Bahama because “this order shall cease to apply to Grand Bahama at 5:00 am on Friday the 7th day of August, 2020”. This includes the required closure of all non-essential workplaces. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102195629/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Emergency-Powers-Covid-19-Pandemic-Lockdown-Order-2020.pdf  Also, from the 10th of August the “Order shall cease to apply to islands of Inagua, Mayaguana, Crooked Island, Acklins, Long Cay, Long Island, Chub Cay, Rum Cay, and Ragged Island”. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102200158/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/EMERGENCY..ORDER_..NO_.3.pdf
notes_C6: On the August 9th, EYEWITNESS NEWS, reported that  “Prime Minister Dr Hubert Minnis today announced lockdown and curfew measures will be lifted for eight islands tomorrow [August 10th].  Normal commercial activity, including church services, beaches and parks will resume on those islands at 5am on Monday.  These include: Mayaguana, Inagua, Crooked Island, Acklins, Long Cay, Long Island, Rum Cay, and Ragged Island.  “The lockdown and curfew has been lifted for these islands because health officials have not recorded any specific COVID-19 activity on these locations for at least two weeks,” he said.” Source: https://archive.vn/vUnt2
notes_C5: “Emergency Powers (Covid 19 Pandemic)(No. 6) Order, 2020.”  “Part V - Miscellaneous”  “This part shall apply to the islands specified in First Schedule and the Second Schedule.  50. Public transportation.  A —  (a) taxi service; or  (b) private and public bus service may operate, provided that such service shall be operated at fifty percent occupancy,   subject to guidelines issued by the Ministry of Tourism and approved by the Ministry of Health.”   The First and Second Schedules can be found on page 29 and page 30.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102203048/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Emergency-Powers-Covid-19-Pandemic-No.-6-Order-2020.pdf

name: Bosnia and Herzegovina
notes_H1: Ministry of Health has a public information site, with the first report published on January 31st. https://web.archive.org/web/20200416231119/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/
notes_H2: 'Three Chinese citizens were admitted to the Sarajevo University Medical Centre and are being tested for the coronavirus, the head of the Centre, Sebija Izetbegovic, said at a press conference on Tuesday [25th February]'.       http://web.archive.org/web/20200416103146/https://balkaneu.com/several-suspicious-but-not-confirmed-cases-of-coronavirus-in-bih/
notes_C7: “Movement Restrictions: Is a curfew in place? No. Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200829101240/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: US Citizens and British Nationals, including those with residence in Bosnia and Herzegovina, need a negative COVID-19 (PCR) test result that is not older than 48 hours. Some groups are exempt from this rule, including: diplomats accredited to and resident in Bosnia and Herzegovina, EUFOR/NATO staff, freight drivers and crew, and foreigners in transit to their country of residence. Changes to restrictions may be introduced at short notice. You should comply with any screening measures put in place by the authorities. You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200921174139/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bosnia-and-herzegovina/entry-requirements  https://web.archive.org/web/20200829101240/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/save/https://blog.wego.com/covid19-travel-restrictions-by-destination-country/
notes_C4: The order is obligatory to wear protective masks indoors with respect to a distance of at least 1 meter, as well as in open space, if it is not possible to maintain a physical distance of 2 meters between people in the open. Due to the aggravated epidemic situation of COVID-19, the new order "allows the gathering of people in a certain area under the following conditions: no more than 50 people indoors and no more than 100 people in the open."  http://web.archive.org/web/20200730123944/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/209/krizni-stab-stozer-fmz-okupljanja-ogranicena-na-50-ljudi-u-zatvorenom-i-100-na-otvorenom-prostoru-rad-ugostiteljskih-objekata-ne-duze-od-23-sata      It is unclear if there is a policy change in Republika Srpska, the other entity comprising BiH.
notes_C1: Cannot find a specific policy of school closure in any entities of the country  The new school year 2020/2021 in BiH started with combined teaching programmes (classroom teaching and online classes). Teaching is conducted in smaller groups of pupils, with shorter  classes and respect of strict sanitary rules (wearing masks is obligatory for teaching staff, and  recommended for pupils.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201024193117/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Bosnia-and-Herzegovina.pdf
notes_H6: As of March 29, 2020, the Federation began requiring all persons on the street or in public areas to cover their mouth and nose with a mask or scarf; in the RS, all persons must also wear gloves in public.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201002061401/https://www.osac.gov/Country/BosniaHerzegovina/Content/Detail/Report/735ec25f-20ef-4ff9-bb52-1858fa23ff5b
notes_C2: Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina:  Night clubs and discos will remain closed until further notice. Restaurants are allowed to remain open until 11 p.m. All services must take additional hygiene measures and continuously disinfect them. From 5.11.2020, all legal persons, i.e. companies, in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina are obliged to set flexible working hours in the work processes they perform and, where possible, to introduce teleworking.     Republika Srpska  All legal entities, i.e. companies, and public administration are invited to organise the work as a teleworking wherever possible. Opening hours for catering establishments are from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m., with live music prohibited. A minimum of 10 m2 of space must be available for each table with a maximum of 4 people. The opening hours of gambling operators (casinos, vending machines and similar ones) must be reduced to 10 p.m. The so-called "drugstores" (small grocery stores), which are usually open 24H, are only allowed to sell counters after 10 p.m. All shops and businesses must take additional hygiene measures and continuously disinfect them.    Brko District  From 7.12.2020, opening hours of catering establishments, fitness centres, gambling operators, sports schools are limited to 7 p.m.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html
notes_E2: "The Republika Srpska (RS) announced the health fund will cover health care costs for all patients and has postponed payments for business tax from end-March to end-June, while speeding up tax and SSC refunds"     Policies appear to have ended in June; no new policies found     https://web.archive.org/web/20200713171131/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: No current policy found for July    https://web.archive.org/web/20200713171131/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina:   Public gatherings of more than 30 people outdoors and indoors are prohibited. Parliament's sittings are excluded from this. Exceptionally, no more than 70 people may be present in theatres and cinemas. Organizers are obliged to register all planned events with the cantonal Ministry of Health. Competition activities for sports clubs and athletes may only take place without an audience.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html    Republika Srpska:   All public gatherings with more than 50 people are prohibited.  All private gatherings (weddings, baptisms and birthday parties, family meetings, etc.) with more than 10 people are prohibited.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html    Brcko District: On 3 November, public gatherings in closed spaces were banned.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102174538/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/bosniaandherzegovina/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.2+Physical+distancing&Type=Section    (22 Nov) religious gatherings (funerals, holidays) as well as weddings limited to 30 persons.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200829154713/http://www.ohr.int/report-on-measures-and-orders-adopted-during-the-pandemic-of-covid-19-in-bih/
notes_C6: Since 11/11/2020, an exit lock is in place from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina,   Since 22/11/2020, an exit lock is in place in the Brcko district from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m.  No specific stay-at-home policy in Republika Srpska and Canton of Sarajevo.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html
notes_C5: According to OECD, in the FBiH the public transportation became operational again, meaning that public transport is now running across the whole country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200528100802/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Bosnia-and-Herzegovina.pdf

name: Belarus
notes_H1: The Ministry of Health is launching a campaign "New Year - Home Holiday" aimed at holding safe New Year holidays.  The purpose of the pre-holiday campaign is to convince the public of the need to comply with safety measures during the COVID-19 pandemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228095550/https://www.belta.by/society/view/minzdrav-zapuskaet-aktsiju-novyj-god-domashnij-prazdnik-421644-2020/
notes_H3: 1st and 2nd level contacts being traced.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200517231426/https://news.tut.by/society/679921.html
notes_H2: more than 65,000 COVID-19 tests are currently available
notes_C8: "President Alexander Lukashenko reportedly ordered the partial closure of Belarus' borders with Poland, Latvia, and Lithuania on (and from) Thursday, October 29, [...]. The extent of the new restrictions was not clear from Lukashenko's announcement, in which he claimed they had been introduced to reduce the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). However, Polish and Lithuanian authorities stated that foreign nationals had been barred from entering Belarus via their border crossings since 16:00 (local time), with only Belarusian nationals and freight traffic being permitted to cross the border. Lithuanian guards later reported that vehicles had also been prevented from crossing the border from the Belarus side. [...]    To better facilitate arrival, foreign nationals are encouraged to carry proof of a negative result for COVID-19 issued no more than 48 hours prior to departure using a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201105140140/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/394851/belarus-government-introduces-restrictions-at-borders-with-poland-latvia-and-lithuania-october-29-update-64    "From October 29, 2020, all persons arriving in Belarus must self-isolate for 10 days upon arrival. This policy does not apply to persons arriving from the following countries / regions: Austria, Albania, China, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Latvia, Monaco, Montenegro, Norway, Serbia, and Spain"    https://web.archive.org/web/20201105140647/https://www.trip.com/travel-restrictions-covid-19/
notes_C1: "On Monday (20th), [the president] allowed the country’s schools to reopen after an extended spring break."  However, "[...] authorities allowed parents to keep their children at home even though the government has steered clear of closures and restrictions on public movement amid the country’s expanding coronavirus outbreak. [...]. As voluntary actions do not fall under the new C1 regulation, I've decided to keep the level on a general 0.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200517225810/https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/politics/2020/04/21/the-latest-the-coronavirus-cancels-oktoberfest-in-germany/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201105125231/https://apnews.com/article/3e53f7e4d840375c70f62847f968ad43
notes_H6: On 5 November, Mogilev became the first city in Belarus to introduce compulsory use of facial masks in public places.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201210143542/https://news.tut.by/society/706859.html    On 5 November, Mogilev became the first city in Belarus to introduce compulsory use of facial masks in public places.    On 9 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Gomel Region.    According to the 11 November Ministry of Health decree, PCR-based tests were no longer conducted for first-level contacts with an asymptomatic infection course.    On 12 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Minsk. As of date, besides Minsk, Gomel Region and Mogilev, such measure was reported to had been employed in Babruisk, Asipovichy, Klichev, Krichev, Chavusy District, Cherykaw District, Polotsk District and Novopolotsk.    On 16 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Vitebsk Region.    On 18 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Brest Region.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201210143604/https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Belarus
notes_C3: No information to be found on actual recommendation/requirement of shutting down public events. There are, indeed, certain requirements on eg. distancing but no general rule to cancel.  That being said, The Ministry of Health decided on 6th of April to limit all cultural, sports and scientific events with !international! participation. Permission to hold other public events will be issued after assessing the availability of conditions for their holding. As mentioned earlier. Also, since 12th of March, places of general gathering of citizens are monitored for correct working ventilation shafts, the presence of antiseptics and compliance with other sanitary standards.  Link: https://archive.fo/g9cm7     ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++    No change in policy until early January 2021. It is recommended that fairs, exhibitions, presentations and other events are held with the observance of social distancing and the use of masks and gloves by staff.     As there seem to be no restrictions on event apart from ones with international participation, this could technically also be coded as "0"     https://web.archive.org/web/20201210134154/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/belarus/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.2+Physical+distancing&Type=Section
notes_H7: “A new stage starts in Belarus today with mass vaccinations (Sputnik V) against COVID-19. Medical staff and  teachers, will be the first to get vaccinated (tachers later on, however, see below). Vaccination will be entirely voluntary,” Belarus Health Minister Dmitry Pinevich was quoted as saying in a statement issued by his ministry and Russian health authorities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104125657/https://apnews.com/article/belarus-coronavirus-pandemic-latin-america-auto-racing-glance-russia-fcddcc286f8295421c0ff301c242dad0    "Now we continue vaccinating healthcare workers. We expect the next batch to arrive in the near future. Teachers will be next in line for a COVID-19 vaccine. In the first quarter of this year, we are set to release the Sputnik V vaccine under the Belarusian brand, together with Russian colleagues at the Belarus-based Belmedpreparaty pharmaceutical company,”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120121234/https://eng.belta.by/society/view/minister-pneumonia-cases-keep-declining-in-belarus-136636-2021/    Unable to find evidence regarding funding so have recorded government funded for now, as vaccine is voluntary and only available to certain groups, suggesting that it couldn't be purchased privately (individually funded)

name: Belize
notes_H1: "The Ministry of Health advises the public to be guided by facts. To stay informed and updated on the evolving COVID-19 situation, follow the Facebook pages of the Ministry of Health, the Office of the Director of Health Services, and the Government Press Office.  The Ministry of Health will continue to provide timely updates as our response changes to this evolving situation."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200430161753/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1016-ministry-of-health-advisory-no-5--covid-19
notes_H3: Belmopan. March 25, 2020. The Ministry hereby provides a report on an initial mapping exercise in San Pedro Town, Ambergris Caye. The mapping exercise allowed the Ministry to test seven persons who were the immediate contacts of the index case. One immediate contact from those individuals resulted as a positive case. The patient is stable and has no signs or symptoms as of today. All other samples are negative. To date, there are two confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Belize. In addition, five other samples which were collected from two other districts all tested negative. As part of the ongoing enhanced surveillance, further tests which were collected today, March 25th, in San Pedro and other districts will be processed at the lab later today. The Ministry of Health will continue its enhanced public surveillance across the country. SOURCE: https://web.archive.org/web/20200402163923/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1029-covid-19-test-samples--update-no-1
notes_H2: "At this time COVID-19 testing is only being done people who have been identified through Ministry of Health contact mapping or present themselves with COVID-19 symptoms" - as of 1st Sept 2020
notes_C7: Starting from 7th of August, no person shall enter or exit Ambergris Caye and Orange Walk villages: Santa Martha; Shipyard and Guinea Grass during the state of emergency.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200813032447/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/belize/coronavirus
notes_C8: No longer require mandatory self-quarantine for any Belizean, permanent resident,  holder of a valid work permit, Qualified Retired Person,  the foreign homeowner or long stay non-national who enters  Belize through the airport due to repeal of Amendment 20, section 1 on October 19, 2020  Latest press release  http://web.archive.org/web/20201022043048/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/SI-No-149-of-2020-Quarantine-rev.pdf  Regulations that this press release refers to:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201022043541/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/SI-136-2020-Quarantine.pdf
notes_C4: Churches, social events, and private parties that would include guests outside of the immediate family who are living together are not allowed as stated by US Embassy in Belize, updated on 1st September 2020.   The statutory instruments that set out the requirements in Belize, updated on 4th September 2020. It includes the restriction of no gatherings of more than 10 persons.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200902003040/https://bz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20200913115634/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/belize/coronavirus
notes_C1: Starting on March 20, the PM and leader of opposition announced that all schools to be closed for 14 days leading into the Easter Break. Measures announced on March 17 following first meeting of the COVID-19 National Oversight Committee.    See Belize national press office for more information:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200527181132/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/government-announces-new-measures-in-response-to-covid-19/
notes_H6: Statutory Instrument 65 states from 1st May:  "every person in a public place, public space, or public office or building shall wear a face mask or other face (mouth) covering;"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200830131649/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/SI-No-65-of-2020-Belize-Constitution-1.pdf?fbclid=IwAR1NmEevhEGOZmhhy2t3FTQEY-FbCOwCm3gdn2-6cOtjd-9DzYbN2ho2BFM    https://web.archive.org/web/20200830131055/https://www.sanpedrosun.com/politics-and-government/2020/06/30/state-of-emergency-expires-certain-restrictions-remain/  "Peyrefitte added that the only time face masks can be excluded is when someone is at home, driving in their vehicle, persons participating in church services would not be required to wear masks but are asked to practice social distancing. Also a mask is not needed when eating at a restaurant, while exercising, and participating in sporting events, to name a few. In the case of face masks, failure to use them in public places can end in an arrest and charge."
notes_C2: The Government of Belize has announced that the nationwide State of Emergency ended on Friday 4 September. Regulations remain in force to prevent, control, contain and suppress the spread of coronavirus. Restaurants can open for delivery, take away or drive through only. Spas, beauty salons and barbershops are allowed to operate with appointment only subject to social distance protocols.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200913115634/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/belize/coronavirus
notes_E2: "liquidity support through postponements of social security and tax payments for companies and self-employed"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200723165805/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: Belize has announced fiscal stimulus amounting to BZ$25 million (about 1 percent of GDP) in 2020 to provide short term relief to employees affected by the crisis, especially those in the tourism sector. So far, more than 40,000 applications for unemployment relief have been approved - as of August 27th, 2020.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200913151000/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Effective cancellation of public events: "Effective immediately, social gatherings will be limited to 100 people. These include indoor and outdoor gatherings."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200426045826/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1024-belize-announces-new-measures-in-response-to-covid-19
notes_C6: State of emergency lifted   https://web.archive.org/web/20200713173631/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/belize  http://web.archive.org/web/20200715192444/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/349986/belize-state-of-emergency-to-end-june-30-update-2
notes_C5: The Department of Transport advises ALL bus operators and the public that the Minister of Health and Wellness Hon. Michel Chebat has announced a 21-day curfew for the entire country, which will commence on Saturday, 28th November, 2020 from 9:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m.    Therefore, only those bus operators with a valid Road Service Permit with runs starting from 5:15 a.m. which are to return back to their original point of departure before 8:30 p.m. will be allowed to operate.    Special written permission must be granted by the Department of Transport to those bus operators who will need to operate outside of their normal bus schedule without interfering with the existing bus schedules within non-curfew hours.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201128062025/https://ambergriscaye.com/forum/ubbthreads.php/topics/546512/notice-to-all-bus-operators-on-curfew.html

name: Bermuda
notes_H1: The Government of Bermuda began press releases to the general public on January 22, 2020. The Government has also released videos and resource materials.  Archived Source: /web/20200402155519/https://www.gov.bm/articles/current-threat-coronavirus-bermuda-residents-low
notes_H3: "The Ministry of Health can confirm that there are no cases or known suspect cases of the coronavirus currently in Bermuda....If a case of 2019-nCoV is confirmed in Bermuda, contact tracing will begin immediately and relevant individuals will be contacted by Ministry of Health staff.  Any situation posing a risk to the safety of the general public will be communicated through official Ministry of Health channels."  Archived Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200402184005/https://www.gov.bm/articles/coronavirus-update-ministry-health-0
notes_H2: The testing schedule is regularly updated. It no longer appears to be restricted to symptomatic patients.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130003747/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-get-tested
notes_C7: No restrictions on internal movement    https://web.archive.org/web/20200916170209/https://bm.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Residents /Visitors are required to quarantine at home or in their accommodation until they receive a negative arrival test.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028234041/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-travellers   http://web.archive.org/web/20201028235035/https://bm.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: The maximum permitted number of people in any group will be reduced further to ten. http://web.archive.org/web/20201215001740/https://www.gov.bm/articles/ministerial-statement-covid-19-%E2%80%93-need-further-action
notes_C1: Public Schools reopened in-person learning on the 13th of January.     https://www.gov.bm/articles/eemc-public-schools-reopen-january-13th     http://web.archive.org/web/20210110213759/https://www.gov.bm/articles/eemc-public-schools-reopen-january-13th     Latest Covid-19 Guidelines for School Settings - http://web.archive.org/web/20210119005407/https://www.gov.bm/sites/default/files/11436-Coronavirus-2020-School-Guidance%20%286%29.pdf     Latest guidance for Minibuses and Public Buses for dedicated school runs - http://web.archive.org/web/20210119005526/https://www.gov.bm/sites/default/files/11645_School%20Buses%20Phase%204%20200903.pdf
notes_H6: Masks must be worn indoors, but outdoors only when physical distancing cannot be maintained.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201017211320/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-phase4-guidance
notes_C2: Indoor Bars and Nightclubs are closed as of 8th December http://web.archive.org/web/20201214230002/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-recreation
