Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200716034706/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/symptoms-and-treatment-coronavirus/coronavirus-tests
notes_C7: Government Q&A:  Is travel within Finland allowed? Travel within Finland is allowed as long as health and safety guidelines relating to coronavirus are observed.  All travel must be avoided when ill. During travel, it is important to observe good hand and respiratory hygiene. It is important to avoid unnecessary physical contact Tourism businesses must pay particular attention to cleaning, preparedness planning and training of staff. https://web.archive.org/web/20200523104305/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions  Old note: Starting from May 29, the Government is encouraging domestic travel. All travel should be avoided when sick, and social distancing should still be practiced.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200523104305/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions
notes_C8: Statutory restrictions on border traffic will be lifted in cross-border traffic across the Schengen internal borders by allowing employment or commission-related commuting and other essential traffic.  For the time being, recreational travel abroad is not recommended    https://web.archive.org/web/20200514124101/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions
notes_C4: There is no policy for private events, but several regional authorities recommend that people adhere to the regional guidelines for (public) indoor gatherings in private as well. I have therefore coded this as 4, since at the regional level, indoor gatherings are restricted to max 10 people (see also the note under C3).     https://web.archive.org/web/20201221180827/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions    The regional authority for Helsinki for instance recommends:     "It is recommended that no private events be held. A private gathering also means family events. An exception to the recommendation is small-scale (up to 10 people) commemorative events that can be organized."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221185524/https://www.hus.fi/ajankohtaista/koronavirus-covid-19/alueellinen-koronavirusepidemiatilanne-ja-suositukset
notes_C1: In Helsinki, institutions of upper secondary education (upper secondary schools and vocational schools) will move to distance learning. The needs for necessary contact teaching will still be secured. Contact teaching will be offered, among other groups, to disabled students receiving special needs education and to students who need individual support for any reason. Distance learning will begin at the start of the new evaluation period on 3 December 2020 and continue until 31 December 2020.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201221175327/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/coronavirus-en/childhood-and    In the rest of the country, schools remain open but with social distancing measures in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201221175732/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/questions-and-answers
notes_H6: THL currently recommends the use of face masks in all parts of the country. More detailed recommendations on the use of masks in different situations depend on the phases of the epidemic, and these can vary from one area to another.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124210002/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/recommendation-on-the-use-of-face-masks-for-citizens
notes_C2: In general, working from home is recommended and workplaces remain open. In Helsinki, public spaces have been closed, which means the closure of some sectors, including all urban indoor sports facilities, cultural centers, museums, youth facilities and the zoo. This measure is in place from 30 Nov 2020 until 31 Jan 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210108142952/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset
notes_E2: Government announced on 5 June a removal of value added tax on PP&E and other goods vital  to fight the pandemic. This will sacrifice around 7 million euros of government revenue over 2020.     http://archive.vn/NWn81
notes_E1: From March 16, the government has removed waiting periods and abolished some conditionalities on the duration of employment etc. to make unemployment benefits more accessible for people who have lost their jobs due to the pandemic. 'The five-day waiting period has been abolished starting 16 March. Unemployment benefits will be available from the first day of unemployment. The normal five-day waiting period will be applied again as of 7 July 2020.' 'The work requirement for qualifying for unemployment allowance has been reduced temporarily (.. ) The change will be effective until 6 July 2020.'     The Finnish benefits system is complicated, so it's not possible to clearly define whether income support is set at above or below 50% of normal earnings. There are multiple different types of benefits a person can receive depending on factors such as employment history and union membership. The amount of the base unemployment benefit provided by KELA is means-tested; increases to the base amount will be granted depending on conditions such as the number of children and the availability of other sources of income. Many people who lost their jobs will also be union members who receive earnings-related benefit that are calculated on the basis of duration of employment; in many cases this will be larger than the base amount.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200523110355/https://www.kela.fi/web/en/unemployment-benefit-corona
notes_C3: Coding change here due to the following:  Public events and general meetings of more than 20 people are prohibited in the Helsinki and Uusimaa Hospital District on 23 November-13 December 2020 (Southern Finland).   https://web.archive.org/web/20201201001519/https://www.avi.fi/web/avi/ajankohtaista-tiedotteet
notes_C6: No stay at home orders in place. Travel within Finland is allowed as long as health and safety guidelines relating to coronavirus are observed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124192250/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions
notes_H7: A,B,C as per: https://web.archive.org/web/20210115143227/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/vaccines-and-coronavirus/vaccination-order-and-at-risk-groups-for-covid-19 Vaccines on order: BioNTech – Pfizer (Comirnaty-vaccin) Moderna AstraZeneca Curevac Jansen Group Sanofi-GSK Novavax http://web.archive.org/web/20210115143749/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/vaccines-and-coronavirus/arranging-covid-19-vaccinations-in-finland  Note, that all are planned to be vaccinated, but it is currently only rolled out for two groups: According to a Government Decree (22 December 2020), the vaccinations are first offered to social and health care professionals who treat COVID-19 patients and to people who work and live in nursing homes or housing services for the elderly. Most of these vaccinations will be carried out in January–February 2021.   The vaccine will then be offered to elderly persons and to those with diseases that predispose them to severe coronavirus disease. After that, the vaccine will be offered to the rest of the population. It is still unclear when the vaccine can be offered to everyone willing to be vaccinated because the schedule mainly depends on the marketing authorisations and the availability of the vaccines.

name: Fiji
notes_H1: Regular public advisories on social media and government websites released starting from Jan 22:    https://web.archive.org/web/20200609073437/http://www.health.gov.fj/media-release-1-2019-novel-coronavirus/    https://web.archive.org/web/20200609073613/https://www.facebook.com/MoHFiji/photos/pcb.1771720962959435/1771720439626154/?type=3&theater=
notes_H3: Upon confirmation of COVID-19 (first case), the Ministry's highly-trained contact team –– which effectively contained last year’s measles outbreak with the same contact-tracing methods –– was immediately put into action to identify all those with whom the patient has been in close contact. Those points of contact are currently being sought out and quarantined. The capacity of our contact team has been further strengthened by the Republic of Fiji Military Forces and the Fiji Police Force, heightening our capacity to trace and quarantine all those potentially exposed to the virus.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200509173949/https://www.fiji.gov.fj/Media-Centre/Speeches/PM-BAINIMARAMA%E2%80%99S-STATEMENT-ON-THE-FIRST-COVID-19-C
notes_H2: Mr Bainimarama said the government had widened its testing to all close contacts of every confirmed case regardless of whether they were displaying symptoms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200501033925/https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/414433/fiji-declares-second-state-of-natural-disaster-as-covid-19-cases-increase
notes_C7: "Domestic travel is returning to normal". https://web.archive.org/web/20200727224748/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/fiji/coronavirus
notes_C8: The change of code to a 3 reflects the immigration rule concerning yachts in the "Blue Lanes" scheme.  As yachts are allowed entry if they satisfy various requirements of the Fiji authorities, the conclusion is that - although limited in scale - the borders are open to some who are not citizens of Fiji.  As such, a code of "4" referring to banning arrival from all regions or total border closure would not reflect the situation.  "Fiji has established a safe “blue lanes”, open to those yachts and pleasure craft sailing to Fiji. Any boat coming to Fiji will be carefully considered on a case-by-case basis. The only port of entry will be Port Denarau Marina. If this pilot project and if successful, extending blue lanes to other ports and marinas will be considered."  Link: http://archive.today/2020.10.12-080639/http://www.immigration.gov.fj/
notes_C4: As of 25th August 2020, gatherings (which were limited to 100 people) will now be increased to 250 people.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200831153129/http://www.health.gov.fj/statement-by-ps-health-on-border-case-and-covid-safe-amendments/
notes_C1: Changing the status to no measures. Schools for Fiji have been open and functioning for their third semester. This site has the best aggregate news on the dates with the schools, dated in June, but I still archived and am noting it here.   "Our plan to reopen schools has catered for a realigned school curriculum, ensuring that all of Fiji’s schools are on the same page. It simply wouldn’t be fair for children in different schools to be disadvantaged just because of where they live, and which school they attend, whether public or private...resuming education in two stages: Year 12 and Year 13 students in our secondary schools will start classes on Tuesday, 30 June. Tertiary institutions can open for face-to-face classes from 30 June. The rest of the primary and secondary schools –– as well as early childhood education –– will open one week later, on Monday, the 6th of July....details will be outlined by the Ministry of Education" source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201214153515/https://www.fiji.gov.fj/Media-Centre/Speeches/PRIME-MINISTER-VOREQE-BAINIMARAMA-S-STATEMENT-ON-C
notes_H6: The MINISTRY OF COMMERCE, TRADE, TOURISM & TRANSPORT website notes that since June 21st Fiji is implementing Phase 2 of its "COVID Safe Economic Recovery (Framework)" (see link below). There is a link to the Framework on this page which opens a PDF covering the policies in each phase of the plan.   For face coverings, Phase 2 details some recommended and some mandatory situations for the wearing of masks. For gatherings such as weddings, the policy is "Strongly encourage the use of PPE, such as face covering".  For domestic travel mask wearing is "strongly encouraged". For hair dressers, beauty services and spas, "employees must wear face coverings when serving clients" and it is mandatory where physical distancing of greater than 1.5m is not possible.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201014124120/https://www.mcttt.gov.fj/doc_uploads/Tourism%20Guidelines.pdf     http://archive.today/2020.10.12-112252/https://www.mcttt.gov.fj/guidelines/covid-19-guidelines/covid-19-important-guidelines/
notes_C2: Localised lockdowns have been lifted, but some business sectors must remain closed across Fiji: Nightclubs, gyms, cinemas, swimming pools, and houses of worship to remain closed.     http://archive.vn/P3Jz2
notes_E2: The Government has struck a deal with banks and higher purchase companies to suspend loan repayments and interest for those who need it. This includes tertiary education loans. This is for a 6 month period    http://archive.vn/7lqlZ
notes_E1: -Fijians in the informal sector who tested positive for the virus to be paid a one-off sum of $1,000  -Informal sector in the lockdown areas entitled to one-off Government relief payment of $150 where holding a street trader or hawker license  -Government to fund 21 days COVID- 19 leave for Fijian employees earning less than $30,000 who have tested positive for the virus    https://web.archive.org/web/20200420154422/https://fijisun.com.fj/2020/03/27/covid-19-response-budget-government-to-top-up-accounts/    https://web.archive.org/web/20200609102409/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/fiji-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html
notes_C3: 'We’ll be permitting live sporting events to resume, but with restrictions. Our formal indoor and outdoors sporting venues can host sporting events with spectators at 50 per cent capacity, so long as physical distancing is maintained within the venue. For informal sports events at the community level, the 100-person limit applies. '  http://archive.fo/T7zX8
notes_C6: They are in phase 2 of their framework, which only recommends staying at home when someone travels: https://web.archive.org/web/20201214160030/https://www.frcs.org.fj/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Fijian-COVID-Safe-Economic-Recovery-Framework-1.pdf
notes_C5: Last lockdown eases:    https://web.archive.org/web/20200609105822/https://www.fbcnews.com.fj/news/covid-19/vunicagi-settlement-restriction-lifted/

name: France
notes_H1: FAQ of government: Information posters rolled out nationwide at train stations; https://web.archive.org/web/20200402111143/http://www.essonne.gouv.fr/content/download/30487/234871/file/FAQ%2520-%2520COVID-19%2520-%2520260220.pdf
notes_H3: May 11 marks the beginning of a gradual deconfinement. Monitoring of all the indicators is underway (the rate of new cases in the population over a period of seven days, the hospital capacities in intensive care remain saturated, the local system of tests and detection of contact cases is not sufficiently ready).   This phase will run until June 2.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200524220240/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/les-actions-du-gouvernement
notes_H2: Tests are free and can be carried out without a medical prescription and on non-symptomatic patients since July 25, 2020. https://web.archive.org/web/20200915140317/https://twitter.com/MinSoliSante/status/1297149019739873280?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1297149019739873280%7Ctwgr%5Eshare_3&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linternaute.fr%2Factualite%2Fguide-vie-quotidienne%2F2489431-test-covid-19-publics-prioritaires-tentes-de-depistage-ce-qui-va-changer%2F  "Afin de faciliter le dépistage de la Covid-19, les tests PCR sont totalement pris en charge par l'assurance maladie et ne nécessitent pas de prescription d'un médecin". https://web.archive.org/web/20200915135127/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915135513/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/soins-et-maladies/maladies/maladies-infectieuses/coronavirus/tout-savoir-sur-la-covid-19/article/se-faire-depister-lieux-et-conditions
notes_C7: There are no restrictions for traveling within France.    https://archive.vn/jGRh1#selection-2541.0-2541.54
notes_C8: "Macron Confirms: All External & Internal Schengen Borders Will Close on Tuesday 17th March at Noon"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200425221726/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/macron-confirms-all-external-internal-schengen-borders-will-close-on-tuesday-at-noon/    "March 17 :  - extraordinary European council by videoconference;  - restriction of travel to the strict minimum in the European Union;  - closure of the borders of the Schengen area;  - activation of the interministerial crisis unit by the Prime Minister."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200813100514/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19    This 'strict minimum' is:  "French citizens and their children are allowed back into the country, but foreigners are only allowed in under certain circumstances.  These are  People who have their primary residence in France. This does NOT include second home owners. Third country nationals will need to present a visa or residency card while EU nationals (which for this purpose still includes British people) do not need any proof of residency status.  People who have their permanent residency in another European country and are travelling through France to get home  Healthcare workers engaged in coronavirus-related care  Commercial good carriers such as lorry drivers and flight or cargo crews  Diplomatic staff  Cross-border workers. So for example if you live in France but work in Switzerland you will still be able to travel back and forth."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200813101145/https://www.thelocal.fr/20200407/permission-form-now-needed-for-anyone-entering-france
notes_C4: Social gatherings are banned. Everyone found outside has to carry a written statement justifying their journey.   'Places of worship may remain open for weddings (with a maximum of six people) and funerals (with a maximum of 30 people).'    https://web.archive.org/web/20201102183825/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19
notes_C1: France entered a new national lockdown on Friday 30 October. Schools and creches will remain open with social-distancing measures in place, but universities nationwide will be shut with online learning will be carried out.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201102183825/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19
notes_H6: Masks are still mandatory in all closed spaces  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915092101/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/masques-grand-public  and, from August 3, préfets can decide to make it mandatory at all times outside the home locally:   https://web.archive.org/web/20200915134412/https://twitter.com/JeanCASTEX/status/1290210634722729984?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1290210634722729984%7Ctwgr%5Eshare_3&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.france24.com%2Ffr%2F20200804-quelles-sont-les-villes-de-france-oC3B9-le-masque-est-obligatoire-en-extC3A9rieur  This measure has been implemented in various cities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915092204/https://www.leparisien.fr/societe/la-carte-des-communes-qui-imposent-le-port-du-masque-en-exterieur-02-08-2020-8362416.php
notes_C2: Gradual re-opening.   Shops and services, including public libraries, are now open.    Bars, restaurants, cinemas, theatres, museums and gyms remain closed.    https://archive.vn/ZpG77#selection-471.1-475.70
notes_E2: According to French government website and IMF website, postponement of rent and utility payments only apply to microenterprises and SMEs.   Cannot find any information about debt or contract relief specific to households.  https://archive.vn/NWam2  https://archive.vn/nyT1l#selection-9613.928-9613.1016
notes_E1: L’État a mis en place, avec les Régions, un fonds de solidarité doté d’1,7 milliard d’euros pour le mois de mars qui permettra le versement d’une aide défiscalisée allant jusqu’à 1500 euros aux plus petites entreprises, aux indépendants, aux micro-entrepreneurs et aux professions libérales touchés par la crise du coronavirus. Ce fonds sera maintenu autant que durera l’urgence sanitaire.https://web.archive.org/save/http://hauts-de-france.direccte.gouv.fr/Coronavirus-COVID-19-mouvements-sociaux-la-Direccte-vous-accompagne
notes_C3: Public gatherings are banned.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201102183825/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19
notes_C6: People are allowed to leave their home only to go to work (if they cannot work from home), to buy essential goods, seek medical help or to exercise for one hour a day. Everyone found outside has to carry a written statement justifying their journey.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201102183825/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19
notes_C5: True return to normal for almost all public transport in Paris and Ile-de-France. All metro stations will be open from June 22, 2020. Almost all RATP buses, tram, metro and RER are working at 100%. The same goes for the majority of Transilien SNCFs. https://web.archive.org/web/20200722155345/https://www.francebleu.fr/infos/transports/transports-en-commun-en-ile-de-france-toutes-les-stations-de-metro-seront-ouvertes-a-partir-du-22-1592483057
notes_H7: A, C:    The HAS (Haute Autorite de Sante = High Authority of Health) recommends first vaccinating the elderly in establishments, in particular EHPADs, as well as the staff working there when they are at risk of developing a severe form of COVID. This represents around 1 million people.    On January 5, 2020, Olivier Véran indicated that firefighters and home helpers over 50 years old will be able to benefit from the injection as priority personnel. "They are also professionals who are in contact with fragile people and who may have to work with the sick," said the minister to justify this decision.  https://archive.vn/a0Ju1

name: Faeroe Islands
notes_H1: 31st March 2020, Although most institutions have closed down amid the corona lockdown, there are numerous phone helplines that can offer support and advice.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201207225036/https://corona.fo/news/242/help-is-only-a-phone-call-away?_l=en
notes_H3: 10th April 2020, Special corona strategy saves lives  The Faroese strategy has placed a strong focus on suppression, with world record high test numbers relative to the population as a means of suppressing the virus entirely by trying to catch cases early and trace all contacts.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208075454/http://kvf.fo/greinar/2020/04/10/special-corona-strategy-saves-lives
notes_H2: 23rd March 2020, Currently, over 2.200 tests have been conducted in the Faroe Islands. Tests are conducted at the hospitals in the Faroe Islands, and the samples are examined by the Faroese Food and Veterinary Authority.  The Faroe Islands seem to hold the record for most tests conducted per million inhabitants – at least compared to Scandinavia and other countries, which have a high amount of cases, statistics from the website Our World in Data reveal.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113034623/http://local.fo/covid-19-the-faroe-islands-conduct-the-most-tests/
notes_C8: As a consequence of the pandemic and the current infection rates internationally, the Danish government has decided to place the entire world on the travel red list. This means that the authorities are discouraging all international travel, included work-related travel. Denmark has therefore introduced stricter requirements to travellers who travel to Denmark and do not have a residence there.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210124111944/https://corona.fo/news/797/regarding-persons-travelling-to-the-faroe-islands-by-air?_l=en
notes_C4: People can now gather in groups of up to 100, while also maintaining the recommended physical distance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208121019/https://corona.fo/news/431/reopening-faroese-society-phase-3?_l=en
notes_C1: On Thursday 14 May 2020, the Government of the Faroe Islands announced the third phase in the reopening of Faroese society.  All levels of primary and secondary school will return to school. This means that pupils in grades 6, 7, 8 and 10 should return to school as soon as possible. The University of the Faroe Islands, the Centre of Maritime Studies and Engineering and colleges can also resume normal activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208121019/https://corona.fo/news/431/reopening-faroese-society-phase-3?_l=en
notes_H6: "Face masks are recommended when a lot of people are in a shop."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210124105454/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en
notes_C2: No policy change
notes_E2: Before business resumed on Monday, the Faroese government announced four ways they would help businesses get through this crisis.[40]    1)The government will pay companies back the salary of people who have been asked by the government to be in quarantine. People who can work from home are not covered.  2) If companies need to decrease the amount of hours their employees work, the Faroese Employment Office will provide the lost income at a percentage of the maximum payment.  3) Companies can pay their VAT 3 months late.  4) The Danish Growth Fund can assist small and medium-sized companies with financing of operations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208091337/https://corona.fo/user_login?_redirect=%2Fhjalparpakki2%3F_l%3Den
notes_E1: 15th March 2020, The remuneration structure applies to all Faroese companies, some in the period 31 March to 30 June 2020 have at least a 50 per cent decline in sales combined with the same period last year. Fishing, aling, fisheries, etc. are not covered by the order.    Treytir fyri at fáa remuneration is, among other things, that the companies will not pay out the prize money for the next three years, and that a joint exhibition for managers and management members is not more than 600,000 ISK. this year.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201208091337/https://corona.fo/user_login?_redirect=%2Fhjalparpakki2%3F_l%3Den
notes_C3: "Schools and daycare centres are advised not to hold larger events to which people from outside the institution are usually invited. This includes Christmas celebrations which would normally be attended by parents and other family members. Christmas church services for school pupils and preschool children should not be organised as usual this year."  "All indoor sporting events should be held without spectators. This applies to both adult and children’s competitions. Coaches and assistants can be present during matches."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210124105454/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en
notes_C6: It is advisable that only one person in the household does the shopping, rather than going several together. It is also advisable to go shopping when there are fewer people.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210124111431/https://corona.fo/recommendations-and-measures?_l=en
notes_C5: SSL buses will now resume their normal schedule on all routes, with no requirement for prior booking. Some restrictions will still apply. A maximum of 22 passengers can travel with the larger buses, 10 with the medium size buses and 5 with people with the small buses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208121019/https://corona.fo/news/431/reopening-faroese-society-phase-3?_l=en
notes_H7: A, B, C (Pfizer/BioNtech)  Source: https://archive.fo/Y48NW

name: Gabon
notes_H1: Start of publishing Facebook videos/graphics to spread awareness of health measures to take.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200622141442/https://www.facebook.com/PresidenceGabon/videos/272794397185865/
notes_H3: "Dr. Guy Patrick Obiang Ndong announced that from Monday, March 30, health personnel will screen all contact cases." https://web.archive.org/web/20200417082047/https://www.gabonreview.com/gabon-tous-les-cas-contacts-seront-depistes-au-covid-19/
notes_H2: According to UNICEF situation overview Gabon has been testing symptomatic patients since March 12th. However, as of April 24 testing scope broaden to general availability albeit lagging in results. https://reliefweb.int/report/gabon/unicef-gabon-covid-19-situation-report-02-reporting-period-15-30-april
notes_C7: The Gabonese government has implemented the following COVID-19 measures:    To travel between cities in Gabon, travelers must show a negative COVID-19 result of a test within the previous 14 days.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210110122848/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/
notes_C8: Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19)  Entry to Gabon  Flight restrictions have eased to allow three flights per airline, per week. Land and sea borders are closed.    UK nationals must receive authorisation from the Gabonese Ministry of Foreign Affairs before travelling to Gabon. Authorisation can be obtained by sending an e-mail addressed to the ‘Minister’ or ‘Secretary General’ at the following e-mail address: ginetedzang2@gmail.com.    On arrival, all passengers must take a compulsory test for COVID-19 at Libreville Airport. Passengers are then required to self-isolate for 48 hours whilst the COVID-19 test is being processed. If the COVID-19 test is negative, passengers will be issued a test certificate, which is valid for 14 days and can be renewed at the end of this period after another test is undertaken.    If a COVID-19 test taken at the airport is positive, then passengers are required to continue self-isolation and await specific instructions from Gabonese health authorities. All COVID-19 tests taken in Gabon supersede any that were taken before arrival in Gabon.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210116131908/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/entry-requirements
notes_C4: Restriction lifted from 10 to 30 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201109223513/https://gabonactu.com/deconfinement-quelques-allegements-et-une-batterie-des-nouvelles-contraintes/
notes_C1: Schools fully open; source: /web/20210106063747/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H6: "You must wear a mask in public areas.".     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200903130359/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus
notes_C2: Public transportation has resumed nationwide, though some limits on passenger numbers remain in place. Hotels have also been allowed to reopen, as have restaurants with outdoor terraces. Some academic activities have resumed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111104247/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/414551/gabon-covid-19-related-state-of-health-emergency-extended-through-january-2021-update-11
notes_E2: The government is drafting legislation to adjust spending plans. OPEC’s second-smallest member secured $147 million from the International Monetary Fund on Friday to support its efforts to contain the virus and the economic damage it causes. President Ali Bongo Ondimba said an "exceptional massive aid" package of FCFA 250 billion ($415 million) had been set up to help both individuals and businesses who have been hard hit by the coronavirus pandemic.  He said the state will inject FCFA 225 million will be used to help companies while FCFA 6 billion ($10 million) will be dedicated to monthly payment of electricity and water bills for the "most fragile and economically weak" Gabonese.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200622142711/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-11/gabon-declares-state-of-emergency-over-covid-19-revises-outlook
notes_E1: "Unemployment benefit of between 50% and 70% of previous income. Low income (between 80.000CFA and 150.000CFA) will be maintained."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200622142844/https://www.macrotopic.com/HTML/gov_measures/covid19_goverment_measures_GAB.html
notes_C3: Cancellation of public events will be highly recommended since there is a restriction on gatherings
notes_C6: Domestic Measures    A nightly 2000-0500 curfew remains in effect.    Residents must wear facemasks and adhere to other hygiene protocols.    Places of worship and bars remain closed; sporting events and other large gatherings remain suspended.    Public transportation has resumed nationwide, though some limits on passenger numbers remain in place. Hotels have also been allowed to reopen, as have restaurants with outdoor terraces. Some academic activities have resumed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201220211152/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/414551/gabon-covid-19-related-state-of-health-emergency-extended-through-january-2021-update-11
notes_C5: Public transportation has resumed nationwide, though some limits on passenger numbers remain in place.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201220211152/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/414551/gabon-covid-19-related-state-of-health-emergency-extended-through-january-2021-update-11

name: United Kingdom
notes_H1: UK Public Health Campaign Launched https://web.archive.org/web/20200427142157/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/coronavirus-public-information-campaign-launched-across-the-uk
notes_H3: NHS Test and Trace has made significant improvements to its contact tracing service and is successfully tracing 92.7% of contacts and telling them to self-isolate, up from 85.9% last week.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221224223/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/nhs-test-and-trace-reaching-more-than-92-of-contacts
notes_H2: UK expands testing so that 'Everyone in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland with coronavirus (COVID-19) symptoms can now get a test.'  https://web.archive.org/web/20200621175239/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/everyone-in-the-united-kingdom-with-symptoms-now-eligible-for-coronavirus-tests
notes_C7: In Scotland On 20 November 2020 new regulations came in to force that restrict travel in or out of level 3 and level 4 local authority areas, except for essential purposes    We need to keep public transport for essential journeys.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201216105916/https://www.transport.gov.scot/travelling-during-covid-19/using-public-transport-in-scotland-during-covid-19/
notes_C8: passengers travelling from South Africa into England from 9am Thursday 24 December will not be permitted to enter, reflecting increased risk from new strain of coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115174613/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/travel-ban-implemented-to-protect-public-health-following-south-africa-covid-19-outbreak
notes_C4: Reversion to before Christmas Day restrictions.
notes_C1: England enters lockdown on Tuesday 5 January. All schools are closed, except for the children of essential workers, despite all students having attended school on Monday 4th.     Colleges, primary (reception onwards) and secondary schools will remain open for vulnerable children and the children of critical workers. All other children will learn remotely until February half term  Universities- Those students who are undertaking training and study for the specific courses should return to face to face learning as planned and be tested twice, upon arrival or self-isolate for ten days.    All 4 devolved nations now have schools closed, meaning this is a policy that applies generally across the UK now      https://web.archive.org/web/20210106100514/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/national-lockdown-stay-at-home
notes_H6: From 14 September, the Welsh government effectively required face coverings in *ALL indoor public places*, for both customers and staff working in those indoor public areas. This includes a very wide range of locations, such as shops and shopping centres, places of worship, hairdressers and salons, cinemas and museums, gyms and leisure centres, and anywhere that is open to members of the public. It would also include any public areas within buildings that are otherwise closed to the public – for example a reception area of an office building.    The only indoor public areas where face coverings will not be required are where you are inside a place to eat or drink, for example, cafés, restaurants and pubs - but only for the purpose of eating or drinking.     Since all nations of the UK now have a 2 in place, upgraded to 2G (see subnational coding).  https://web.archive.org/web/20201003210731/https://gov.wales/face-coverings-guidance-public
notes_C2: Under the restrictions introduced for people in Tier 4 areas, non-essential shops, hairdressers, and leisure and entertainment venues must close, with a new “stay at home” message introduced.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201221220505/https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2020/dec/21/covid-tier-4-what-are-the-new-rules-london-south-east-england-christmas
notes_E2: UK gov reaches agreement with energy companies to ensure people receive power throughout coronavirus crisis even if they fall into debt on payments  "Measures include ensuring prepayment and pay-as-you go customers remain supplied with energy through challenging times and supporting all customers in financial distress  industry agreement signed by all UK domestic suppliers and will come into force immediately"   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/government-agrees-measures-with-energy-industry-to-support-vulnerable-people-through-covid-19
notes_E1: Measures introduced to include self-employed workers:   "Self-employed workers can apply for a grant worth 80% of their average monthly profits to help them cope with the financial impact of coronavirus"; up to £2,500 a month in a single lump sum; paid in June; open to those who earn under £50,000 a year - up to 3.8 million of the 5 million people registered as self-employed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200410025157/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-52053914
notes_C3: The public is advised in Sturgeon's address to the Nation on 22 March that gatherings and parties, receptions and celebrations are not allowed. This now counts across all 4 devolved nations.  http://archive.vn/wip/CY4Re
notes_C6: All devolved nations are under stay at home orders    Scots are to be ordered to stay at home amid a fresh Covid-19 lockdown on 5 January. These are the toughest restrictions Scotland has faced since the lockdown of March 2020.      The new rules - which will be put down in law - mean Scots will only be allowed to leave home for essential purposes, such as shopping for food and medicine, exercise and caring responsibilities.    No limit is to be put on how many times people can go out to exercise, but outdoor meetings are to be limited to a maximum of two people from two households.      These rules will apply across the Scottish mainland until at least the end of January, and will be kept under review.    https://web.archive.org/web/20
notes_C5: https://web.archive.org/web/20200320191027/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/government-announces-further-measures-on-social-distancing  “The closures announced today will not impact the running of public transport, and government continues to work closely with transport operators to ensure that people who need to get to work can continue to do so.  Yesterday, the government and rail industry agreed a plan that will see a gradual reduction in train services across the country to reflect lower passenger demand as people change their travel patterns to help reduce the spread of coronavirus, while keeping vital rail services running.”
notes_H7: Currently UK is offering the Pfizer vaccine to "frontline staff, those over 80, and care home workers" from 50 hospitals. It expects to begin vaccinating all care home residents in 2 weeks," but is not doing so yet. Vaccines will be distributed evenly across the 4 nations of the UK. The UK has ordered 40m doses of this vaccine, and has 880,000 on hand https://web.archive.org/web/20201208073322/https://www.bbc.com/news/health-55045639  UK policy for COVID Vaccines in England given by Public Health England "Green Book" https://web.archive.org/web/20201208072743/https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/941450/Greenbook_chapter_14a_v2.pdf

name: Georgia
notes_H1: The Action Plan developed by the government seeks to provide the public and media with correct information, to which end the Public Broadcaster of Georgia has been requested to supply the public at large with correct and useful information on coronavirus and ways to mitigate its risks: http://archive.vn/k9FQ8
notes_H3: The first case of infection with a new type of coronavirus was recorded in Georgia, said Health Minister Yekaterina Tikaradze: https://web.archive.org/web/20200515025948/https://ria.ru/20200226/1565252642.html
notes_H2: Testing extended to asymptomatic individuals who have no symptoms today, but have been to Italy or have received guests from this country, or have been in contact with patients. The third package extends to those that are treated in hospitals, or stay at home and have symptoms, but there are no risk factors. That is, they cough, have fever, sore throat, but have never been anywhere and have not had contact with the alleged patient. Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200515025244/https://sputnik-georgia.ru/society/20200401/248130604/Gruziya-izmenila-protokol-diagnostiki-koronavirusa.html
notes_C7: Municipal transport will be suspended within Tbilisi, Telavi, Batumi, Kutaisi, Rustavi, Gori. Poti and Zugdidi. Mobility of people walking or driving restricted across Georgia, as well as staying in a public space from 21:00 to 05:00; exceptions will be made for the New Year's Eve on December 31 and Orthodox Christmas on January 6.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130172338/https://www.stopcov.ge/en/shezgudvebi
notes_C8: Georgia has suspended entry into the country for most foreign citizens, with exceptions to some EU countries. The state border of Georgia is unconditionally opened for Germany, France, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. Citizens of EU countries with which Georgia opens the border by reservation, can enter Georgia under a 14-day mandatory quarantine.   http://web.archive.org/web/20200718144751/https://stopcov.ge/ka/EntryRules
notes_C4: "No more than 10 people can participate in social gatherings such as weddings and funerals, indoor or out. There is no limit on gatherings for political or election-related activities."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201017081634/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/georgia/coronavirus
notes_C1: Many schools have moved to distance learning.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201106191444/https://ge.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-on-georgia/
notes_H6: Face masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, including taxis and public transportation. Violators of face musk rules are subject to a 20 GEL (about 6 USD) fine. There are some exceptions for children under 6, people with disabilities, or who have health problems that prevent them from wearing a face covering.  Link: Measures to control the spread of COVID-19 in Georgia | U.S. Embassy in Georgia (archive.fo)
notes_C2: on 23 May 2020, The state of emergency was concluded. All types of economic activities became permitted, with the following exceptions o Providing customers with on-site catering services in restaurants, bars, cafes, or diners of any type; o Trading in clothes and shoes (permitted online); 15 o The operation of trade centers (shopping malls) and open-air markets (with the exception of open agrarian markets); o Organizing or holding sporting, cultural, or entertainment activities; o The operation of currency exchange points.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200718152025/https://stopcov.ge/Content/files/COVID_RESPONSE_REPORT__ENG.pdf  According to the US Embassy COVID-19?information for Georgia?updated on July 17,?2020, Many swimming pools and gyms have reopened, after passing a health inspection.  Restaurants and hotels have reopened subject to periodic ongoing health inspections. Customers in restaurants are required to wear masks when moving about indoors, and to maintain social distancing measures, with a maximum of six people allowed at one table.   http://web.archive.org/web/20200718145003/https://ge.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-on-georgia/
notes_E1: "All hired employees who officially worked and lost their jobs, income during the crisis after the declaration of the state of emergency and cannot receive their salaries, will receive assistance from the state in the amount of 1200 GEL over a period of six months. This means that these people will receive 200 GEL per month" - Prime Minister. "In addition, the same kind of subsidy will be received for the salary of 750 GEL for all retained jobs and remuneration will be up to 1500 GEL. In fact, in this way we are assisting both the citizens of Georgia to retain their jobs salaries and the entrepreneurs to retain the jobs. The budget of this event is 250 million GEL", said Giorgi Gakharia: http://archive.vn/28a9Y
notes_C3: Any and all types of conferences, training sessions, cultural or entertainment events are restricted. Only virtual formats will be permitted online.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130172338/https://www.stopcov.ge/en/shezgudvebi
notes_C6: The Government of Georgia imposed movement restrictions in major cities between 10 PM and 5 AM. During the restricted time, public and private transportation (including walking) is not permitted, unless it is for an essential need.  Link: https://archive.fo/kYCaw
notes_C5: Regular inter-city passenger transportation, including that of by rail, bus or minibus are restricted. Restriction does not apply to light vehicles (including taxis).     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130172338/https://www.stopcov.ge/en/shezgudvebi

name: Ghana
notes_H1: A coordinated public informational campaign through this webpage. https://web.archive.org/web/20200315001922/https://ghanahealthservice.org/covid19/
notes_H3: /web/20200407003532/https://www.theghanareport.com/coronavirus-contact-tracing-increases-to-600-health-minister/
notes_H2: In his address, the president said that "all persons that have come in contact with infected persons [will be] tested for the virus" http://web.archive.org/web/20200518210434/https://twitter.com/moigovgh/status/1241474156891459586/photo/1
notes_C7: With the lifting of the partial lockdown of Accra and two other cities on April 19th, there does not appear to be any limits to internal movement  https://archive.vn/sW0wL
notes_C8: 'Ghana is reopening its main airport to international flight passengers from Sept. 1 ... Any passenger arriving in Ghana will have to present a negative Covid-19 result, taken no more than 72 hours before departure from the country of origin, President Nana Akufo-Addo said in a broadcast Sunday. Upon arrival, passengers will again be tested at the airport, with results to be provided within 30 minutes. International travel by land and sea are still prohibited.'  https://archive.vn/mFF9B    The President's speech on 30 August: https://archive.vn/sJY1N    Meanwhile, 'borders, by land and sea, will remain closed to human traffic until further notice'.  https://archive.vn/JrOSE
notes_C4: " All public gatherings, including conferences, workshops, funerals, festivals, political rallies, sporting events and religious activities, such as services in churches and mosques, have been suspended for the next four (4) weeks. Private burials are permitted, but with limited numbers, not exceeding twenty-five (25) in attendance"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200510225459/https://www.moh.gov.gh/president-akufo-addo-addresses-nation-on-measures-taken-by-govt-to-combat-the-coronavirus-pandemic/
notes_C1: From today final year senior high school students (SHS 3), and second year Gold Track students returned to school - this was announced yesterday by the President:    https://web.archive.org/web/20200625192353/http://www.presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1601-update-no-12-measures-taken-to-combat-spread-of-coronavirus
notes_H6: The President of Ghana said in his speech on 14 June that, 'the wearing of masks is now mandatory. Leaving our homes without a face mask or face covering on is an offence. The Police have been instructed to enforce this directive, which is the subject of an Executive Instrument.'    https://archive.vn/4PIDh
notes_C2: Total lockdown imposed in some key cities was lifted on April 20th in a speech by the president which states "Businesses and other workplaces can continue to operate, observing staff management and workplace protocols with the view to achieving social distancing and hygiene protocols." - No Explicit reference to working from home but it is here assumed through "social distancing and hygiene protocols" - https://web.archive.org/web/20200425193750/https://www.cnbcafrica.com/news/2020/04/20/ghana-lifts-lockdown-on-key-regions-as-covid-19-cases-reach-1042/
notes_E2: Policy ended in June
notes_C3: " it has been decided that the Ghana Premier League and the Division One Football League will restart on Friday, 30th October, with a full regime of testing of the players, technical and management staff. No spectators will be allowed at the training centres, and, when actual competition resumes, seating at all stadia will be limited to twenty-five percent (25%) capacity to ensure social distancing. Wearing of masks by spectators at stadia will be mandatory. The restart of all other sporting competitions will be determined on a case-by-case basis, pending consultations between the Ministry of Youth and Sports and the respective sport associations"  17th Address by President, https://archive.vn/JrOSE  While other public events may still be required to close, I understand this as "recommended" since not ALL are required to close given this exception
notes_C6: https://archive.vn/sW0wL
notes_C5: Market places, work places, public transport, and constitutional and statutory bodies such as the Electoral Commission, the National Commission for Civic Education and the National Identification Authority, whose activities were exempted from the outset from these restrictions, must conduct their activities in accordance with social distancing and the necessary hygiene and safety protocols.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200604215546/http://www.presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1597-update-no-10-measures-taken-to-combat-spread-of-coronavirus

name: Guinea
notes_H1: The Minister of Health makes a press release urging Guineans to take precautions to protect themselves from COVID-19. He also informs the public about the actions being taken by the government regarding the issue.     https://web.archive.org/save/https://sante.gov.gn/communique-du-gouvernement-sur-lepidemie-de-coronavirus-declaree-par-la-chine/    https://web.archive.org/save/https://mobile.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=2725823084198063&id=685140344933024&_rdc=1&_rdr
notes_H3: The daily situation report includes the numbers of contacts identified and the number of contacts that were followed up with. It appears fairly comprehensive. On Nov 29th, for example, 712 contacts were identified and 703 were followed up with.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201201014746/https://anss-guinee.org/assets/document/DOC_160672245812047426425fc4a39ac1707.pdf
notes_H2: The Health Minister advises those who have symptoms of COVID-19 to go to the health centres.    "Drive to a health facility anyone showing suspicious symptoms from the affected countries. Health facilities are invited to make all arrangements for the detection and treatment of any eventual cases."    https://web.archive.org/save/https://sante.gov.gn/communique-du-gouvernement-sur-lepidemie-de-coronavirus-declaree-par-la-chine/
notes_C7: Movement around the country is restricted and a negative COVID test certificate within 14 days of travel outside of Conakry is required.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201201011605/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/guinea/coronavirus
notes_C8: Note: All arriving passengers are not required to quarantine - only those with symptoms or who test positive for COVID-19 will be sent to a designated treatment centre until two negative tests are completed. See: https://gn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ [web archive unavailable, last updated 4th January 2021]
notes_C4: According to the UK government's website on travel to Guinea, there is a limit of 100 people assembling for marriage, baptism and funeral services in Conakry. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210111063708/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/guinea/coronavirus
notes_C1: Schools have reopened (see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201216105634/https://gn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/) with increased sanitation measures as indicated by the previous note.
notes_H6: It seems like this should be coded as 3G since  the directive is that "masks must always be worn in public spaces." See: https://gn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ [web archive unavailable, last updated 4th January 2021]
notes_C2: Economic activity should have resumed on 22 Sep according to the IMF:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201014021405/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E2: Previous policies have not been renewed
notes_E1: Previous policies have not been renewed
notes_C3: Demonstrations are cancelled, but other events that favour the presidency aren't (see C4)
notes_C6: Curfew still in place; not eased until July 15    https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/360596/guinea-authorities-ease-covid-19-restrictions-on-july-15-update-9 [link not archivable]
notes_C5: Public transport (already allowed to resume) can now operate without restrictions   https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/382936/guinea-authorities-announce-easing-of-certain-measures-september-22-update-11 [link not archivable]

name: Gambia
notes_H1: Ministry of Health and State Facebook pages begin sharing information including daily situation reports, WHO prevention information, etc.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200425182545/https://www.facebook.com/WHO/photos/a.167668209945237/2946038618774835/?type=3&theater=
notes_H3: The government claims to be carrying out comprehensive contact tracing, and maps out all transmission and the source of each case in weekly infographics posted on its official twitter page. It's unclear to what extent these 'situational report' graphics represent the completeness of the governments contact tracing efforts, and this doesn't represent a discrete policy change, but there is now _ostensibly_ comprehensive contact tracing being carried out in the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200615182016/https://twitter.com/Presidency_GMB/status/1272594265550524422/
notes_H2: Backcoded  [August 28] to reflect the actual testing policy in the country. Previously coded as 0.     http://web.archive.org/web/20200823135222/https://www.mrc.gm/information-on-COVID-19-testing-at-the-mrc-unit-the-gambia-at-lshtm/
notes_C7: There seem to be no restrictions on internal movement.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200903115325/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: The Gambia reopened its borders on October 16 after a six-month lockdown in light of the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the Gambia's international airport in the capital Banjul will not be fully operational until October 31 because of ongoing reconstruction. Foreign travelers will still be required to show evidence of negative PCR test results conducted not more than 72 hours prior to their arrival. Those with positive test results will be quarantined.  Link: https://archive.vn/1abnh  Link: https://archive.vn/Zj3t3
notes_C4: Due to a surge of over 60% in the last seven days, the Gambia government imposed a 21-day state of emergency and nighttime curfew (10pm-5am), in force from 6 August to 26 August. "The government also closed down all places of worship and schools. Only a select number of establishments are allowed to continue operating. These are: grocery stores, markets, banks and all businesses classified as essential."  The government attributed this surge to "citizens lowering their guard with respect to protective health measures".    However, although two media reported this new measure on 6 August, there is no such announcement on the government website...    http://archive.vn/XlV9N  http://archive.vn/7a571
notes_C1: Schools have been opened with increased hygiene, sanitation and social distancing measures. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210104232335/https://www.rfi.fr/en/africa/20201025-gambia-parents-raise-safety-concerns-amid-schools-reopening-during-the-covid-19-pandemic
notes_H6: Face masks become mandatory in public spaces.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200903121126/https://www.worldaware.com/covid-19-alert-gambia-makes-wearing-face-masks-public-mandatory-july-24
notes_C2: The Gambian government has lifted COVID-related restrictions, allowing businesses, markets, schools, restaurants, bars, gyms, cinemas, and night clubs to resume normal operations.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/?_ga=2.222803228.685612913.1606144271-1301692634.1606144271
notes_E1: No indication that the measures were extended. According to the WFP, the cash transfers ended in October - "Each household received D1,500 per month (USD $30) for a period of two months; October and November 2020." See https://web.archive.org/web/20210104233058/https://gambia.un.org/en/104227-wfp-supports-hardest-hit-covid-19-cash; see also https://web.archive.org/web/20210104101126/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Due to a surge of over 60% in the last seven days, the Gambia government imposed a 21-day state of emergency and nighttime curfew (10pm-5am), in force from 6 August to 26 August. "The government also closed down all places of worship and schools. Only a select number of establishments are allowed to continue operating. These are: grocery stores, markets, banks and all businesses classified as essential."  The government attributed this surge to "citizens lowering their guard with respect to protective health measures".    However, although two media reported this new measure on 6 August, there is no such announcement on the government website...    http://archive.vn/XlV9N  http://archive.vn/7a571
notes_C6: The Gambian government has lifted COVID-related restrictions, allowing businesses, markets, schools, restaurants, bars, gyms, cinemas, and night clubs to resume normal operations.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/?_ga=2.222803228.685612913.1606144271-1301692634.1606144271
notes_C5: According to the US Embassy in Gambia, public transport is open with social distancing measures. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210111053656/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

name: Greece
notes_H1: First Public Info Video uploaded to government.gov.gr by Ministry of Health (Simple and Useful Instructions for protecting us from Coronavirus)  https://web.archive.org/web/20200504102900/https://government.gov.gr/aples-ke-chrisimes-odigies-gia-tin-prostasia-mas-apo-ton-koronoio/
notes_H3: The first COVID-19 case was diagnosed in Greece on February 26th. Contact tracing was initiated on the first and all subsequent confirmed cases, with all contacts being tested and isolated. See: https://web.archive.org/save/https://eody.gov.gr/en/current-state-of-covid-19-outbreak-in-greece-and-timeline-of-key-containment-events/
notes_H2: COVID-19 tests are available at many major hospitals in Greece, as well as the Athens Eleftherios Venizelos Airport (at Arrivals level between entrances 2-3). Testing is paid by the individual being tested.  The average cost for COVID-19 testing is 100-120 euros. Patients needing COVID-19 tests or exhibiting possible symptoms may contact the COVID-19 hotline at 1135 for guidance on testing and referral for medical care.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: Hyper-local movements between Regional Units are prohibited, with the exception of:    health reasons  professional reasons  return to permanent residence  family reunification    https://web.archive.org/web/20201108174954/https://covid19.gov.gr/covid-map
notes_C8: Greek borders open some to international (EU and select other countries) visitors, but with screening - explicit ban on visitors from Sweden and United Kingdom   http://archive.vn/0w86H
notes_C4: private gatherings are also cancelled  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108174954/https://covid19.gov.gr/covid-map
notes_C1: from Monday 11 January 2021 at 6:00 to Monday 18 January 2021  "Suspension of the lifelong educational function of gymnasiums, general and vocational schools and all types of educational structures including nurseries, language centres, education and skills certification providers, foreign-language education institutes and all related structures    Conducting modern distance teaching in Secondary Education"    https://web.archive.org/web/20210117184346/https://covid19.gov.gr/leitourgia-scholeion-kai-pasis-fysis-ekpaideftikon-domon-aei-kai-choron-latreias-gia-to-diastima-apo-ti-deftera-11-ianouariou-2021-kai-ora-600-eos-kai-ti-deftera-18-ianouariou-2021-kai-ora-600/
notes_H6: new lockdown measures country wide  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108174954/https://covid19.gov.gr/covid-map
notes_C2: Some non-essential sectors remain open during the current lockdown, which is in effect until 14 December 2020 nationwide.    Seasonal shops, selling only Christmas items, reopened on Monday 7 December for a few days. By the end of the week, the government will make further decisions on the operation of churches, hair salons and the retail sector, Petsas said.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201209185340if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSKBN28H1GL
notes_E2: "State contribution for the repayment of loans with collateral in the main residence for borrowers who have been affected by the adverse effects of the coronavirus" implemented from August 4, 2020.   The State contributes to the repayment of all types of loans of private or legal entities to financial institutions, for up to 9 months. People who have been proven to be affected by the COVID-19 coronavirus pandemic are eligible, as well as their spouses and dependents. https://web.archive.org/web/20200808152748/https://covid19.gov.gr/synisfora-dimosiou-gia-tin-apopliromi-danion-me-ebragmates-exasfalisis-stin-kyria-katikia-gia-danioliptes-pou-echoun-pligi-apo-tis-dysmenis-synepies-tou-koronoiou/
notes_E1: In addition to prior support through the indemnity and focused income support, from 1 June until at least 30 September, the Greek government provides 60% income support through the COOPERATION program funded by European SURE initiative in the formal sector.  "The state undertakes the obligation of replacement by 60% of the employee's income for the time that the employee will not work. In addition, in the event that the net remuneration after the above adjustment falls short of the minimum wage, the difference will be fully covered by the state."  http://archive.fo/9J9Qv
notes_C3: public events are cancelled  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108174954/https://covid19.gov.gr/covid-map
notes_C6: curfew in place  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108174954/https://covid19.gov.gr/covid-map
notes_C5: restriction rules now are country-wide  "Authorities have set a maximum 65 percent capacity on public transport over the three-week lockdown in order to curb the spread of the coronavirus, while taxis are only allowed to carry one passenger."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201115183238/https://www.ekathimerini.com/258933/article/ekathimerini/news/transport-rules-during-lockdown
notes_H7: Greece kicked off COVID-19 vaccinations among the elderly on Saturday, after first inoculating tens of thousands of frontline workers to fight the spread of the coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117190824/https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-01-16/greece-starts-covid-19-vaccinations-among-the-elderly    Vaccinations can be booked online as explained here but it is not clear when vaccinations will start for the general public:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210117190155/https://covid19.gov.gr/leitourgia-tou-systimatos-kai-tis-platformas-diacheirisis-synedrion-emvoliasmou-kata-tou-koronoiou-sars-cov2/

name: Greenland
notes_H1: Translated from Danish:   'On Thursday, the first SMS will be sent from the three authorities who jointly control the efforts to prevent the spread of infection - namely the Naalakkersuisut, the National Medical Association and the Greenland Police.    The SMS will encourage you to follow our advice - keep your distance and wash your hands frequently - because it slows down the spread of infection.'    https://web.archive.org/web/20200506123325/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/2603_sms
notes_H3: Complete contact tracing done for confirmed cases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200803163259/https://arctic-council.org/en/news/coronavirus-in-the-arctic-it-is-imperative-to-keep-the-virus-out/
notes_H2: Policy remains unchanged. Test available to anyone with symptoms.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221152615/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/hvem_bliver_testet_for_covid_19?sc_lang=da
notes_C7: The government's 'Entry to Greenland' page archived on August 10th was "updated on the 21st of July", which is the date the "Self-Government Executive Order no. 26 of 20 July 2020 on conditions for entry to Greenland (Phase 2)" came into effect.   The code has changed from 1G to 0 on July 21st because there are no further restrictions, required or recommended, on internal movement, for those who aren't recent entrants to Greenland.  However, the Executive Order describes required quarantine upon arrival into Greenland and related restrictions on internal movement "before it is considered proven that they [entrants to Greenland] are not infected with Covid-19". This movement restriction is specifically an international travel policy and therefore accounted for under international travel restrictions. C8-2 shows there is a quarantine policy in place.  "Your trip depends on your final destination   If you have passed a negative COVID-19 test before departure and filled in the SUMUT form, you can travel to the following cities without further restrictions.   The 10 towns and two villages are:   Municipality of Sermersooq   - Nuuk   - Paamiut   Qeqqata Municipality   - Sisimiut   - Maniitsoq   - Kangerlussuaq   Municipality Kujalleq   - Qaqortoq   - Narsaq   - Narsarsuaq   Municipality Qeqertalik   - Aasiaat   - Qasigiannguit   - Qeqertarsuaq   Avannaata Municipality   - Ilulissat   If your final destination is not figuerer above list you   Stay in the city with health center that is closest to your final destination.   If you have a home address in Greenland, you can contact the authorities regarding accommodation facilities for test results.   If you do not have an address in your final destination, you must maintain the expenses that may be associated with overnight stays, rebookings, board and lodging.   Contact your local health center and order a COVID-19 test to be performed at 5 p.m.   In the event of a negative test result, you can travel on to your final destination.   3. In the event of a positive result, you must go directly into isolation. The health center will contact the National Board of Health for further clarification of your situation."   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200810150502/https://nun.gl/Emner/Borgere/Coronavirus_emne/Rejser_til_Groenland_fra_den_15_juni?sc_lang=da  (Entry to Greenland page) & http://web.archive.org/web/20201110102927/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/~/media/Nanoq/Files/Kundgoerelser/DK/2020/Bekendtgoerelser/Selvstyrets%20bekendtgrelse%20nr%2026%20af%2020%20juli%202020%20om%20betingelser%20for%20indrejse%20til%20Grnland%20Fase%202%20da.pdf (Executive Order)
notes_C8: Updated restrictions to forbid travel to/from Denmark as well as all other regions. 'Based on the health professional recommendations and forecasts for potential spread of infection in society, the Naalakkersuisut has actively looked at reducing the number of travellers over Christmas and the New Year... The departures to and from Denmark on 21 and 22 December will be canceled as well as associated domestic connections.' Possibly extended until January 17th.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221143722/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/12/0212_lukning_aflysning
notes_C4: Naalakkersuisoq Karl Frederik Danielsen announced that from 25 April at 8 am, 'Recommendation for meetings of a maximum of 100 persons'    https://web.archive.org/web/20200506142525/https://www.nun.gl/Nyheder_COVID19/2020/04/2204_Groenland_aabner_op_i_to_faser?sc_lang=da
notes_C1: Office of Medical Officer of Health maintains that schools are open across the country with safety measures in place (since an executive order was issued on 29 May) - website updated 11 June)  "Teaching is normal for primary schools throughout the country and in all the country's educational institutions under special instruction that takes into account:  as much space as possible around the pupils / students; Among other things, by utilizing all the school institution's areas, maximum utilization of the school day, etc.  that all advice on hygiene is observed as far as possible: physical distance, hand hygiene, hand alcohol.  that canteen - restaurant meets the requirements of shops"  http://archive.fo/tkZEq
notes_H6: In Greenland, you are required to wear a bandage(mask) in the following situations:    1. For international and domestic flights.  This applies to everyone over the age of 12 as well as the cabin crew, with a few exceptions when on the plane, staying at airports or terminal areas.  When employed with passenger contact in terminal areas and the like, you must wear a bandage or visor if a plastic screen cannot be set up between employees and travelers. Reference is also made to § 6 and § 7 Self-Government Executive Order no. 37 of 29 September 2020 on conditions for travel to and in Greenland  2. If you are infected or at risk of being infected with a new coronavirus and exceptionally have to move out, eg because you need to be tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201006064205/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/rejser_til_groenland_fra_den_15_juni?sc_lang=da
notes_C2: Workplaces open from April 27th.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200629102515/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/04/2204_genaabning
notes_E1: The Ministry of Business and Labor released “Guidelines of September 2020 establishing detailed criteria for application, award and administration of funds under the labor market package”   “Wage costs must:…B. relate to the period 19 March 2020 - 30 September 2020, both days inclusive.” No policies which have extended the period of wage costs beyond September 30th have been found.  “3. Compensation is limited to salary expenses for the following employees  A. Employees with a permanent connection to the company. Firm affiliation means that there must be an employment contract between employee and company for the company to receive salary compensation for the employee. The agreement must have been entered into before 19 March 2020.  Loose workers are not covered as they do not have a permanent affiliation with the company. Loose workers are characterized by the employment is only very short-lived so that the employment is terminated when e.g. day work is over and the employee is not committed to work the following day. The employment relationship must have one duration exceeding 2 days. The employment must be permanent”  “The compensation is calculated as follows:  A. 90% of the salary expense, however, a maximum of DKK 20,190, per 30 days wage compensation period per. employee.   B. If the wage compensation period is shorter than 30 days, is calculated compensation as a proportionate share rounded to nearest whole day.  C. Deducting any other support from public funds to the applicant concerning the same wage cost.”   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201019212330/https://www.businessingreenland.gl/~/media/Erhverv/COVID-19/30%20september/DK%20Retningslinjer%20vedr%20arbejdsmarkedspakke%20pr%2030%20september%202020.pdf?la=da
notes_C3: Translated:  "It is now possible to hold public events within current municipal boundaries with certain restrictions. It is the organizer's responsibility to ensure that there is no participation from persons from other municipalities or that they are encouraged to do so.  The purpose of the adaptations is to meet the desire for permission to organize events at the same time as the desire to minimize the risk of infection spread, it is stated."    News link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200628151606/https://sermitsiaq.ag/nye-regler-private-offentlige-arrangementer  Official announcement (in Danish):  https://naalakkersuisut.gl/~/media/Nanoq/Files/Kundgoerelser/DK/2020/Bekendtgoerelser/Selvstyrets%20bekendtgrelse%20nr%2021%20af%2019%20juni%202020%20da.pdf
notes_C6: With Greenland opening, only those home-quarantining are asked to remain home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200616031705/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/06/120620-Genaabning-den-15_-juni-fastholdes
notes_C5: As Greenland begins to ease restrictions, public transit resumes. International travel still restricted.   http://archive.vn/wip/jOZwP
notes_H7: Greenland received about 1,000 doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine from Denmark for inoculation in Nuuk and Illulissat. KNR reports that elderly Greenlanders and their caregivers are at the top of the list for priority inoculation.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210111231603/https://www.rcinet.ca/eye-on-the-arctic/2021/01/04/greenland-launches-covid-19-vaccination-campaign-1/

name: Guatemala
notes_H1: On 6 March, Ministry of Education formally presented a COVID-19 informatoin campaign. https://web.archive.org/web/20200520190657/https://www.facebook.com/MineducGuate/posts/3113286355372814    The first video infomercial was posted on social media on 7 March  https://web.archive.org/web/20200520191313/https://www.facebook.com/MineducGuate/posts/3113001608734622  Further, a Presidential Decree formally instituted information campaigns on 16 March. See article 5 (Quinto) https://web.archive.org/web/20200520190730/https://legal.dca.gob.gt/GestionDocumento/VisualizarDocumento?verDocumentoPrevia=True&versionImpresa=False&doc=56869
notes_H3: On 14 Aug the govt announces the introduction of tracers to conduct contact tracing via phone calls:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201005023158/https://www.mspas.gob.gt/noticias/noticias-ultimas/5-noticias-mspas/1012-%C2%BFqu%C3%A9-es-un-rastreador-de-casos-y-contactos-covid-19.html    by 14 Sep the ministry of health counts with 444 tracers in 4 departments: https://web.archive.org/web/20201005023329/https://lahora.gt/salud-hay-444-rastreadores-de-covid-19-en-cuatro-departamentos/
notes_H2: That the IGSS will carry out the diagnostic tests to rule out suspected cases of the COVID-19 disease, these tests will be run only to those people who have symptoms or suspicion of this disease, such as dry cough, fever and difficulty breathing or any link epidemiological.   Source: https://www.mspas.gob.gt/index.php/noticias/comunicados/item/795-el-ministerio-de-salud-publica-y-asistencia-social-mspas-y-el-instituto-guatemalteco-de-seguridad-social-igss-a-la-opinion-publica-informa
notes_C7: On 14 January 2021, Guatemalan President declared a State of Prevention in the departments of Izabal, Zacapa, Chiquimula, Jutiapa, El Progreso, Peten and Santa Rosa, from 14 to 28 January 2021. The declaration seeks to prevent the spread of Coronavirus and to maintain order as the caravans make their way to the United States of America. It prohibits public gatherings, the carrying of weapons and may restrict travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118093136/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/guatemala/coronavirus
notes_C8: All passengers age 10 and over arriving in Guatemala by air and land are required to obtain a negative COVID-19 PCR or an Antigen test within 96 hours prior to arrival, and comply with health screening requirements.  Starting December 23, all persons entering Guatemala who have visited the United Kingdom or South Africa within the past 14 days could be denied entry or be subject to quarantine due to a new variant of COVID-19 found in those countries. Guatemalan nationals, permanent residents, and diplomats with accreditation will be allowed entry, but will be required to quarantine for a minimum of 10 days.  This guidance could change rapidly and additional countries may be added.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210103160841/https://gt.usembassy.gov/alert-covid-19-2/
notes_C4: Although there is no upper limit for some parts of the country, in the red areas it is still not permitted for groups of more than 10 to gather (not even in churches):    https://web.archive.org/web/20201005030303/https://www.mspas.gob.gt/noticias/noticias-ultimas/5-noticias-mspas/1079-alertas-sanitarias-covid-19-mspas-actualiza-disposiciones-para-establecimientos.html
notes_C1: On Jan 4th, the status of education of Guatemala was changed to partly open according to UNESCO.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118094407/https://en.unesco.org/sites/default/files/covid_impact_education.csv
notes_H6: Masks are required in all public spaces starting on April 8: https://web.archive.org/web/20201005031448/https://www.prensalibre.com/guatemala/politica/guatemala-hace-obligatorio-el-uso-de-mascarillas-para-prevenir-contagios-de-coronavirus-ultima-hora/    As of 5 Oct they are still obligatory (although de facto this is probably more relaxed as businesses such as bars and restaurants reopened on 1 Oct): https://web.archive.org/web/20201005031830/https://www.prensalibre.com/guatemala/comunitario/el-uso-de-mascarilla-y-el-distanciamiento-social-siguen-siendo-obligatorias-en-guatemala-segun-nuevas-disposiciones-breaking/
notes_C2: All sorts of businesses can now reopen following the restrictions that vary according to the risk level of the municipality:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201005030303/https://www.mspas.gob.gt/noticias/noticias-ultimas/5-noticias-mspas/1079-alertas-sanitarias-covid-19-mspas-actualiza-disposiciones-para-establecimientos.html
notes_E2: The government deferred income taxes for a quarter and further subsidized electricity  https://www.prensalibre.com/guatemala/politica/cuales-son-los-programas-del-gobierno-por-la-crisis-del-coronavirus-en-guatemala-y-a-quienes-beneficiara/  https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: On 14 January 2021, Guatemalan President declared a State of Prevention in the departments of Izabal, Zacapa, Chiquimula, Jutiapa, El Progreso, Peten and Santa Rosa, from 14 to 28 January 2021.
