name: Lesotho
notes_H1: ‘Manthabiseng National Convention Centre has been identified as designated National Command Centre for Coronavirus (COVID-19). All the information about COVID-19 will be coordinated and accessed from this centre so that the public can be only provided with credible information. Meanwhile, a budget of M60 million targeting information dissemination and human resource emprovement amongst others has also been proposed in this regard and it emerged during this meeting  https://web.archive.org/web/20200506104855/https://www.gov.ls/lesotho-government-identifies-national-command-centre-for-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20200506103816/https://www.gov.ls/about-coronavirus-covid-19/
notes_H3: contact tracing reported to be taking place. https://web.archive.org/web/20200511223121/https://www.iol.co.za/news/africa/still-no-covid-19-in-lesotho-after-48-suspected-cases-test-negative-47827604
notes_H2: Any health personnel who has been exposed to a confirmed case of Covid-19 shall be subjected to testing and self-isolation https://web.archive.org/web/20200615181342/https://www.gov.ls/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/PUBLIC-HEALTH-COVID-19-REGULATIONS-PDF.pdf A person allowed to enter the country during the period of lockdown shall be subject to screening at the designated point of entry, screening shall be done on people who travelled to affected countries.
notes_C7: Is a curfew in place?   Yes Under Alert Level 3, the curfew will apply from 1900 until 0600 daily.  Are there restrictions on travel between districts? Yes  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117190929/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/
notes_C8: No movement across borders except for essential goods and services, diplomats, funerals, migrant workers, students, medical reasons. Approved COVID-19 testing of commercial drivers and other persons at all ports of entry. Foreign persons testing positive denied entry. Lesotho citizens testing positive to be quarantined. Daily commuting workers denied entry.     See the prime minister's announcement of Lesotho moving to a more stringent "orange stage" on 6 January 2021 (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-070838/https://www.gov.ls/lesotho-moves-back-to-orange-colour/).  See also NACOSEC twitter communications (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-071252/https://twitter.com/nacosec?lang=en).
notes_C4: All social and family gatherings restricted.     See the prime minister's announcement of Lesotho moving to a more stringent "orange stage" on 6 January 2021 (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-070838/https://www.gov.ls/lesotho-moves-back-to-orange-colour/).  See also NACOSEC twitter communications (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-071252/https://twitter.com/nacosec?lang=en).
notes_C1: Schools closed immediately after announcing on 4 January 2021 that they would be re-opening.     See the prime minister's announcement of Lesotho moving to a more stringent "orange stage" on 6 January 2021 (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-070838/https://www.gov.ls/lesotho-moves-back-to-orange-colour/).
notes_H6: Not sure why this might be coded as 1G. according to the UK FCO website for Lesotho, anyone leaving their place of residence in Lesotho must wear a mask or face covering. This includes in public and private vehicles, walking in the street, and in shops and public offices. See https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus. Also, from the IMF policy response website, see: https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 (web archive unavailable, accessed 21 September 2020)
notes_C2: Entertainment industry required to close. Textile and Manufacturing Industries at 50% capacity with day and night shifts. Restaurants to operate with takeaways only. Essential stores like supermarkets to close at 6PM, with social distancing and sanitary requirements in place.     See the prime minister's announcement of Lesotho moving to a more stringent "orange stage" on 6 January 2021 (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-070838/https://www.gov.ls/lesotho-moves-back-to-orange-colour/).  See also NACOSEC twitter communications (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-071252/https://twitter.com/nacosec?lang=en).
notes_E2: No debt relief noted on government sites or IMF. Government funding focuses on health and prevention.  Government looking for private sector to help with relief.  "The IMF reports that the Governments has funded their current COVID response from the existing health care budget, and has been focused on  health care and prevention. The  Government has also called for private sector support, and Banking Sector in the country has contributed M2 million towards the National Response to Coronavirus (COVID-19). As of the 4th of April there are no fiscal policy measures. However, the Central Bank of Lesotho (CBL) announced it will (1) increase of the NIR target floor from US$630 million to US$660 million, and (ii) reduce the CBL rate by 100 basis points from 6.25 per cent to 5.25 per cent  per annum. "  https://web.archive.org/web/20201023140517/https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1s46Oz_NtkyrowAracg9FTPYRdkP8GHRzQqM7w6Qa_2k/edit?ts=5e836726
notes_C3: All public events cancelled. Exceptions made for church services, with a maximum of 50 people inside and 100 people outside and mask-wearing requirements.    See the prime minister's announcement of Lesotho moving to a more stringent "orange stage" on 6 January 2021 (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-070838/https://www.gov.ls/lesotho-moves-back-to-orange-colour/).  See also NACOSEC twitter communications (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-071252/https://twitter.com/nacosec?lang=en).
notes_C6: Curfew from 8PM to 5AM.    See the prime minister's announcement of Lesotho moving to a more stringent "orange stage" on 6 January 2021 (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-070838/https://www.gov.ls/lesotho-moves-back-to-orange-colour/).  See also NACOSEC twitter communications (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-071252/https://twitter.com/nacosec?lang=en).
notes_C5: "...Minibuses, taxis, and bus services are operating at reduced levels subject to social distancing and mandatory use of face masks for passengers and drivers..."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117190929/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/

name: Lithuania
notes_H1: On 1 June, a nationwide campaign ‘Thank You, Lithuania’ to take place to show gratitude to the Lithuanian people for the successful efforts in overcoming the first wave of COVID-19 and to ask them to continue staying focused and hopeful, so as to be ready to confront any other challenges lying do it again.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200611135425/http://lrv.lt/en/news/thank-you-lithuania-campaign-in-honour-of-all-those-who-have-helped-to-overcome-first-wave-of-coronavirus    Moreover, the government is publishing extensive information about the virus and implemented measures via a special website, set-up only for topics of the pandemic:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125101901/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/
notes_H3: Currently, the contact tracing system in Lithuania is overwhelmed. On 3rd December, newly elected Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte told that NVSC failed to do contact tracing for all positve cases. Moreover, the newly elected Minister of Health Arunas Dulkys on 12th December told that the priority at the time was that NVSC could complete contact tracing for all cases within 48 hours after positive test result, indicating that it is not currently done.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201212143139/https://www.lrt.lt/naujienos/lietuvoje/2/1290792/simonyte-kritikuoja-nvsc-del-nepasiruosimo-vasara-jei-istinka-koma-nuo-200-nauju-atveju-akivaizdu-kazkas-neveikia  https://web.archive.org/web/20201212143341/https://www.lrt.lt/naujienos/lietuvoje/2/1296629/dulkys-tikina-kaledoms-atsipalaiduoti-negalima-nereiketu-del-to-apgaudineti-saves
notes_H2: The Health Ministry said that all people experiencing cold-like symptoms associated with the coronavirus could now be tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200527113044/https://www.lrt.lt/en/news-in-english/19/1156515/when-to-get-tested-for-covid-19-new-rules-in-lithuania-explained
notes_C7: Travelling between municipalities is restricted.    Except:    -to go to/from airports, seaports, bus stations serving international passenger routes;  -to go to the municipality where you live;  -for the death of close relatives;  -to do work, where the place of employment is in another municipality;  -for health care services;  -for other objectively justified reasons of urgency, where travelling to a municipality other than -the place of residence is absolutely necessary.    -This restriction does not apply to members of one family and/or household travelling to a municipality other than the place of their residence where they have real estate property that is owned by a member of that family and/or household.    https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021
notes_C8: People returning / arriving from affected countries are subjects to 10-day isolation. Isolation does not apply to those who have a negative test for COVID-19 performed not earlier than 48 hours ago.    You can also be tested in Lithuania. In this case, isolation applies to you until a negative laboratory test is obtained.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107143201/https://nvsc.lrv.lt/en/information-on-covid-19/for-arrivals-from-abroad
notes_C4: Lithuania’s government on Wednesday declared a three-week lockdown starting on Nov.7 (extended end of November), to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus which has accelerated in recent weeks in the Baltic nation.    Public groups of more than 5 people will be banned and no more than 10 people will be allowed at marriages or funerals.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201114114424/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-lithuania/update-1-lithuania-to-enter-three-week-covid-lockdown-on-saturday-idINL8N2HQ525    See also for official communication:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202092539/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-25-november-2020
notes_C1: Restrictions remain in place (until 31st January)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124173336/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1
notes_H6: rotective face masks are mandatory in all public places (for all from the age of 6). Exceptions apply in the case of:     -exercising individuals;  -professionals of high-performance sports and physical activity participating in high-performance sports training and -competitions, high-performance sports and physical activity instructors and referees;  -during the provision of a service where a service cannot be provided when a customer is wearing a mask;  -persons with disability who cannot wear a mask due to their health condition or where it can adversely affect their health condition. They are recommended to wear a face shield instead.  -when outside populated areas (cities, towns, villages, single-homestead settlements and dacha (garden) settlements) and -when there are no other people within the radius of 20 metres, except for family members.   -children over the age of 6 who are educated under pre-school, pre-primary and primary education programmes will not be required to wear protective equipment covering nose and mouth (face masks, respirators or other equipment) while in -education establishments and/or their territories.       -A face mask must be worn in common areas of accommodation.    -It is recommended to wear a face mask at a private party, if held, or when socialising with members of other families / households.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201202092539/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-25-november-2020
notes_C2: Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    State and municipal institutions and bodies and state and municipal enterprises and the private sector will organise work and provide customer services remotely, except where relevant functions (work) have to be performed at the workplace, while ensuring conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for the management of the flow of people, safe physical distance, and other key requirements for public health safety, hygiene, and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment    Stores, including those in shopping and/or entertainment centres, marketplaces and other public points of sale will be closed except:    -stores (including those in shopping and/or entertainment centres), whose main business is the retail of food, veterinary, animal feed, pharmacy, optical goods and orthopedic technical devices;  -selling food in marketplaces and public points of sale;  -remote commerce (by internet or other means of communication), where goods are delivered to natural and legal persons or collected at collection points;  -funeral stores;  -outdoor trade in Christmas trees and other festive trees.    Stores that remain open will be required to:    ensure 15 sq. m. of retail space per visitor or serve only one visitor at a time and ensure other conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020
notes_E2: Variety of measures implemented.  Among others:    • To extend the deferral period for payments of residential loans (excluding interest) from 3 to 6 months in the form of a state guarantee for those who have lost their jobs.    • Make it possible to defer the contributions or pay them by installments for electricity and natural gas to AB Ignitis.    • Recommend that municipalities should offer a possibility to defer public utility payments and payments for heat energy or pay them by installments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107145102/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-1
notes_E1: When an emergency situation or quarantine is declared, remote work is not always possible, so in complicated situations employers may announce downtime or partial downtime, and the State is ready to contribute to the payment of wages to employees.    When an enterprise declares inactivity due to an emergency or quarantine, the worker shall receive at least the minimum monthly salary and shall not be required to arrive to work. Currently, the minimum monthly salary makes EUR 607 gross or EUR 437 net.    An allowance of a fixed amount will be paid from the Guarantee Fund to self-employed individuals who have paid social security contributions for at least 3 months during the last year period prior to the declaration of the emergency or quarantine.    State support in cases of downtimes and partial downtimes. The employee allowance shall be not less than the minimum monthly salary.    • Sickness benefits for carers of children and persons with disabilities during quarantine in educational establishments or in social care and employment centres.    • To pay EUR 257/month to self-employed residents who have paid social security contributions when quarantine prevents them from carrying out their activities.
notes_C3: source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201101210959/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-28-october-2020  From 30 October to 13 November 2020, there shall be no events and gatherings held indoor and outdoor in public places, except: high-performance sporting and cultural events (with several crowd restrictions described below); funerals.    crowd restrictions:  * they are held indoors with maximum 300 spectators;    * spectators watch an event seated at a 2 m distance from each other except for family members;   * spectators wear protective equipment covering nose and mouth (face masks, respirators or other equipment) during the entire event (the requirement to wear protective equipment covering nose and mouth (face masks, respirators or other equipment) will not be applicable to persons with disability who cannot wear a mask or where wearing it may adversely affect their health condition; they are recommended to wear a face shield instead);    * electronic distribution of tickets and/or registration of spectators and/or participants, as well as control of the access of spectators and/or participants to the venue is ensured;   * they are held outdoors with maximum 400 spectators provided the conditions referred to above are met:;   events are organised and held where the organisers of an event can ensure electronic distribution of tickets and/or registration of spectators and/or participants and control the access of spectators and/or participants to the venue of the event;
notes_C6: Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    It is required to stay at home except:    -to go to work (for work purposes);  -to go shopping;  -to go to/from airports, seaports, bus stations serving international passenger routes;  -to go to your real estate property;  -to go to a funeral;  -for health and other essential services;  -for other essential services or for objectively justified reasons where it is absolutely necessary;  -to go for a walk in open spaces only with members of your family or household;  -to attend to the sick or to those unable to take care of themselves.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020
notes_C5: Lithuania’s government on Wednesday declared a three-week lockdown starting on Nov.7 (extended end of November), to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus which has accelerated in recent weeks in the Baltic nation.    "Passengers travelling by public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) will be required to travel seated maintaining the distance of at least one meter between each other."    No other measures to be found on the official websites of the government which is why I keep the level at 0    https://web.archive.org/web/20201202092539/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-25-november-2020
notes_H7: A, B:     The first doses of the vaccine will be given for the medical staff working in the COVID-19 wards, emergency departments, and those at high risk for COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107161149/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/lithuanian-healthcare-workers-start-getting-the-covid-19-vaccine

name: Luxembourg
notes_H1: Opening of a dedicated Site for information relating to COVID and the states response. Mentioned initially in a facebook post on the 28th of February. Site seems to have gone online on 5th of February. www.gouvernement.lu/coronavirus was the initial site, moving to covid19.lu on the 23rd of March.      https://www.infocrise.lu/fr/web/guest/accueil/-/asset_publisher/uJAlpeXURbmf/content/toutes-les-informations-officielles-et-utiles-regroupe-sur-covid19-lu?inheritRedirect=false&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.infocrise.lu%2Ffr%2Fweb%2Fguest%2Faccueil%3Fp_p_id%3D101_INSTANCE_uJAlpeXURbmf%26p_p_lifecycle%3D0%26p_p_state%3Dnormal%26p_p_mode%3Dview%26p_p_col_id%3Dcolumn-1%26p_p_col_count%3D1%23article_78291#p_101_INSTANCE_uJAlpeXURbmf
notes_H3: First case of COVID on March 1st has been reported and the a team of sanitary inspectors have "retracer son entourage", traced whom he has been in contact with. https://web.archive.org/save/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/en/communications-officielles.gouvernement%2Ben%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2020%2B03-mars%2B01-premier-cas-corona.html
notes_H2: https://gouvernement.lu/en/actualites/toutes_actualites/communiques/2020/04-avril/28-strategie-deconfinement-sante-recherche.html:  "Due to the size of Luxembourg and its limited number of residents, we have a great opportunity: we can test the entire population for the novel coronavirus within a short period of time. This makes us the first country in the world to have a complete overview of the number of infected citizens," said Minister of Higher Education and Research, Claude Meisch.
notes_C7: It is prohibited to circulate in public between 23h00 and 6h00.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130202547/https://covid19.public.lu/dam-assets/covid-19/toolbox/nouvelles-mesures/affiche/11-26/201124-santelu-mesures-affiche-a4-EN.pdf
notes_C8: It should be noted that from 1 January 2021, these restrictions also apply to third-country nationals residing in the United Kingdom, including UK nationals who do not fall under the provisions of the Withdrawal Agreement (see FAQs).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103224749/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html
notes_C4: indoors and outdoors  › 5-10 pers: mask + distance 2m  › 11 -100 pers: mask + distance 2m + seating place    https://web.archive.org/web/20210119032645/https://covid19.public.lu/dam-assets/covid-19/toolbox/nouvelles-mesures/affiche/11-01-2021/10206-DISA-Cov19-Mesures-Jan21-A4-EN.pdf
notes_C1: Gradual re-opening of classes. Exams can be taken in person at school again.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201231123326/https://gouvernement.lu/fr/actualites/toutes_actualites/articles/2020/12-decembre/23-covid-enseignement.html
notes_H6: - in all circumstances for activities open to the public that are circulating and which are taking place in a closed place (e.g. in administrations open to the public, shops and supermarkets), as well as on public transport.  - for any gathering of people that brings together more than 4 people at the same time, either in a closed area or in the open air.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210105163404/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/protective-measures.html
notes_C2: From 26 Nov, establishments serving food and drinks are closed to the public. Any commercial operation with a sales area = 400 m2 is subject to a limitation of 1 customer per 10 m2.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201130202547/https://covid19.public.lu/dam-assets/covid-19/toolbox/nouvelles-mesures/affiche/11-26/201124-santelu-mesures-affiche-a4-EN.pdf
notes_E2: With regard to direct taxes, the modalities of the advance tax payments and payment deadlines will be adapted for corporations and self-employed persons. More specifically, legal persons and natural persons carrying out an activity generating trade and business income, agriculture and forestry income, or income from independent professional services, who are experiencing liquidity problems due to the Covid-19 pandemic, can apply for a cancellation of the two first quarterly advance tax payments of the year 2020 (due in March and June 2020). Covered by this measure are (corporate) income and municipal business taxes.    In addition, these same persons may request, for taxes due after 29 February 2020, a payment extension of four months. On this deferral, no interest on late payment will be due and it covers (corporate) income, municipal business, and net wealth taxes.  https://mfin.gouvernement.lu/en/actualites.gouvernement%2Ben%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2020%2B03-mars%2B17-mesures-fiscales-covid19.html
notes_E1: No policy change.     More details here:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130210640/https://meco.gouvernement.lu/dam-assets/dossiers/Neistart-Letzebuerg-Tableau-Mesures.pdf
notes_C3: Re-opening of sports, culture & cults under strict sanitary conditions. Bars and restaurants   remain closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210119032645/https://covid19.public.lu/dam-assets/covid-19/toolbox/nouvelles-mesures/affiche/11-01-2021/10206-DISA-Cov19-Mesures-Jan21-A4-EN.pdf
notes_C6: no policy change.
notes_C5: Public transport in Luxembourg is open with sanitary measures in place such as wearing a mask at all times and keeping a distance from other users.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201212185644/https://transports.public.lu/fr/actualites/2020/03-mars-covid-19-transports-modifications-mesures-coronavirus.html
notes_H7: Group A. As of January 15, 3,233 people have received a vaccination in the Grand Duchy, with more than 1,200 of those getting their first injection in the last three days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118190732/https://luxtimes.lu/luxembourg/42782-more-people-to-get-vaccine-as-moderna-shots-arrive

name: Latvia
notes_H1: 2 websites are dedicated to Covid-19: the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and covid19.org.lv, both of which provide sufficient information on various aspects of the pandemic.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200608214453/https://spkc.gov.lv/en/for-general-public/covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20200617213719/https://covid19.gov.lv/index.php/en
notes_H3: There is a voluntary contact tracing app available, however its not mandatory to use.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201014154613/https://www.baltictimes.com/around_40_000_people_have_downloaded_latvia_s_covid-19_contact_tracing_app/
notes_H2: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/latvia/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5%20Testing&Type=Section
notes_C8: It is allowed to enter Latvia, provided that the guidelines developed by the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (SPKC) are being followed. When arriving from countries with a 14-day cumulative number of COVID-19 cases that is higher than 50 per 100,000 inhabitants, self-isolation must be observed for 10 days.  10-day self-isolation must be observed when entering Latvia from the countries listed in the “National COVID-19 morbidity rates” section of the SPKC website.  If a person is arriving from a “safe” country by transiting through an “unsafe country”, the person must observe self-isolation; in order to avoid self-isolation, a different return route must be chosen.  Self-isolation means staying in the place of self-isolation without exposing other persons to the risk of infection and without making direct contact with others (not receiving guests, not visiting anyone, not going to work or public places where many people may be present, except for going to the shop or getting to the place of residence or of self-isolation immediately after arriving in Latvia, using a mouth and nose covering).  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207042737/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions-and-answers
notes_C4: From 24 October, private event venues may have a maximum of 10 people indoors and 100 people outdoors . If a private event is held in a public place, such as a restaurant, rented sauna, club, etc., then guests must be provided with fixed, personalized seating, 2 meters distance (except for persons from one household), as well as the event can take place until 24.00;    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026220648/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/nosaka-stingrakus-pulcesanas-un-citus-drosibas-pasakumus
notes_C1: Ministry of Health  Similarly, in order to reduce the spread of the virus and it would be time for epidemiologists to observe fluctuations in the number of infections, the government decided that pupils in grades 7-12 would learn remotely.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/uz-laiku-jaierobezo-cilveku-kustiba-arpus-katra-sociala-burbula
notes_H6: - From 24 October mouth and nose covering should be worn in any public place.  - Mouth and nose covering should be used during indoor cultural events. The covering can not be removed if you are sitting in a fixed, personalized seat at a cultural event.   - A homemade mask should be made of at least three layers of suitable material (cotton, nylon, etc.) and have ties to secure it behind the ears or behind the head  - May not be used for children under 13 years of age and people who cannot use it for medical reasons, such as functional impairment    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures
notes_C2: On 17 December, the The Cabinet of Ministers decided to make amendments to Cabinet of Ministers Order No. 655 "Regarding Declaration of the Emergency Situation", strengthening safety measures from 19 December to 11 January.    From 19 December to 11 January, the rules that were until now applied to holidays and public holidays will apply on a daily basis, but the product groups that may be sold during this period will be expanded. This means that during these 3 weeks only the following shall operate: pharmacies (including veterinary pharmacies), optical goods stores, fuel stations,  points of sale where essential goods are sold (groceries, PPE, hygiene products etc.).  At the same time, the requirements for points of sale have been reinforced: at least 15 m2 of the available space will have to be provided for one visitor (excluding the area occupied by shelves, equipment, etc.), the number of visitors cannot exceed the number of available trolleys/carts, and visitors must attend the store alone (it is allowed to bring children under the age of 12 or an assistant if necessary).  On-site services, which can be dispensed with for three weeks, are prohibited, including beauty care, piercing, tattooing, photoshoots, entertainment, and wellness (SPA, saunas, games rooms, etc.).  Libraries, exhibition sites and other cultural venues will not work, and it will also not be allowed to organize fairs (including Christmas markets). Indoor premises of museums will be closed for visitors, but the open-air areas of museums will continue to operate,  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111213254/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/within-three-week-period-movement-people-must-be-significantly-reduced-allowing-us-gift  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111214926/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/during-holiday-season-period-silence-must-be-observed-reducing-contact-and-refraining
notes_E2: Tax relief measures have been extended to all companies regardless of their industry sector, provided they meet certain criteria:    "Turnover in March or April 2020 compared to the respective month in 2019 decreased by 30% or more.  Turnover in March or April 2020 compared to the respective month in 2019 decreased by 20%, if one of the three following requirements is met:   The company’s revenues from export amounted to at least 10% of total turnover in 2019, but not less than EUR 500,000.  Average salary paid in 2019 was at least EUR 800.  Long-term investments in fixed assets as at 31 December 2019 was at least EUR 500,000."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200615205427/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/latvia-tax-developments-in-response-to-covid-19.html
notes_E1: While Covid-19 restrictions continue, the government has decided on support measures to companies suffering from Covid-19. The government has approved the following support measures:    "Self-employed persons who apply the general tax payment regime, persons who receive royalties, who have not registered as performers of economic activities, and sole proprietorships whose economic activity has been suspended as a result of the restrictions, or whose income from economic activity has decreased by at least 20% in comparison to this year’s August, September and October, will be eligible for support in the amount of 75% of the average income from economic activity or royalties during Q3 this year; but not exceeding EUR 1,000."    "Self-employed persons who pay the micro-enterprise tax will be eligible for 50% of monthly average income for Q3 this year. Payers of patent payments will be eligible for support of EUR 330."    "Employees working at companies affected by Covid-19 will be eligible for idle-time payment. This support will be at least EUR 330, but not more than EUR 1,000 a month. In addition to idle-time payment, the employee can receive an extra EUR 50 for each dependent child under 24."    "The regulations state that support as compensation for idle time will be paid to the employee at the amount of 70% of the reported monthly average gross salary from 1 August to 30 October this year or of the reported monthly average gross salary for those months after 1 August when the employee actually worked. An employee of a micro-enterprise taxpayer will be eligible for idle-time payment of 50% of the monthly average gross salary at the micro-enterprise for Q3 2020."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201118091001/https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=293a20d7-ee9e-4c68-8962-4dca8247c181
notes_C3: In view of the epidemiological assessments of the growing risks of spread of the COVID-19 virus, a national state of emergency will be declared in Latvia, to be in effect between 9 November and 6 December.    All in-person public events (such as theatre and music performances) are cancelled and banned. No more than 10 people, and members of no more than two households may participate in private meetings. No more than 50 people may participate in public gatherings, rallies and political demonstrations. Members of more than two households may attend to a funeral, up to a total of 10 people (not including the individuals conducting the funerary proceedings).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113081120/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/state-emergency-be-declared-latvia-9-november
notes_C6: No specific measures implemented. There are currently no plans to restrict daytime movement. The clarifications in the security measures for the holiday season approved by the Cabinet of Ministers do not restrict freedom of movement. Public transport will continue to run and people are encouraged to take the opportunity to spend time outdoors in nature.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111214926/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/during-holiday-season-period-silence-must-be-observed-reducing-contact-and-refraining  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111220036/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/government-conceptually-agrees-new-years-eve-curfew
notes_C5: "Nose and mouth coverings must be used (a self-made or purchased mask, scarf, shawl, and other solutions are accepted). Hygiene measures must be observed." Those who have tested positive for Covid-19 must not use public transport. Neither should those who have been in contact with a Covid-19 positive citizen. https://web.archive.org/web/20200617214914/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures
notes_H7: The first vaccination rooms in Latvia started operating on December 28, 2020. The European Medicines Agency (EMA) and the European Commission (EC) have approved the quality, safety and efficacy of the first two Covid-19 vaccines. These are the vaccine Comirnaty manufactured by Pfizer-BioNTech and the vaccine manufactured by Moderna.      The vaccine will first be given to medical staff working with Covid-19 patients and to the staff of the Emergency Medical Service (EMS). After that, other vaccines will be gradually delivered to Latvia. The first vaccines will be given to healthcare workers working with Covid-19 patients in hospitals and to the Emergency Medical Service.     It is planned that all other residents of Latvia will be able to be vaccinated starting from the second quarter of 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233236/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/vaccine  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233533/https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/kad-vakcinas-bus-pieejamas-latvija

name: Macao
notes_H3: 'In response to the first case of new coronavirus infection in Australia, the SAR government has launched and deployed anti-epidemic work in an all-round way, taking necessary measures including implementing heat detection at ports and filling in entry declaration forms to fully respond to, prevent and control the epidemic.'  https://web.archive.org/web/20200403075243/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AV4AiJe;jsessionid=AE280AF2AFB28803D49190392A304F09.app03?0
notes_H2: Nucleic acid tests are open for online reservation for cross-boundary travellers starting from 10am on 15 July.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201116151921/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20GONHgtC;jsessionid=1B46FD21318D0ECC755125E34F5001FD.app02?0
notes_C8: non-resident workers from Zhuhai eligible for exemption from 14-day Macao medical observation.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200520134950/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20EJuYISW;jsessionid=A369E9ABEE675477120F48351381622C.app02?0
notes_C1: Primary school completely resumes. So far, all schools and universities in Macau have resumed, with social distancing and other public health precautions in place. Kindergarten, which is not part of the K-12, remains suspended.      https://web.archive.org/web/20200520135120/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20EKbDD24;jsessionid=A76EFED4B05FE6FC79888F499FE2EFCC.app01?0
notes_H6: Bus, ferry, taxi passengers must wear facial masks. Visitors to casinos or other entertainment venues must wear facial masks. Source:     http://web.archive.org/web/20200928200710/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hans/global-search/page/4/?q=%E6%88%B4%E5%8F%A3%E7%BD%A9%E6%8C%87%E5%BC%95
notes_C2: public services resume as normal  https://web.archive.org/web/20201118121305/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20Bbsudzy?1
notes_E2: The Government announces subsidy for a period of three months of all electricity and water tariffs for the housing units of Macao residents ; rebate of 70 percent of the personal income tax for the fiscal year 2018 paid by each Macao resident liable for such tax; waiver of waive property tax levied on all housing units of Macao residents for the year 2019. Links: https://web.archive.org/web/20200521223141/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20BMQ4RQa;jsessionid=D8FFCC6F49F88A8F26D204A136AEEE98.app03?0 ; https://web.archive.org/save/http://finance.eastmoney.com/a/202002141383532963.html
notes_E1: Apart from the e-voucher, there is a 600-pataca medical voucher to every permanent resident, extra 1-month's relief to means-tested fragile families. Source:    http://web.archive.org/web/20200928182541/http://www.gov.cn/xinwen/2020-06/24/content_5521649.htm  The Government would allocate an e-voucher – with a value of 3,000 patacas – to each resident. Such e-vouchers would have to be used within a three-month period and would be accepted only in certain restaurants, retail outlets and shopping centres.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200521223141/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20BMQ4RQa;jsessionid=D8FFCC6F49F88A8F26D204A136AEEE98.app03?0.   [second round of income support was announced on 8 April, see below]
notes_C3: The Cultural Affairs Bureau will resume operation of its performance venues from 26 June (Friday) onwards.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201118134442/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20FVolMk4;jsessionid=DFAE36A2FAA3F4D35DF424019F8D34F3.app02?0

name: Morocco
notes_H1: The telephone platform of listening and guidance "Allo 300", set up since March 25, 2020 to provide citizens with advice and information on the new coronavirus (Covid-19), has so far recorded about 38,000 phone calls, for an average of 9,500 calls per day, a military source said on Monday.    Retrieved from: https://web.archive.org/web/20200409102532/http://www.maroc.ma/en/news/covid-19-allo-300-platform-records-nearly-38k-calls-average-9500-calls-day
notes_H3: Morocco launched an app that helps users detect covid-19 exposure and informs them when they get in contact with a positive case.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200601162533/https://northafricapost.com/41348-morocco-starts-using-coronavirus-contact-tracing-app.html
notes_H2: If you are exhibiting signs or symptoms of COVID-19, please contact the Moroccan Ministry of Health’s hotline at +212 (0)8-0100-4747. Assistance is available in English, French or Arabic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201121090354/https://ma.usembassy.gov/25161/
notes_C7: A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Regional or local authorities may put into place (sometimes with little notice) travel or other restrictions aimed at stopping the spread of COVID-19.  Individuals entering or departing from the Casablanca city limits must have a letter of permission issued by Moroccan authorities. In Casablanca, there is an evening curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Those who circulate within Casablanca during these hours must have proper authorization from local authorities.    Is a curfew in place? There is a curfew in Casablanca between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Government reopens borders to 67 visa-exempt countries with some restrictions. Citizens of those countries cleared to travel to Morocco without a visa will be allowed entry, provided that they have an express invitation from a Morocco company or a confirmed hotel reservation.(MSN News, 14.09.2020).    All travellers planning to fly to Morocco must have valid negative Covid-19 test results issued no more than 48 hours before their flight.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200925052707/https://travelbans.org/africa/morocco/
notes_C4: On December 21, the Government of Morocco announced additional restrictions aimed at stopping the spread of COVID-19.  The measures will take effect on Wednesday, December 23 and will remain in place for three weeks. The new measures include the following:  A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am;  A daily closing time for restaurants, cafes, shops, and supermarkets of 8:00 pm;  The closure of all restaurants and cafes in Agadir, Casablanca, Marrakech, and Tangier; and  A ban on all public and private gatherings and parties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Schools are fully open with precautionary measures in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201121082517/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H6: The use of masks is mandatory.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201019012009/https://ma.usembassy.gov/25161/  Also see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201019005808/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/morocco/coronavirus
notes_C2: On December 21, the Government of Morocco announced additional restrictions aimed at stopping the spread of COVID-19.  The measures will take effect on Wednesday, December 23 and will remain in place for three weeks. The new measures include the following:  A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am;  A daily closing time for restaurants, cafes, shops, and supermarkets of 8:00 pm;  The closure of all restaurants and cafes in Agadir, Casablanca, Marrakech, and Tangier; and  A ban on all public and private gatherings and parties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: There is no clear indication that the policy was extended up until now. For example, according to the IMF, " Businesses with less than 500 employees made temporarily idle and experiencing a reduction in turnover of more than 50 percent were authorized to defer social contribution payments until June 30. Their employees who become temporarily unemployed and are registered with the pension fund received 2,000 dirhams a month and were allowed put off debt payments until June 30. In April, almost 1 million workers from 134,000 companies were eligible to these transfers. Companies and households can also defer income tax payment until September 30, 2020. " See: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129161626/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: On March 23, it was announced that: Employees affiliated with the social security system will benefit from a 2000 dirhams monthly allocation (approximately 202 USD). They will also benefit from a suspension of loans and consumption credits reimbursements, until 30 June 2020. With high levels of informality, the Economic Watch Committee decided on 23 March to provide financial relief to informal workers suffering from the economic impact COVID-19.   Workers in the informal sector, starting with households benefiting from the medical assistance  plan RAMED and which no longer have an income due to compulsory confinement, will receive  800 DH per month for households of two people or less; 1,000 DH per month for households  of three to four people; 1,200 DH per month for households of more than four people.  Households without RAMED operating in the informal sector and who have lost their income following compulsory confinement will also benefit from this provision by filling out their requests in an electronic platform dedicated to this purpose.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200507103621/https://www.oecd.org/mena/competitiveness/The-Covid-19-Crisis-in-Morocco.pdf
notes_C3: Morocco's Interior Ministry announced cancellation of all sporting, cultural, and artistic events in the country, until further notice from 14 March https://web.archive.org/web/20200601135438/https://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2020/03/296129/morocco-bans-public-gatherings-of-over-50-people-cancels-all-events/
notes_C6: A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am. . In Casablanca, there is an evening curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Those who circulate within Casablanca during these hours must have proper authorization from local authorities.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: 23 October: Tighter curbs announced for Greater Casablanca, which includes the Casablanca and Mohammadia prefectures and Naouceur and Mediouna provinces, as well as the Berrechid and Benslimane provinces. Measures include the prohibition of all forms of night movement between 9pm and 6am; the closing of community grounds and parks; closing restaurants, cafes, stores and large shopping centres at 8pm; the shutdown of public transportation buses and tramways at 9pm; closing local markets at 3pm; and promoting teleworking when possible.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201029142017/https://www.meed.com/tunisia-pushes-finance-bill-to-cope-with-covid-19

name: Monaco
notes_H1: From 9 am tomorrow, Friday 6 March, the COVID-19 Call Centre, a telephone information service, will take over, staffed by a dedicated team from the Department of Health Affairs (DASA), first aiders from the Monaco Red Cross and a medical supervisor.    Monegasque nationals, residents and employees can contact the centre to discuss any questions they may have about COVID-19 by calling 92 05 55 00. The line will be open every day from 9 am to 6 pm. The centre can also be emailed at the following address: covid19@gouv.mc .    The Prince’s Government would like to remind readers that in the event of any doubt, particularly if you have visited an area where the virus is circulating and have significant symptoms consistent with the disease (fever, cough, breathing difficulties, etc.) you should contact the emergency services directly on 18 or 112.    To avoid infecting others, people with symptoms are asked not to visit their normal doctor.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201203123750/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/CORONAVIRUS-Prince-s-Government-to-expand-COVID-19-telephone-information-service
notes_H3: No information regarding specific contact tracing to be found on the official websites:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_H2: Faced with a resurgence of positive cases of COVID-19, the Government wished to set up a National Screening Centre at the Espace Léo Ferré.    The aim is to regulate and co-ordinate PCR testing in order to optimise the time taken to obtain results.    This centre is open to all Monegasque residents, anyone who has social insurance in Monaco and all schoolchildren in Monaco, with a medical prescription and a prior appointment.    Only people who are symptomatic or are high-risk contacts can be tested there.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115163618/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-tests-diagnostics/
notes_C7: No specific regulation on internal movement found (probably not available due to the small size of Monaco). Visiting second homes in e.g. France is allowed between 6 am and 6 pm, which is why I assume no restrictions on internal movement, too.
notes_C8: Regardless of nationality, anyone who wishes to enter the Principality from either:    -A country outside Europe  -A country within Europe which has recorded more than 60 cases per 100,000 people in 14 days must contact the COVID-19 Call Centre as soon as they arrive in Monaco.    They will be subject to a quarantine imposed by the Director of Health Affairs.    Quarantine can be waived if the person entering the country provides proof of a negative PCR test or, for those who are asymptomatic, proof of a negative antigen test conducted no more than 72 hours before their arrival, in their country of origin.    The quarantine period can be cut short if the person undergoes a PCR test carried out by a medical biology laboratory (Laboratory in the Principality of Monaco or a laboratory. Alternatively, those who are asymptomatic can undergo an antigen test on arrival (carried out by a chemist, doctor or nurse), if negative, this will also cut short the quarantine period. If the antigen test is positive, the individual will need to undergo a PCR test in one of the laboratories referred to above. In the event of a positive PCR test or a refusal to undergo a test, quarantine measures will remain in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201230103235/https://covid19.mc/en/thematiques/transports-et-voyages/
notes_C4: Due to the worldwide COVID-19 epidemic, Monaco has imposed severe restrictions on public life: A curfew has been in effect since Tuesday (17 March). People are only allowed to leave their homes for justified purposes, while restaurants, museums, and non-essential shops are closed throughout the country. Persons entering the country from risk areas must undergo a 14-day domestic quarantine.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201216070845/https://global-monitoring.com/gm/page/events/epidemic-0002086.Eg778z0AGwE9.html?lang=en
notes_C1: " Alesi    On 7 September 2020, Minister of State H.E. Mr Pierre Dartout visited Lycée Albert I upon the return of Year 13 (Terminale) pupils, who will sit the newly reformed General Baccalaureate examinations next June.    H.E. the Minister of State was accompanied by Mr Patrice Cellario, Minister of the Interior, and Ms Isabelle Bonnal, Director of Education, Youth and Sport.    During the early afternoon, H.E. the Minister of State, Mgr David, Archbishop of Monaco, Mr Patrice Cellario and Ms Isabelle Bonnal were also keen to meet students and staff at the François d’Assise-Nicolas Barré primary school.    After witnessing the return of the five-year-old (Grande Section) nursery pupils, H.E. the Minister of State chatted to Year 2 (CP) and Year 5 (CM1) pupils and teaching staff.    During his discussions at the Principality’s schools, H.E. the Minister of State asked pupils how they felt about returning to school this year. They told him that they were happy to be able to get back to their lessons and to be with their friends again.    In the course of his visits, H.E. the Minister of State also welcomed the rigorous compliance with health guidelines on the part of all pupils and staff.    This September marks the beginning of a new school year for the 518 teachers and 5,774 pupils enrolled in Monaco’s schools."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201226070954/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/2020-2021-school-year-begins
notes_H6: https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150930/https://www.monaco-tribune.com/en/2020/11/all-you-need-to-know-about-monacos-new-measures-to-tackle-the-pandemic/
notes_C2: PHASE 1: From 4 May      all shops (one person/4 m2), with the exception of cafés, restaurants and hotels, can open  places of worship will be open (maintaining a safe distance of 1.5 m from others + mask)  hairdressers, beauty salons and healthcare practices can open by appointment only  private and public construction sites can resume activity  take-away sales will continue (with management of queues)  the Monegasque Bus Company (CAM) will resume a normal service  cruise ship ports of call will be banned  private vessels will be authorised to leave the port  there will be a partial resumption of traffic at the heliport (private charters)  finally, the civil service will resume its activities, while continuing to prioritise teleworking and videoconferencing. However, departments that generally deal directly with the public will reopen their doors.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201208140324/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/Lifting-the-lockdown-in-the-Principality-step-by-step
notes_E1: Employees who usually receive a gross base salary of less than or equal to EUR 2,075.16, for 169 hours per month, will not lose any of their income. They will receive their usual net salary, since this is less than EUR 1,800.00.    Employees who usually receive a gross base salary of between EUR 2,075.17 and EUR 2,571.43, for 169 hours per month, will be entitled to the safeguard clause at a rate of EUR 1,800.00.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201124150602/https://covid19.mc/en/thematiques/travail/    "The extension of the Strengthened Provisions for Total Temporary Layoff until next spring is a significant measure, budgeted at EUR 9M per month. It meets the needs of many professionals who fear renewed difficulties at the end of the summer season, which has been marked, in particular, by the cancellation of several major events in September-October," stated Mr. Gamerdinger."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201226084504/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/Extension-of-the-CTTR-to-31-March-2021-A-Powerful-Indication-of-the-State-s-Commitment-to-Safeguarding-Employment
notes_C3: Concerts and shows must end by 9:30 pm. Spectators will have until 10 pm to get back home, using their concert ticket as proof of their trip.  The same rules apply to casinos. Gaming establishments must issue clients a document certifying the client’s time of departure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150930/https://www.monaco-tribune.com/en/2020/11/all-you-need-to-know-about-monacos-new-measures-to-tackle-the-pandemic/
notes_C6: The Principality is not under lockdown, but a curfew is in place!    In short, travel by any person outside their place of residence between 7 p.m. and 6 a.m. is prohibited, with the exception of travel for the following reasons:    -travel between the place of residence and the place of exercise of the professional activity or the place of education or training  -travel for consultations and care that cannot be provided remotely and cannot be postponed or for the purchase of health products  -travel for pressing family reasons, for assistance to vulnerable or precarious people or for childcare  -travel to respond to a judicial or administrative summons  -travel to participate in missions of general interest at the request of the administrative authority  short trips for the needs of pets    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_C5: The Monegasque Bus Company (CAM) is resuming normal service for all buses, including the Bateau Bus (water bus). The only exceptions to this are the night services, N1 and N2, which will remain closed.     The following health measures apply:    The wearing of masks is mandatory on public transport  Tickets can be purchased on board, on condition that you pay the exact amount  Tickets are also available from the 12 automatic ticket machines located throughout the Principality, and the shop at 22/24 Rue du Gabian is open from 8.30 am to 4.30 pm Monday to Friday  The following procedures continue to apply:    Buses will be disinfected twice a day  Dispensers of hydro-alcoholic gel have been installed in every bus  Buses will stop at every stop (to avoid the need for people to press the buttons)  Passenger information showing the direction in which you should walk when boarding, leaving and while on the bus, is displayed on the floor and doors of the bus  It is forbidden to get off the bus  at the front    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_H7: "Initially, vaccinations will be available to senior residents aged 75 or over, living either in care homes or in the community, who have received a letter from the Government inviting them to contact the COVID-19 Call Centre"    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115170152/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/First-COVID-19-vaccination-in-Principality    In general:    Vaccines will become available gradually, and so the Prince’s Government has had to establish priorities to ensure that at-risk groups are at the front of the queue. These groups are:    -Elderly people living in care settings    -People aged over 75    -People aged 65–74    -People with underlying health conditions (obesity (BMI>30), particularly among younger people, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and respiratory disease, complex high blood pressure disorders, heart disease, type 1 or type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, recent history of cancer (within the last three years), solid organ transplant or haematopoietic stem cell transplant, Down’s syndrome, etc.)    -Healthcare workers, etcA    The vaccination campaign will therefore be rolled out in several phases to target each category of the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115165719/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-vaccins/vaccination-procedure/

name: Moldova
notes_H1: Public Information campaign appears organised with posters giving specific advice and instructions. https://web.archive.org/web/20200727231717/https://msmps.gov.md/minister/comunicare/covid-19/
notes_H3: Current restrictions from 30 November remain in place until 15 January.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110000414/https://gov.md/en/comunicate-presa  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109235654/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H2: Suspected cases are tested in order to classify and report them based on standard procedures.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200517130545/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/moldova/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5%20Testing&Type=Section
notes_C7: Depending on the zone, individuals are in, it is recommended not to travel inside the country.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201008021259/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UN%20Moldova%20COVID-19%20Response%20and%20Recovery%20Monlty%20Bulletin%20-%20September%202020.pdf
notes_C8: Foreigners coming from “red zone” countries are not permitted into Moldova unless they meet one of the following exceptions:  (1) immediate family members of Moldovan citizens or of foreign nationals who have been allowed to stay in Moldova; (2) persons having a visa, residency permit, or other document issued by Moldovan authorities; (3) persons traveling for “professional interest” in possession of a visa, residency permit, or other document issued by Moldovan authorities; (4) diplomats accredited to Moldova and members of international organizations and their family members; (5) personnel who can provide humanitarian aid; (6) passengers in transit, (7) pupils or students who travel for activities related to the completion, organisation or development of studies, (8) foreign nationals working as teachers in Moldova, (9) foreign journalists. The list of “red zone” countries is published by the Ministry of Health and will be updated every two weeks.     Moldova requires a 14-day home stay (quarantine) for new arrivals from “red zone” countries in determined places, with exceptions including asymptomatic individuals delivering goods, crew members, students, people traveling for health or humanitarian reasons, people travelling in the professional interest with visas or residence permit or other confirmatory document, cross-border workers, diplomatic corps accredited in Moldova, foreign journalists, and passengers in transit. The Ministry of Health will update the list of countries on the “red” list every two weeks. All travelers must complete an epidemiological questionnaire (“fisa epidemiologica”) when entering Moldova and sign a statement that they will self-isolate for 14 days, if required.    If the starting point is located in a classified country as a green area, and during the journey the country classified as a red zone was transited, including airport transit, then the person is considered to be coming from the red zone, needs to complete the epidemiological file and is obliged to respect the self-isolation regime of 14 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200929120012/https://gov.md/sites/default/files/hotarirea_cnesp_nr.33_28.09.2020.pdf
notes_C4: The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled to establish emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova on the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021:  Groups of more than three people are prohibited in public areas. Public parks are open, but people should not congregate in groups larger than three.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201205215306/https://gov.md/en/content/national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-declares-state-emergency-public-health-all   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205214717/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: The Minister of Education, Culture and Research established that schools remain open. The Minister further provided seven models to which schools can decide to adhere, from full school attendance in Model 1 to teaching exclusively online in connection with the quarantine situation in the locality or institution in Model 6. In case of school attendance, several COVID measures are in place including social distance of 1.5 meters and 4 sq.m per student.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201118112541/https://mecc.gov.md/ro/content/ministrul-igor-sarov-prezentat-datele-privind-modul-de-desfasurare-procesului-educational
notes_H6: The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled to establish emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova on the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021:  Face-masks are mandatory in all public spaces, including outdoors.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201205215306/https://gov.md/en/content/national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-declares-state-emergency-public-health-all   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205214717/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled to establish emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova on the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021:  Ban the activity of night clubs (disco clubs, karaoke, disco pubs), starting from 28 November. At the same time, as of 30 November, the restaurants, pubs and coffee houses will be able to work till 22:00. The public nourishment units will be banned from working in the time interval 22:00-7:00.    The organization and holding of scientific conferences, sports competitions, Olympiads with the physical presence of people will be prohibited. Also, the presence of audience in theatres, movie theatres, concert halls and community centres will not be allowed.    At the same time, the public and private institutions will establish a special regime of work, with only the strictly necessary staff attracted to the working place, in order to ensure the enterprises’ functionality. The distance work will have to be organized for the personnel, whose activity does not need the compulsory presence at the working place.        https://web.archive.org/web/20201205215306/https://gov.md/en/content/national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-declares-state-emergency-public-health-all   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205214717/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: Banks are allowed to instigate payment holidays until June 30. Income tax payments have been suspended. https://www.ebrd.com/where-we-are/moldova/overview.html;https://www.ebrd.com/where-we-are/moldova/overview.html
notes_E1: "The government will also assist businesses that have suspended their activities (fully or partially) by refunding personal income taxes and social security contributions up to 100%. Those that had to stop their operations due to decision of authorities will receive a subsidy amounting to 100% of their income tax, social security and health contributions, and other compulsory state payments. Persons who have worked for at least nine months at one enterprise and have lost their jobs will be paid from 60 to 80% of their final salary. Banks were also incentivised to delay payment deadlines and/or the amounts of due payments on loans until 30 June."https://www.oecd.org/coronavirus/policy-responses/covid-19-crisis-response-in-eu-eastern-partner-countries/
notes_C3: The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled to establish emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova on the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021:  The Commission will allow the organization of one-off mass rallies and festive events with the participation of less than 50 people, with the observance of the public health measures and compulsory compilation of the event’s epidemiological record lists.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201205215306/https://gov.md/en/content/national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-declares-state-emergency-public-health-all   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205214717/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: On 28 September, the National Commission for Public Health established from 1 October, color-coded alert levels and that local territories could establish their own policies.    Depending on the zone, individuals are in, it is recommended to stay at home (red zones).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213234816/https://msmps.gov.md/comunicare/noutati/in-unitatile-teritorial-administrative-cu-grad-de-alerta-cod-rosu-a-fost-instituita-starea-de-urgenta-in-sanatate-publica-2/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201008021259/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UN%20Moldova%20COVID-19%20Response%20and%20Recovery%20Monlty%20Bulletin%20-%20September%202020.pdf
notes_C5: Masks are required on public transport.https://web.archive.org/web/20200727230419/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/moldova/coronavirus

name: Madagascar
notes_H1: No policy change
notes_H3: Ho faritana mazava tsara ny toerana rehetra honenan’ireo mpandeha ary anaovana antso avo amin’ny vahoaka malagasy rehetra amin’ny alalan’ny fametrahana ny laharana 911, mba hanamorana ny fanaraha-maso azy ireo sy hahafahan'ny havany, ny olom-pantany na ny olona akaiky ireo olona vao nitodi-doha an-tanindrazana tato anatiny 14 andro, mampandre ny tompon'andraikitra. https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.presidence.gov.mg/actualites/754-tatitry-ny-filankevitry-ny-minisitra-natao-tao-amin-ny-lapam-panjakana-ambohitsirohitra-sabotsy-21-martsa-2020.html    The location of the passengers will be clearly defined and made available to all Malagasy people by providing a 911 number, to facilitate surveillance and to enable relatives, acquaintances or people close to the newcomers within 14 days, authorities said.
notes_H2: On 21 March the Government of Madagascar declared a Health State of Emergency.  All individuals that have come to Madagascar within the 14 days prior to 19 March must have a medical examination and be tested for coronavirus. https://web.archive.org/web/20200406202632/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus
notes_C7: Sanitary checks are in place at exit points from Antananarivo and other major cities.  A curfew is in place from 21:00pm to 04:00am. It is mandatory to wear a mask when outdoors.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200501012649/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus
notes_C8: All Foreign visitation is restricted to the island of Nosy Be, foreign citizens are not permitted elsewhere in Madagascar    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232310/http://www.presidence.gov.mg/actualites/decret/997-decret-n-2020-1270-du-03-octobre-2020-prolongeant-la-duree-de-l-etat-d-urgence-sanitaire-sur-tout-le-territoire-de-la-republique.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232333/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232330/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232339/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/390636/madagascar-authorities-announce-end-of-state-of-health-emergency-october-18-update-19
notes_C4: Curfews that were previously introduced in multiple areas of Madagascar were lifted. Authorities have also announced the easing of public gathering restrictions from Monday, permitting groups of up to 200 to gather for religious, cultural, and sporting events.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201012213846/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20201012214310/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/386456/madagascar-covid-19-curfew-lifted-as-state-of-health-emergency-extended-until-october-18-update-18
notes_C1: Previous coding: 0  New coding: 1G    Hygiene protocols are in place, even though there are reports that these are difficult for students to adhere to because e.g. handwashing with soap and water is a challenge.    https://archive.vn/nOfdw    Previous coding comment and sources:    On September 6, the president announced students can return to school on October 26th. "Pupils and students set on their return to class. According to the President of the Republic of the Republic, the start of the school year for the 2020-2021 school year is scheduled for October 26 for primary and secondary students in public institutions"     https://web.archive.org/web/20201125031144/https://2424.mg/education-la-rentree-scolaire-2020-2021-fixee-au-26-octobre-2020-sauf-pour-les-classes-terminales-la-rentree-universitaire-2019-2020-fixee-au-2-novembre-2020/     UNESCO's visualization of school closures also shows schools moving to Fully Open on October 26. https://web.archive.org/web/20201125031524/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H6: According to the US Embassay website "Failure to wear a mask in public can result in arrest for 24 hours.  Also, according to Aljazeera "Authorities warned that citizens leaving the house without face masks would face community service. "  "https://web.archive.org/web/20201025220700/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/https://web.archive.org/web/20201025220700/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201025221419/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/4/27/madagascar-people-without-face-masks-forced-to-sweep-streets
notes_C2: The State of Emergency ended on October 18, and there has been no guidance limiting workplaces since then.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201125041932/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201125042022/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E2: On July 1 the Special Council of Ministers announced the relief of payment of IR, IRSA, VAT provision and deferred until August 15, 2020 the payment declaration (declaration of payment) for those in the fields of tourism, aviation and the free enterprise  - Delay in payment of combined tax (Synthetic tax) and declaration of payment until August 15, 2020  - Suspension of tax controls and "notices to third parties or ATDs" until August 15, 2020  - Permission to return foreign currency (currency exchange) up to 80% without penalty  - Agreement on the payment of social contributions in the first quarter and second quarter.    From press release: Tatitry ny filankevitry ny minisitra natao tamin’ny alalan’ny « VISIOCONFERENCE » ny 01 jolay 2020   Follow link on https://web.archive.org/web/20200721074455/http://www.cnlegis.gov.mg/
notes_E1: The Government of Madagascar has launched a social protection programme to assist families impacted by the Covid-19 outbreak through the use of unconditional cash transfers in urban and suburban areas. The beneficiaries of TOSIKA FAMENO, identified at the fokontany level and registered in the list of beneficiaries established by the respective municipalities, are very poor and vulnerable families, those most exposed to a risk of food insecurity as well as *those whose income is interrupted because of the lock down.*The amount of the transfer amounts to 100,000 Ariary per household, payable in a single installment , for the month of May 2020. A second transfer of the same amount (100,000 ariary) is planned. While only applying to very poor households, this measure still is a measure of income support that is independent of whether previous employment was in the formal or informal sector. As the level of income replacement is a flat rate well below 50 percent of median income, this is rated as 1A despite its limited reach. https://web.archive.org/web/20200505013014/https://www.cnbcafrica.com/africa-press-office/2020/04/28/coronavirus-in-madagascar-a-social-protection-response-is-launched-in-urban-and-suburban-areas-to-aid-families-and-their-children-during-covid-19-pandemic/; https://web.archive.org/web/20200531203933/https://www.fid.mg/tosika-fameno/#1590388088109-e657a849-66fd (see technical sheet for details)
notes_C3: The State of Emergency was lifted October 18th with no further restrictions/advisement on conducting public events, apart from a restriction on mask-wearing and size of gathering (covered by other criteria)    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232310/http://www.presidence.gov.mg/actualites/decret/997-decret-n-2020-1270-du-03-octobre-2020-prolongeant-la-duree-de-l-etat-d-urgence-sanitaire-sur-tout-le-territoire-de-la-republique.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232333/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232330/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232339/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/390636/madagascar-authorities-announce-end-of-state-of-health-emergency-october-18-update-19
notes_C6: The State of Emergency was lifted October 18th with no further restrictions/advisement on staying at home, apart from  mask-wearing (covered by other criteria)    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232310/http://www.presidence.gov.mg/actualites/decret/997-decret-n-2020-1270-du-03-octobre-2020-prolongeant-la-duree-de-l-etat-d-urgence-sanitaire-sur-tout-le-territoire-de-la-republique.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232333/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232330/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232339/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/390636/madagascar-authorities-announce-end-of-state-of-health-emergency-october-18-update-19

Avoid staying around people at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19.  Consider getting tested for COVID-19.  In the United States, quarantine requirements and recommendations may vary by state. [/web/20200414045939/https://www.gob.mx/salud/prensa/presentan-salud-y-sep-medidas-de-prevencion-para-el-sector-educativo-nacional-por-covid-19?idiom=es%2C+https%3A%2F%2Fwww.unotv.com%2Fnoticias%2Fportal%2Fnacional%2Fdetalle%2Fcoronavirus-en-mexico-anuncian-jornada-nacional-de-sana-distancia-491479%2F]
notes_H6: As part of efforts to reduce Covid-19 transmission, governments in at least 11 states and Mexico City have made the use of face masks mandatory either in all public places or in certain locations.    In particular, the following qualifies for a 4T: The use of masks is also compulsory for all citizens in Cuernavaca, Morelos, when they are not in their homes, while senior citizens, pregnant women, children and people with respiratory diseases who live in other parts of the state must wear them while outside.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201105204636/https://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/coronavirus/use-of-face-masks-declared-mandatory/      Mexico: Mexico City and Many Mexican States Make Wearing Masks Mandatory on Public Transit  (Apr. 17, 2020) Mexico City’s rapid transit metro, the Collective Transportation System (Sistema de Transporte Colectivo, STC) reported in a press release on April 15, 2020, that to prevent the spread of COVID-19, the wearing of masks will be mandatory to travel by metro as of April 17, 2020.  The free distribution of one million mouth masks began on April 15. The masks will be available on Lines A and 9 at Pantitlán, the station with the highest user traffic in the system and where four lines converge.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201105203833/https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/mexico-mexico-city-and-many-mexican-states-make-wearing-masks-mandatory-on-public-transit/#:~:text=(Apr.,as%2520of%2520April%252017%252C%25202020.
notes_C2: “We’re going to postpone the return to both public and private offices in Mexico City to avoid infections. See news article, archived: http://web.archive.org/web/20200925055339/https://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/coronavirus/mexico-city-postpones-reopening-offices-hospital-occupancy-down/
