notes_H1: In addition, social, sporting, cultural and political groupings of more than 50 people such as weddings, baptisms, funerals were banned.  Public, private and denominational schools, including madarsas will be closed for three weeks  https://web.archive.org/web/20200408211603/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/mali-suspends-flights-from-covid-19-hit-countries-/1769908
notes_H3: http://malijet.com/a_la_une_du_mali/241897-covid-19-bonne-nouvelle-baisse-du-nombre-de-nouvelles-contaminat.html
notes_H2: The Government of Mali has implemented enhanced screening and quarantine measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: THere is no information on internal movement after the curfew being lifted.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.worldaware.com/covid-19-alert-mali-lifts-nationwide-curfew-may-10
notes_C8: The Government of Mali has implemented enhanced screening and quarantine measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19.  Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to go into effect with little or no advanced notice.  Incoming air travellers are required to:  •	Wear a mask.  •	Complete a form with contact information, travel history and health symptoms.   •	Present a negative COVID-19 test dated no more than seven days prior to arrival in Mali.  •	Any passenger who arrives without a negative COVID-19 test result or with a COVID-19 test result dated more than seven days before arrival will have their travel documents retained by airport officials and will be subjected to testing. Travelers must self-quarantine at home or at a hotel at their expense until the test result is available.  Anyone suspected of having COVID-19, despite presenting a negative COVID-19 test result, will be subject to testing.  If test results are positive, that person’s travel documents will be retained, and the traveler will be put into isolation at a government of Mali facility.  The travel documents will be returned once the patient is deemed free of COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: "On 25 March 2020, the Government declared a state of health emergency and a curfew from 21h to 5h in the morning which came to complete a set of measures previously adopted including (...) the prohibition, until further notice, of social, sports, cultural and political groups of more than 50 people"    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200427090758/https://reliefweb.int/report/mali/mali-coronavirus-covid-19-situation-report-no-1-reporting-period-25-march-08-april-2020

In fact, when the first cases popped up in March, comprehensive contact tracing took place for each case.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201217080015/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/January/19/pr200063.aspx
notes_H2: Swabs are generally available, even to asymptomatic or people wishing to swab on their wish.    https://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2020-03-24/local-news/Two-new-swabbing-hubs-to-open-in-Malta-tomorrow-6736221236
notes_C7: Travel to Gozo once again permitted without any restrictions    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201217064445/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/June/01/pr201038.aspx
notes_C8: Although the border closure is now lifted, travel to several countries remain banned throughout. The list of countries that travel is restricted to is very fluid and changes across time.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201217072559/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/travel-ban-to-be-lifted-for-regions-in-italy-france-spain-hard-hit-by.801810
notes_C4: Malta restricts gatherings to fewer than 10 people, then to 6.    source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201217065445/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/105023/covid19_group_gatherings_in_public_spaces_reduced_to_10_people
notes_C1: Schools are open with some alterations resulting in significant differences compared to usual non-COVID19 operations. Source:    http://web.archive.org/web/20201216092243/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/summer-schools-to-reopen-on-july-1-two-weeks-early.796041
notes_H6: Mask is mandatory as soon as a person leaves home.    source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201217080855/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/October/16/pr202014.aspx
notes_C2: Maltese Government re-introduced closure restrictions for certain sectors of the economy    http://web.archive.org/web/20201216095033/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/October/26/pr202088.aspx
notes_E2: From 13th March 2020, Government introduced, and maintained various narrow debt relief to households, from tax deferments to loan moratoria. This is in place up to at least 2021.    source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201217074334/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/March/14/pr200489.aspx  http://web.archive.org/web/20201217074531/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/moratorium-on-loan-repayments-to-extend-into-2021.839084
notes_E1: A wage supplement is introduced on 18th March 2020. This is committed to be provided at least till March 2021.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201217072939/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/March/18/pr200520.aspx
notes_C3: Government reintroduces public event ban    http://web.archive.org/web/20201216100018/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/July/31/pr201473.aspx
notes_C6: Stay at home requirements are removed completely.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201217083045/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/June/01/pr201038.aspx
notes_C5: Public transport operational as per normal, apart from some small requirements such as mask wearing.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201217070503/https://www.maltachamber.org.mt/en/malta-public-transport-releases-new-summer-schedule-with-436-additional-trips-per-day
notes_H7: A, C:    After starting vaccinating Healthcare workers, on 1st January 2021, Malta started vaccinating also people in old people's homes.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210101183322/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/woman-94-becomes-first-elderly-person-to-be-vaccinated-against-covid.842265

name: Myanmar
notes_H1: On March 9th, the Ministry of Health and Sports launched an awareness campaign and COVID-19 tracking website.     They are:   "-publishing situation reports about Myanmar and other countries in the state-owned newspapers and the internet website of the Ministry (www.mohs.gov.mm) and social media pages (https://www.facebook.com/ MinistryOfHealthAndSportsMyanmar) and (https://www.facebook.com/ MyanmarCDC) , with taking response to the fake news  -coordination with relevant government agencies to lessen socioeconomic impacts resulted from COVID-19.  -awareness programmes with the use of handheld loudspeakers at the crowded places in Regions and States such as bus gates and markets, in cooperation with Myanmar Red Cross Society , civil society organizations and community based organizations."  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200604172504/https://www.globalnewlightofmyanmar.com/report-on-coronavirus-disease-2019-covid-19-3/    COVID-19 tracking website: https://web.archive.org/web/20200320234718/https://mohs.gov.mm/Main/content/publication/2019-ncov
notes_H3: H3 : updated to 2 from 1 as per the highlight below.    There is an app and a *SOP for contact tracing*. Further information below.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201109183410/https://eurocham-myanmar.org/post/615/Myanmar-government-developed-a-COVID-19-tracking-App  http://web.archive.org/web/20201109183622/https://www.who.int/myanmar/emergencies/covid-19-advice-for-the-public/contact-tracing  during the second wave of infections, the Ministry of Health and Sports has *scaled up contact tracing* and testing capacity and adopted tougher rules. These measures are reflecting that the Union Government is taking all precautions extremely seriously.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201109183850/https://www.mdn.gov.mm/en/contact-tracing-key-beat-back-second-coronavirus-wave
notes_H2: H2 : updated to 3 from 2 as per the article below.    Administrative testing for travel and other purposes in asymptomatic people is available in Burma. The test costs 200,000 MMK, paid by the customer.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201109171739/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: C7 : updated to 2T from 2G as the restrictions vary from province - check the highlight below and details by province are in the link.    Travel restrictions and mandatory public health measures are in force in *most parts of Burma*.    Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? – YES  http://web.archive.org/web/20201109171739/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: C8 : updated to 4 from 3 as the land and air borders are closed as per link below.    Effective March 30, the Burmese government will no longer allow international commercial passenger flights to land at any airport in Burma. This suspension will last through November 30  On March 19, the Burmese government announced the temporary suspension of entry and exit of foreign nationals through land borders.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201109171739/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: C4 : updated to 3G from 3T because the ban is nationwide ( check the highlight below )    The Burmese government imposed a *nationwide* ban on gatherings of 30 or more people, effective beginning on August 16. Exceptions include work commutes for public servants, corporate employees, and factory workers; medical emergencies; shopping at permitted markets; delivery of goods; employment activities; public, private, and monastic schools; holding meetings, discussions, and classes in line with Ministry of Health guidelines; eating at restaurants that follow Ministry of Health guidelines; official COVID-19 control and protection activities; and funerals.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201109171739/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: The government of Myanmar ordered all schools, including private ones, to close from 26 August. The date for re-opening has not yet been announced  https://web.archive.org/web/20200909015440/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/myanmar/coronavirus
notes_H6: Since 13 May it has been compulsory for anyone going out in public in Myanmar to wear a facemask. Failure to wear one will result in a fine. This requirement is being enforced strictly and has led to the arrest of some offenders. https://web.archive.org/web/20200909015440/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/myanmar/coronavirus
notes_C2: On the 25th of September the Ministry of Health and Sports issued an order effective 26th September that, people residing in 11 townships of the four state and regions are required for “Stay-at-Home” in order to effectively control the spread of the disease.   Those who need to perform their duties at government departments, banking services, filling stations, private-rum ports, communication businesses, food production, production and distribution of medical supplies and drinking water, factories of daily personal hygiene products and related businesses are excluded. Civil servants are to rotate on a 2-week for office attendance and 2-week on work-from-home basis.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201006141131/https://www.moi.gov.mm/moi:eng/announcements/1545
notes_E2: This seems like it should be coded as 2. For example, according to the IMF, as of October 8 2020, there were measures in place including: exemptions and subsidies of household electricity charges (MMK 109 billion); deferment of income and commercial tax payments due in the second and third quarters of the fiscal year to end of FY 19/20. See https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  [accessed 19 October 2020, web archive unavailable]
notes_E1: E1 : updated to 1A from 1F as the relief is being provided to everyone in the "vulnerable" category.    In-kind and cash transfers to the *most vulnerable* population (MMK 325 billion)    Insured Fund for Workers: The Social Security Board, under the Ministry of Labor, Immigration and Population, will pay 40 percent of the salary to insured workers, as a family assistance fund, in accordance with the Social Security Law.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201029172716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: On the 25th of September the Ministry of Health and Sports issued an order effective 26th September that, people residing in 11 townships of the four state and regions are required for “Stay-at-Home” in order to effectively control the spread of the disease.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201006141131/https://www.moi.gov.mm/moi:eng/announcements/1545
notes_C6: The Burmese government announced stay-at-home orders for all of Yangon Region (except for Coco Island), effective at 8:00 AM on September 21.  Residents of Yangon Region must abide by the following orders: 1.) stay at home unless going to/from work, 2.) employees of private organizations and businesses must telework (those working in banking and finance, gas stations, food and refrigeration services, production and manufacturing of pharmaceutical products, medical equipment production, and the distribution of drinking water and personal hygiene items are exempt).  http://web.archive.org/web/20201109171739/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: On the 25th of September the Ministry of Health and Sports issued an order effective 26th September that, people residing in 11 townships of the four state and regions are required for “Stay-at-Home” in order to effectively control the spread of the disease.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201006141131/https://www.moi.gov.mm/moi:eng/announcements/1545

name: Mongolia
notes_H3: More than 120 people who came into close contact with the patient have been identified so far and taken to quarantine and over 500 people with indirect contact with him have been tacked down and currently are under medical observation.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200403231017/https://montsame.mn/en/read/218344
notes_H2: Pretty low positive/tested rate: they might actually be testing even asymptomatic people:  http://archive.fo/AUUOy
notes_C7: Travel to and from the capital has been banned.
notes_C8: The Government of Mongolia has decided to temporarily suspend entry of all passengers through all border checkpoints until 30 April 2020.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200517094042/http://embassyofmongolia.co.uk/?p=3265&lang=en
notes_C4: Mongolia has ended a lockdown in several provinces, including the capital Ulaanbaatar.  Meanwhile, 'Battsengel soum in Arkhangai and Altanbulag and Sukhbaatar soums in Selenge are subject to more severe restrictions until at least 21 December under a state of “all-out readiness”. The public in those locations need to avoid any non-essential activities and movement. Essential services such as grocery stores, pharmacies and hospitals remain open.  The government of Mongolia has placed all other provinces in Mongolia under a state of “high alert”, which entails less severe restrictions.'    https://archive.vn/AcMHj
notes_C1: Mongolia has ended a lockdown in several provinces, including the capital Ulaanbaatar.  Meanwhile, 'Battsengel soum in Arkhangai and Altanbulag and Sukhbaatar soums in Selenge are subject to more severe restrictions until at least 21 December under a state of “all-out readiness”. The public in those locations need to avoid any non-essential activities and movement. Essential services such as grocery stores, pharmacies and hospitals remain open.  The government of Mongolia has placed all other provinces in Mongolia under a state of “high alert”, which entails less severe restrictions.'    https://archive.vn/AcMHj
notes_H6: Everyone is required to wear a facemask in public places. Non-compliance is subjected to a fine up to MNT 50 000 (EUR 15).    https://archive.vn/0NGLd#selection-1133.0-1133.122
notes_C2: "The Mongolian government has publicly announced a downgrade in its?state?of?emergency?preparedness in Ulaanbaatar, effective January 11, 2021.? Beginning on this date, vehicle restrictions will be lifted and certain businesses will be permitted to resume limited operations."   https://web.archive.org/web/20210119040506/https://mn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: On March 27, a comprehensive set of fiscal measures for consideration has been proposed by the cabinet to protect vulnerable household and businesses and to support the economy. These include: (i) ... and (iv) an increase in credit guarantees to SMEs and soft loans from the development bank to cashmere producers. On April 13, Parliament approved tax exemption measures as proposed by the cabinet.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200723211732/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.mongolbank.mn/eng/news.aspx?tid=1&id=2489
notes_E1: Government on 2 Aug on how it is using international aid:  "For example, the child allowance was increased to MNT 100,000, funding for food purchases for low-income families was doubled, MNT 73,000 was provided to 73,000 people from 6.9 thousand low-income enterprises, and social welfare pensioners and permanent care recipients were provided. An additional MNT 768 billion has been spent so far, including an increase of MNT 100,000 in child benefits.  In addition, in order to protect the income of citizens, business entities and organizations, a total of 1 trillion 877.9 billion MNT of social insurance premiums, personal income and corporate income tax, its interest and fines were completely exempted. The Kovid-19 epidemic has created a total budget burden of 2.5 trillion MNT. "  http://archive.fo/E0dVy

Meanwhile, 'Battsengel soum in Arkhangai and Altanbulag and Sukhbaatar soums in Selenge are subject to more severe restrictions until at least 21 December under a state of “all-out readiness”. The public in those locations need to avoid any non-essential activities and movement. Essential services such as grocery stores, pharmacies and hospitals remain open.  The government of Mongolia has placed all other provinces in Mongolia under a state of “high alert”, which entails less severe restrictions.'    https://archive.vn/AcMHj

The public in those locations need to avoid any non-essential activities and movement. Essential services such as grocery stores, pharmacies and hospitals remain open. name: Mozambique
notes_H1: Mozambique reports first case of Coronavirus; starts daily Coronavirus briefings; https://web.archive.org/web/20200506214722/http://www.misau.gov.mz/index.php/100-primeiro-caso-de-coronavirus-confirmado-hoje-em-mocambique
notes_H3: Contact tracing for the first case in the country: The patient has mild symptoms, is in isolation at home and is undergoing clinical follow-up by the country's health authorities. At this moment, contacts are being tracked for the purposes of monitoring the transmission of the virus. https://web.archive.org/web/20200506214722/http://www.misau.gov.mz/index.php/100-primeiro-caso-de-coronavirus-confirmado-hoje-em-mocambique
notes_H2: Testing policy is not explicitly stated, but limited test kit supply strongly implies that only suspected and eligible cases can be tested. "2,500 testing kits for COVID-19 available, and the government is negotiating with partners on receiving more testing kits, protective and other medical equipment."  https://www.netherlandsworldwide.nl/latest/news/2020/03/20/covid-information-mozambique-for-dutch-nationals (page cannot be archived)
notes_C7: No restrictions measures on interstate or intercity travel are mentioned.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201028113637/https://mz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028114857/https://www.dw.com/pt-002/covid-19-estado-de-calamidade-p%C3%BAblica-declarado-em-mo%C3%A7ambique/a-54822206
notes_C8: "On December 17, President Nyusi announced revised COVID-19 measures effective December 19. These measures include:    - All persons arriving in Mozambique must present a PCR negative test result undertaken in the country of origin up to 96 hours prior to departure;   -Tourist and visitor visas will be re-issued at all operational border posts"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201231180619if_/https://www.facebook.com/pg/CanadainMozambique/posts/
notes_C4: The SOPC (State of Public Calamity) will allow for the gradual resumption of the following activities:  - Private social events are permitted with up to 40 attendees  - Religious services are permitted at 50 percent capacity, up to 150 attendees  - Public and private institutions can conduct operations in conformance with social distancing and preventative measures including temperature checks, regular cleaning of facilities, ventilation, prohibition of sick staff entering facilities, and a limit of 40 people for events  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115131525/https://mz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Beginning August 18, the President of Mozambique announced a phased approach to resuming economic and social activity in the country.  Phase 1: Low Risk Activities including following:  - Resumption of higher education classes  - Resumption of classes in the academies and schools of security and defense forces  - Resumption of primary and adult education teaching training classes  - Resumption of technical and vocational classes  - Resumption of medical training classes at public professional training centers    https://web.archive.org/web/20200816123205/https:/mz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Slightly contradicting information. According to the latest information ( Nov 15) masks appear to be mandatory: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115132800/https://tvi24.iol.pt/aominuto/5e56645d0cf2071930699ff6/pr-mocambicano-pede-que-restricoes-continuem-mesmo-com-fim-do-estado-de-emergencia/5f21ecea0cf2e21cf3311a23      Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104225831/https://mz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104225907/https://masks4all.co/pt/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104230022/https://intelyse.com/coronavirus-travel-restrictions/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104230948/https://www.noticiasaominuto.com/mundo/1618818/covid-19-mocambique-regista-relativa-estabilizacao-de-casos-e-obitos
notes_C2: On December 17, the President, Filipe Nyusi, announced revised COVID-19 measures - for a moderate restart of the country's social life - effective on Saturday, December 19. These measures include:    "(...) - Market hours will be extended from 5pm to 6pm  - Bars and “baracas” will be open from 9am-4pm between Sundays and Thursdays, and between 9am and 7pm on Fridays and Saturdays"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201231180619if_/https://www.facebook.com/pg/CanadainMozambique/posts/  https://www.dw.com/pt-002/filipe-nyusi-suaviza-estado-de-emerg%C3%AAncia-para-o-final-de-um-ano-at%C3%ADpico/a-55979048 (unable to archive)
notes_C3: Gatherings of more than 20 people are banned   https://web.archive.org/web/20200816123245/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/mozambique/coronavirus
notes_C6: All persons displaying respiratory symptoms or fever must stay home.]    Link:http://web.archive.org/web/20210117205045/https://mz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: "On September 7, Mozambique transitioned from a State of Emergency (SOE) to a State of Public Calamity (SOPC) [will be in place for an indefinite period].  The SOPC will continue indefinitely at the red alert level while the risk of spreading COVID-19 exists in Mozambique and preserves many of the SOE COVID-19 prevention measures with gradual resumption of social and economic activities in coordination with health authorities.    During the SOPC the following prevention measures remain in effect:  (....)  Passenger limits for buses, vans, and other methods of public transportation"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201028113637/https://mz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028114857/https://www.dw.com/pt-002/covid-19-estado-de-calamidade-p%C3%BAblica-declarado-em-mo%C3%A7ambique/a-54822206

name: Mauritania
notes_H1: Ministry of Health has made prevention information campaigns, instituted a hotline and issues daily situation reports ( active as of April 24):https://web.archive.org/web/20200425200501/http://www.sante.gov.mr/?p=4038; https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.francetvinfo.fr/monde/afrique/societe-africaine/covid-19-plus-aucun-cas-positif-la-mauritanie-semble-avoir-trouve-une-strategie-gagnante-contre-l-epidemie_3928929.html
notes_H3: The government monitors the active and asymptomatic cases and publish their status on the website.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200731022622/http://www.sante.gov.mr/?lang=fr
notes_H2: No policy update.
notes_C7: "The government of Mauritania has announced the easing of domestic restrictions nationwide from July 10. The nightly 2000-0600 will expire July 10, and intercity travel will be permitted to resume. Domestic flights can also begin from this date. "https://web.archive.org/web/20200721040828/https://www.worldaware.com/covid-19-alert-mauritania-ease-domestic-restrictions-july-10
notes_C8: Negative COVID-19 test required for entry; screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry; quarantine procedures upon entry cannot be confirmed, December 18, 2020; source: /web/20201221104523/https://mr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/
notes_C4: According to the UK government's website on travel to Mauritania, Friday gatherings for the prayers at the most have been banned and schools are also closed. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210111094603/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/mauritania/coronavirus
notes_C1: Schools/Universities have closed effective from December 4, 2020
notes_H6: On June 15, the Mauritanian Government made face covering compulsory in public places.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200731012154/https://mr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/
notes_C2: According to the UK government's website on travel to Mauritania, all government offices will work from 8am to 4pm instead of 9am to 5pm. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210111094603/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/mauritania/coronavirus
notes_E2: Although the government is reducing lending rates and banks' reserve requirements, it is not freezing any financial obligations. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210104101126/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: The code has been changed from 1A to 0, from June 26th; the financial support to 30,000 families announced on March 25th, due to last 3 months, was no longer current after the June 25th, and no new income support policies have been found. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200504183357/https://arabic.cnn.com/business/article/2020/03/26/mauritania-coronavirus-electricity-water-bills
notes_C3: In order to contain the resurgence of the virus, on December 2, 2020 the government instructed the suspension of public ceremonies.
notes_C6: According to the UK government's website on travel to Mauritania, there is a nationwide curfew across the country from 8pm to 6am. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210111094603/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/mauritania/coronavirus    Also see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210111095742/https://mr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/
notes_C5: "The government of Mauritania has announced the easing of domestic restrictions nationwide from July 10. Domestic flights can also begin from this date. The use of protective masks is compulsory in all public spaces." https://web.archive.org/web/20200721040828/https://www.worldaware.com/covid-19-alert-mauritania-ease-domestic-restrictions-july-10

name: Mauritius
notes_H1: Mobile app launched on 26th March: https://web.archive.org/save/https://defimedia.info/besafemoris-une-application-gratuite-pour-des-informations-officielles-sur-le-covid-19
notes_H3: It seems like contract tracing is comprehensive rather than limited. Since the time the number of cases climbed steadily and reached 128 on 30 March, health services prioritised contact tracing to identify people to test – that is, people who had been in physical contact with infected and identified patients – while anybody who had been quarantined and showed symptoms suggestive of COVID-19 infection was also tested. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20200521205121/https://voxeu.org/article/mauritian-response-covid-19
notes_H2: The only guidance on who can get access to testing I can find is on the US embassy’s website.   COVID-19 Testing:  COVID-19 tests are available at the C-Lab laboratory at Wellkin Hospital on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 09:00 to 12:00. Patients must dial 605-1000 to book an appointment. Results are available within 48 hours. Cost of Rs. 2500 (approximately $60 USD) must be paid in full by the patient. Visit Wellkin Hospital’s COVID-19 announcement (French) for additional information.    https://archive.vn/YwWqy#selection-1899.0-1911.37  The above referenced website does not mention costs or eligibility.  https://archive.vn/da2qK  However, the coverage about a newly detected community case and related contact tracing implies that anyone with symptoms does get tested.  https://archive.vn/CC3bZ  But I can’t find any evidence of drive-through testing.
notes_C7: Per May 30th policy "These include: citizens will be able to go out without abiding to the alphabetical order rule; the Work Access Permit will not be used; the elderly and those who have a weak health will have to avoid rush hours to travel; those aged under 18 will be able to go out; day care centres and nurseries will be allowed to operate; and trades such as supermarkets will be able to operate on a normal hour basis without having to necessarily respect the alphabetical order rule."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200617152934/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Covid-19-Mauritius-to-lift-curfew-on-30-May-2020,-at-midnight,-says-PM.aspx
notes_C8: Following the emergence of the new strain of COVID, in late December Mauritius banned entry for all travelers who have been in South Africa or the United Kingdom in the past 14 days. See: https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 [web archive unavailable, accessed 11 January 2021]
notes_C4: "The Prime Minister announced that following the Cabinet Meeting today, decision has been taken for the lift of all business and activity lockdowns ordered earlier to cope with the Covid-19, as from Monday 15 June 2020. Consequently, beaches, markets, gyms, parks, Village Halls, Community Centres, cinema and other public places will now be accessible to the public but the wearing of masks will still be compulsory."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200617154020/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Covid-19-We-should-be-proud-of-the-way-we-have-tackled-the-situation,-says-PM.aspx
notes_C1: The VPM stressed that following the recommendations of the Ministry of Health and Wellness, based upon the current situation with no positive Covid-19 case among the population, the Ministry has reworked the school calendar as well as resumption of classes.  Instead of the phased resumption of schools as from 01 August 2020 as announced earlier,  all classes will now resume on 01 July 2020, she indicated. Mrs Leela Devi Dookun-Luchoomun emphasised that a series of measures geared towards ensuring a safe environment will have to be adhered to by students , teaching and non-teaching staff.    link - https://web.archive.org/web/20200615155638/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/New-school-calendar-for-academic-year-2020-revealed-.aspx
notes_H6: Social distancing and wearing of face masks in public remains mandatory.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210119070739/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/mauritius/coronavirus
notes_C2: "After 47 days without any new local Covid-19 case, all economic and social activities can now resume and we should be proud of the way we have tackled the situation, stated the Prime Minister, Mr Pravind Kumar Jugnauth, this evening, in a press conference at the Treasury Building in Port Louis.  The Prime Minister announced that following the Cabinet Meeting today, decision has been taken for the lift of all business and activity lockdowns ordered earlier to cope with the Covid-19, as from Monday 15 June 2020. Consequently, beaches, markets, gyms, parks, Village Halls, Community Centres, cinema and other public places will now be accessible to the public but the wearing of masks will still be compulsory."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200617154020/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Covid-19-We-should-be-proud-of-the-way-we-have-tackled-the-situation,-says-PM.aspx
notes_E2: The previously coded support applies to corporations, not households.   According to IMF, there was a six month moratorium on household loans at commercial banks, from March 23. Cannot find information that this has been extended.    https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#M
notes_E1: As regards those companies which will not be able to sustain the shock and will have to close down, Mr Callichurn underlined that where termination of employment is justified, a worker will be entitled to 30 days’ wages in lieu of notice and will also benefit from the payment of an End of Year Bonus computed on the basis of the number of months he has been working during the year.     He will also be refunded the remaining balance of his annual leave. In addition to the above, the employer would have to fulfill his obligations under the Portable Retirement Gratuity Fund, that is, he/she will be under the obligation to pay gratuity on retirement of 15 days per year of service to the laid-off worker or contribute same in the latter’s individual account held by the Mauritius Revenue Authority.  Furthermore, the Workers’ Rights Act is also being amended to entitle laid-off workers reckoning more than 180 days (6 months) to benefit a Transitional unemployment assistance of 90% of the basic wage up to the NPF ceiling for a period of 6 months instead of 3 months, as it is the case presently, and 60% for the next 6 months instead of 30% for the last 6 months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200615161150/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Budget-2020-2021-New-regulations-and-measures-for-a-gradual-restart-of-business-activities.aspx
notes_C3: "The Prime Minister announced that following the Cabinet Meeting today, decision has been taken for the lift of all business and activity lockdowns ordered earlier to cope with the Covid-19, as from Monday 15 June 2020. Consequently, beaches, markets, gyms, parks, Village Halls, Community Centres, cinema and other public places will now be accessible to the public but the wearing of masks will still be compulsory."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200617154020/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Covid-19-We-should-be-proud-of-the-way-we-have-tackled-the-situation,-says-PM.aspx
notes_C6: Per May 30th policy "These include: citizens will be able to go out without abiding to the alphabetical order rule; the Work Access Permit will not be used; the elderly and those who have a weak health will have to avoid rush hours to travel; those aged under 18 will be able to go out; day care centres and nurseries will be allowed to operate; and trades such as supermarkets will be able to operate on a normal hour basis without having to necessarily respect the alphabetical order rule."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200617152934/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Covid-19-Mauritius-to-lift-curfew-on-30-May-2020,-at-midnight,-says-PM.aspx
notes_C5: "As for public transport, it will return to its central role in moving the greatest number of commuters as social distancing will not be applicable as from 15 June 2020. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20200617154020/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Covid-19-We-should-be-proud-of-the-way-we-have-tackled-the-situation,-says-PM.aspx

name: Malawi
notes_H1: Already on 7 March, the government of Malawi called for a special cabinet to be formed on the issue of the coronavirus, including several ministers. From that day onwards (without any confirmed cases in the country), the government has shared information about the symptoms of the virus, how to debunk myths, how to protect oneself, etc. https://twitter.com/malawigovt. If Twitter were to be the only channel for the public information campaign, I would have coded it as targeted (internet penetration rate likely low and only around 20,000 followers despite 18m inhabitants), but the special cabinet is likely to have used other channels for information dissemination as well, Twitter is just the most visible externally.
notes_H3: Contact tracing is happening for all confirmed cases
notes_H2: No restrictions appear to be in place for testing anyone could undergo testing  http://web.archive.org/web/20201026213053/https://www.unicef.org/malawi/documents/unicef-malawi-covid-19-situation-report-7-april
notes_C8: Land borders are closed, per the US Embassy in Malawi - "All land borders are closed for two weeks (14 days) starting December 23, 2020, except for essential goods transporters, deportees, and those in special circumstances. Malawians and residents can return to Malawi upon production of an original certified negative COVID-19 test result. Foreigners may not travel to Malawi via land boarders."     Malawians and residents are permitted to enter via air, subject to production of a negative PCR test certificate obtained within the 10 days prior to arrival, possible testing on arrival, and self-monitoring for 14 days after arrival. Details at https://web.archive.org/web/20210104064606/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: Per press statement from the Government of Malawi issues on December 22 2020 and effective December 23 2020 for a period of 14 days, gatherings are restricted to a maximum of 100 people.  https://archive.vn/PaNz7
notes_C1: Malawi's Education Ministry announced a phased approach to reopening of schools on 28 August, with priority given to Examination classes:    Monday, 7th September, 2020  1. Initial Primary Teacher Education to complete registration processes for examinations;  2. Final Year Students at colleges, universities and examination classes for all schools that offer International curriculum;    Sunday, 20th September, 2020  1. Initial Primary Teacher Education to report to colleges on 20th September;  Phased Re-Opening of Colleges, Universities and International Schools  2. Colleges, universities and schools that offer International curriculum will be allowed to take the second phase of students after three weeks from the day of re-opening (week beginning 28th September, 2020;  3. Since colleges and universities are at different stages, each institution will have to decide which group will have to go first in consultation with the Ministry.    https://archive.vn/g7QwJ
notes_H6: Wearing of face masks is mandatory in all public spaces and offenders could be fined up to $13 (£10).  https://archive.vn/DESep
notes_C2: The majority of shops, banks and restaurants continue to operate, with some restrictions and coronavirus precautionary measures in place. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200608130226/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/malawi/entry-requirements
notes_E2: From the 9th of April, Malawian banks stopped payments of premiums and loans for a period of three months. All fees for bank transactions were reduced by for that time period to encourage cashless transactions. Other debt relief plans include restructuring small and medium enterprise loans on case by case basis. An emergency liquidity assistance facility has also been introduced for banks as well.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200615203156/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20200615203203/https://malawi24.com/2020/04/10/malawi-banks-suspend-loan-repayments/
notes_E1: No indication this was extended to January. According to the IMF, "an Emergency Cash Transfer Program of about $50 million (0.5 percent of GDP), mostly financed by development partners, is being implemented during May-November." See: https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 [web archive unavailable, accessed 11 January 2021]
notes_C3: Per press statement from the Government of Malawi issued on December 22 2020 and effective December 23 2020 for a period of 14 days, public events are restricted to a maximum of 100 people who must wear face masks. "Venue owners are asked to comply with this restriction and must ensure that only up to 100 people are at venue functions. Venues shall include but limited to the following: hotels, lodges, ceremony gardens or parks." https://archive.vn/PaNz7
notes_C6: As per this article, the people have emphatically refused any harsh measures including forced lockdown.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201026204505/https://www.thinkglobalhealth.org/article/coronavirus-malawi

name: Malaysia
notes_H1: Director-General of Health's press statement regarding the novel coronavirus; preparatory steps taken to deal with potential spreading of the disease [https://web.archive.org/web/20200403225553/https://kpkesihatan.com/2020/01/16/kenyataan-akhbar-kpk-16-januari-2020-kesiapsiagaan-dan-respons-kkm-dalam-menghadapi-potensi-penularan-novel-coronavirus-wuhan-china/]
notes_H3: Following information received from Singaporean counterparts, Malaysia's Ministry of Health conducted contact tracing on 8 Chinese nationals known to have close contact with a Covid patient. [https://web.archive.org/web/20200403233957/https://kpkesihatan.com/2020/01/24/kenyataan-akhbar-kpk-24-januari-2020-tindakan-kkm-bagi-pengesanan-kontak-contact-tracing-kepada-kes-pertama-positif-novel-coronavirus-di-negara-singapura-pada-24-januari-2020/]
notes_H2: To access the new service, patients will have to pre-register and book an appointment online https://web.archive.org/web/20200505120742/https://www.zdnet.com/article/malaysia-to-get-quicker-access-to-covid-19-tests-results/ “A private laboratory consortium in Malaysia is rolling out a nationwide COVID-19 collection and testing programme that aims to conduct more than 5,000 tests a day, with a 24-hour turnaround time. Touted to be the country's largest such collection and testing scheme, it is set to begin as a drive-through service in Klang.”
notes_C7: 'On 11 January, the Malaysian government announced increased and varying restrictions, depending on which state you are in, to enter force at 12:01am, Wednesday 13 January.  Inter-state travel is not permitted across Malaysia. [Inter-district travel is not permitted in Kuala Lumpur, Johor, Labuan, Melaka, Penang, Putrajaya, Sabah, and Selangor. Roadblocks will operate at state boundaries; in addition in these states journeys will be limited to 10km radius].  Internal flights from Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) and Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah Airport (also known as Subang Airport) are operating as usual, but services could be reduced without notice.'    https://archive.vn/oB3e6
notes_C8: Travel Restrictions most foreigners remain banned from entering Malaysia; exemptions are in place for resident diplomats, foreign spouses and dependents of Malaysian citizens, long-term pass holders, and expatriate employees working in essential industries and their dependents, among others.     Arriving expatriate employees must present an approval letter from authorities. Travelers must test for COVID-19 upon arrival. Those testing positive will undergo treatment at medical facilities, while those testing negative will quarantine for 14 days at designated locations.     Travelers must also download the MySejahtera contact tracing application. Foreigners may transit at Malaysian airports as long as they do not pass through immigration points.     Malaysian nationals remain banned from traveling abroad, with limited exceptions. Emergency repatriation of citizens may occur on a case-by-case basis.    Malaysia allows limited cross-border travel with Singapore for business and official purposes. Under the Reciprocal Green Lane (RGL) scheme, people can travel short-term from Singapore to Malaysia with an exemption from normal quarantine requirements for arrivals. The travelers must present approval letters from immigration authorities and a company or government agency in Malaysia, obtain visas if required, and test for COVID-19 within 72 hours before travel and upon arrival. Such travelers must comply with a controlled itinerary for the first 14 days and contact tracing measures. Additionally, in the Periodic Commuting Arrangement (PCA) scheme for long-term work visa holders, only people traveling to Johor State can quarantine at their residence or accommodations for seven days upon arrival, while those going to other Malaysian states must isolate at government-designated facilities for a week. Travelers can leave the quarantine sites upon testing negative for COVID-19. The PCA program allows the travelers to undertake multiple-entry visits through land border crossings at Woodlands or Tuas for 90-day stays once their applications are approved. Travelers are eligible for a home leave of two to four weeks after every minimum stay of 90 days in the country where they work.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221170524/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/409741/malaysia-covid-19-restrictions-adjusted-in-most-states-as-of-dec-7-update-18
notes_C4: Several areas of the country are currently under different stages of lockdown. For example, the Klang Valley area has been under a lockdown since mid-October that sees office employees having to work from home, while sporting matches including those of football have been prohibited, with training limited to only groups of 10.    https://archive.vn/vCzDk#selection-1455.0-1455.327
notes_C1: The government’s decision to close all schools, even in states not currently under the latest conditional movement control order (CMCO), is to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, Education Minister Mohd Radzi Md Jidin explained today.    https://archive.vn/BK4dl
notes_C2: 'On 11 January 2021, Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced that Movement Control Order restrictions would be re-introduced to the states of Malacca, Johor, Penang, Selangor, Sabah and the federal territories of Kuala Lumpur, Putrajaya, and Labuan between 13 until 26 January 2021. [In these states, only] five essential economic sectors [are] allowed to operate: manufacturing, construction, services (including supermarkets, banks and health services), trade and distribution and plantations.'    https://archive.vn/pNb3q
notes_E2: All banks will provide an automatic deferment of all loan/financing repayments for a period of 6 months, with effect from 1 April 2020.  This applies to performing loans that have not been in arrears for more than 90 days as at 1 April 2020. Interest will continue to accrue unless otherwise informed by the bank. [https://web.archive.org/web/20200430210908/https://www.bnm.gov.my/covid19/indiv.php; https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.malaymail.com/news/malaysia/2020/03/24/bank-negara-announces-automatic-six-month-moratorium-on-all-bank-loans-exce/1849820]
notes_E1: On 27 March, the government announced the Prihatin Rakyat Economic Stimulus Package which includes the following direct cash payments and wage subsidy programme: (1) One-off cash assistance to the bottom 40% and middle 40% income groups including the following payments: RM1,600 to nearly 4 million households earning less than RM4,000 a month, RM1,000 to nearly 1.1 million households earning between RM4,000-RM8,000 a month; RM800 to 3 million single individuals aged 21 and above, earning less than RM2,000 a month; RM500 to 400,000 single individuals aged 21 years and above, earning between RM2,000 and RM4,000 per month. (2) One-off cash assistance of RM500 to more than 1.5 million civil servants. (3) Wage Subsidy Programme: the Government will provide salary of RM600 per month to every employee for 3 months. This programme is dedicated to workers earning less than RM4,000 and employers experiencing more than 50% decrease in their income since 1 January 2020. Employers must ensure that there is no retrenchment or imposing unpaid leave or forcing a wage cut for the next 3 months after the implementation of the programme. (4) One- off cash assistance of RM500 to 120,000 e-hailing drivers with a total allocation of RM60 million. [https://web.archive.org/web/20200406182401/https://www.nst.com.my/news/nation/2020/04/581256/prihatin-rakyat-financial-aid-fast-tracked-first-payment-now-set-monday]    On 4 April, the Minister of Finance announced that the above financial aid disbursements will be made starting 6 April [https://web.archive.org/web/20200406182401/https:/www.nst.com.my/news/nation/2020/04/581256/prihatin-rakyat-financial-aid-fast-tracked-first-payment-now-set-monday]    On 6 April, the Prime Minister announced further measures on the Wage Subsidy Programme which will be expanded from RM5.9 billion to RM13.8 billion. Under this additional initiative, all companies with local employees earning a monthly salary each of RM4,000 and below will receive wage subsidies as follows: (a) For companies with a workforce of more than 200 people, a wage subsidy of RM600 per month for every retained worker will be provided. The maximum number of workers that a company is eligible to claim for will be increased from 100 to 200 employees. (b) For companies with employees between 75 to 200 people, they will receive a wage subsidy of RM800 per month for every employee. (c) Finally, for companies with employees of less than 75 people, the government will provide a wage subsidy of RM1,200 per month per employee. This assistance is for a 3-month period and is specifically for employers registered with the Companies Commission of Malaysia (SSM) or local authorities before 1 January 2020 and are registered with the Social Security Organisation (SOCSO). It is estimated that 4.8 million employees will benefit from this initiative. For employers opting to accept this assistance, they are required to retain their employees at least for a period of 6 months, that is 3 months during the period receiving the subsidies and 3 months thereafter.
notes_C3: 'On 11 January 2021, Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced that Movement Control Order restrictions would be re-introduced to the states of Malacca, Johor, Penang, Selangor, Sabah and the federal territories of Kuala Lumpur, Putrajaya, and Labuan between 13 until 26 January 2021. [In these states,] social gatherings and events, including weddings, seminars, and sports, are banned. ... Five person limit at mosques and other places of worship.'    https://archive.vn/pNb3q
notes_C6: From 14 to 27 October, for residents in Malaysia's capital city of Kuala Lumpur, administrative capital Putrajaya and in the states of Selangor and Sabah, 'only two members of each household will be permitted to leave the house at one time to buy necessities.'    https://archive.vn/qVzSM
notes_C5: Public transport can operate with protocols in place, such as requiring passengers to undergo temperature checks and wear facemasks.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201221170524/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/409741/malaysia-covid-19-restrictions-adjusted-in-most-states-as-of-dec-7-update-18

name: Namibia
notes_H1: In State of Emergency declaration: "Public awareness messages and campaigns should be intensified using all media avenues and platforms to reach every community member in all regions" https://web.archive.org/web/20200318152700/https://allafrica.com/stories/202003171066.html
notes_H3: Contact tracing begins as Namibia records its first case. See: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.iol.co.za/news/africa/namibia-confirms-two-covid-19-cases-44882925. Also: https://web.archive.org/save/https://allafrica.com/stories/202003220035.html
notes_H2: All persons meeting the standard case definition for COVID-19 must be subject to testing.     No change to previous policy as announced in the "Public Health and Covid-19 General Regulations" (https://web.archive.org/web/20201130134825/https://sistemas.mre.gov.br/kitweb/datafiles/Windhoek/pt-br/file/namibia%20-%20govt%20notice%20233%20-%20mohss%20-%20public%20health%20covid-19%20regulations%20-%2023%20set%2020.pdf) on 23 September 2020.
notes_C7: Movement Restrictions:  Is a curfew in place? No  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No    https://web.archive.org/save/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Arriving international tourists do not have to quarantine if they present a negative COVID-19 PCR test result that is not older than 7 days.  However, non-Namibian travelers arriving with a negative result that is older than 7 days will be placed in quarantine and tested for COVID-19 on the same day at their own cost.  If the results of this test come out negative, they will be released from quarantine.  If positive, they will be isolated at their own cost, according to Namibia’s isolation protocols.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220105/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: Gatherings reduced from the previous limit of 200 persons to 50 persons indoors and 100 persons outdoors. It is a requirement that conveners and organisers of such gatherings keep registers of attendees at each gathering, record body temperatures of attendees in such registers and provide facilities for guests to wash their hands with soap or to sanitise their hands. Physical distancing of no less than 1.5 metres between persons must be maintained at all times.    See "Statement by His Excellency Dr Hage G. Geibgob on the Occasion of the 21st Covid-19 Public Briefing on the National Response and Preparedness" (https://web.archive.org/web/20210103031033/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/Statement+by+President+Hage+G.+Geingob%2C+21st+COVID19+Update+16+December+2020.pdf/f9e5acbc-a5a1-40ea-a43e-b902d326d97c) which amended Public Health COVID-19 Regulations effective from 23:59 Wednesday 16 December 2020.
notes_C1: E-learning. Schools closed to Covid19 Per UNESCO https://web.archive.org/web/20210124213726/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H6: According to reports from Wednesday (03 June), the third phase of the Namibian government's easing plan will last until 29 June. During this phase, a protective mask must be worn in all public places.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201015084751/https://global-monitoring.com/gm/page/events/epidemic-0002091.QA7Ft6UbMq4Q.html?lang=en
notes_C2: According to the REPUBLIC OF NAMIBIA website. 9. (1) Heads of the institutions are encouraged to allow vulnerable employees to work from home, subject to suitable arrangements between the employer and employee.(2) Heads of the institutions are encouraged to provide masks to their employees.(3) Heads of the institutions must ensure that their employees at all times adhere to the measures to combat, prevent and suppress the spread of COVID-19  https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/775250/%237255-Proc+N28%285%29.pdf/d3242236-19d6-48f4-8691-ff393360e9da       /web/20201018195410/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-10/06/c_139422633.htm
notes_E2: No debit relief for households. https://web.archive.org/web/20201115194555/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: Adjustment. Income support is a one time payment in April.   April 1, 2020 A one-time emergency income grant of N$750 to employees who have lost their jobs due to the pandemic and its fallout, limited to a maximum of N$562 million in total. Only Namibian citizens between the ages of 18 and 60 years old who do not receive any other social grants qualify for this grant. Payments will be by the Government in collaboration with the Social Security Commission.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201115200350/https://www.ey.com/en_gl/tax-alerts/namibia-announces-economic-stimulus-and-relief-package-to-mitigate-impact-of-covid-19
notes_C3: No measures in place to cancel public events, but restrictions to the number of persons allowed apply. A maximum of 200 persons are allowed and all gatherings are encouraged to be outdoors. Registers of attendees at such gatherings and events must be maintained.     See "Update by Dr Kalumbi Shangula, Minister of Health and Social Services on COVID-19 in Namibia" (https://web.archive.org/web/20210103082747/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/COVID-19+Daily+Update+15.12.2020.pdf/ee7fa02d-edf1-48b4-b6fb-7079b54f6025), which emphasises the importance of observing COVID-19 prevention measures. Previous COVID-19 measures were announced on 30 November 2020 (https://web.archive.org/web/20210103080555/https://namibiatourism.com.na/uploads/file_uploads/30.11.2020_Statement%20by%20H.E.%20President%20Dr%20Hage%20Geingob%20on%20the%20occasion%20of%20the%2020th%20Public%20Briefing%20on%20the%20National%20Response%20Measures_COVID-19.pdf).
notes_C6: Mask requirements. Is a curfew in place? A nationwide curfew is in place between 9:00 pm and 4:00 am daily.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220105/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: Public transport open with requirements in place. Drivers and passengers must wear masks, owners/operators must provide alcohol-based hand sanitisers and must regularly disinfect the vehicle. Social distancing and passenger number restrictions also in place.     See "Update by Dr Kalumbi Shangula, Minister of Health and Social Services on COVID-19 in Namibia" (https://web.archive.org/web/20210103082747/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/COVID-19+Daily+Update+15.12.2020.pdf/ee7fa02d-edf1-48b4-b6fb-7079b54f6025), which emphasises the importance of observing COVID-19 prevention measures. Previous measures were announced in the "Public Health and Covid-19 General Regulations" on 23 September 2020 (https://web.archive.org/web/20201130134825/https://sistemas.mre.gov.br/kitweb/datafiles/Windhoek/pt-br/file/namibia%20-%20govt%20notice%20233%20-%20mohss%20-%20public%20health%20covid-19%20regulations%20-%2023%20set%2020.pdf).

name: Niger
notes_H1: There is a campaign for the measures to help curb the virus. This is video from the website of the Ministry of Health on COVID-19. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20201115201433/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ogx3nXb_voM&feature=youtu.be
notes_H3: No evidence that contract tracing is occurring.  No mention.     https://coronavirus.ne/test-covid-19/
notes_H2: The testing is available at a cost according to the US embassy in Niger's website;    The Center for Medical Research and Health (CERMES) started conducting tests on Saturday, August 1, 2020. It takes about 24 to 48 hours for results to be issued.  You can call between 8 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. to make an appointment.  The contact information is listed below.  Once a certificate of the test result is issued, it will be valid for 72 hours.  Location: Google Maps    Centre de Recherches Médicales et Sanitaires  BP 10887 – Niamey YN034 Niger  Phone: 20752040 / 20752045 / 88526448 / 80090111    Cost    Rapid Test: 7,500 FCFA  PCR Test: 30,000 FCFA    Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20201021222926/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: There are no restrictions according to the website of the US embassy in Niger. Please see:    https://web.archive.org/web/20201021222926/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201021222926/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: All travellers entering Niger from countries suffering from the COVID-19 must self-quarantine in their homes or in another adequate location for a period of 14 days.    A rapid COVID-19 test and a nasal swab may be taken from passengers upon arrival and passengers will be encouraged to self-quarantine at a precise address.  Niger will fine airlines for boarding passengers who do not have a valid certificate of a negative test result taken within the previous 72 hours.    All people testing positive for COVID-19 at the airports will be led automatically to a governmental quarantine site.  Foreign nationals who refuse a COVID-19 test at the airport will be denied entry into Niger and turned back to the airlines.  Nigerien nationals who refuse a test at the airport will have their passports seized by the Nigerien police.  The Center for Medical Research and Health (CERMES) started conducting tests on Saturday, August 1, 2020. It takes about 24 to 48 hours for results to be issued.  You can call between 8 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. to make an appointment.  The contact information is listed below.  Once a certificate of the test result is issued, it will be valid for 72 hours.    Links: https://web.archive.org/web/20201101155814/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201011201056/https://coronavirus.ne/quarantaine/#
notes_C4: Effective December 24, bars, night clubs, and performance venues are closed for a renewable, two-week period.  Large gatherings for weddings, funerals, and baptisms are banned.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201223160909/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: According to UNESCO schools in Niger are fully open.  Source:
notes_H6: It is mandatory to wear a face mask or other objects that cover the mouth and nose in Niamey in public places, markets, and urban transport. This is according to the US embassy in Niger's website. There was information on Niamey and not all parts of the country.    Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20201021222926/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: According to the UK government's website on travel to Niger, some hotels are open with social distancing measures in place.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115203759/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/niger/coronavirus  Restaurants, shops and bars are open with social distancing measures in place.
notes_E2: An updated crisis response plan has been presented to donors with an estimated cost of 18.4 percent of GDP, divided into an immediate health response and broader economic and social mitigation. Key elements are already being implemented, such as food distribution, two months of free utilities to the vulnerable households and temporary tax relief for hard-hit sectors.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118160006/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Restriction on gatherings will affect public events
notes_C6: There are no curfews nor confinements. There is requirement to use masks and practice social distancing. Please see:    https://web.archive.org/web/20201021222926/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

name: Nigeria
notes_H1: From 31 Jan, with the CDC issuing second Public Health Advisory, it started taking shape of a coordinated information campaign. Here, guidelines for healthcare workers were provided and a toll free number was provided along with general awareness info for the public. https://web.archive.org/web/20200412203307/https://ncdc.gov.ng/news/219/31st-january-2020%257C-public-health-advisory-to-nigerians-on-novel-coronavirus-%2528%25232%2529    Subsequently, NCDC also launched a WhatsApp APL, a free to use service to provide a central source of accurate, verified and current information on COVID-19 in Nigeria.; https://statehouse.gov.ng/news/covid-19-what-president-buhari-has-done-and-is-doingby-presidency/ (not archivable)
notes_H3: Nigeria records first case of COVID 19: NCDC digital tool for surveillance, SORMAS, is being used to manage contact tracing and related activities to quickly control the spread of the disease. Contact tracing is ongoing to identify everyone who has come in contact with the confirmed case. https://web.archive.org/web/20200412212133/https://ncdc.gov.ng/news/item/232/?t=frequently-asked-questions-on-coronavirus---29%252F02%252F20 https://web.archive.org/web/20200412213346/https://ncdc.gov.ng/reports/246/2020-february-week-7
notes_H2: As of July, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) defined 13 categories of cases which should be prioritized for testing. People who are not in one of these categories are considered low-risk and should therefore remain in self-isolation for 14 days, and inform the State Response Team if they develop any symptoms prior to testing.     Source:  NCDC "Strategies to Improve Surveillance for COVID-19: Guidance for States", pp. 2-4  https://web.archive.org/web/20200726071942/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/media/files/SurveillanceStrategies.pdf
notes_C7: Some domestic flights resumed since July 8th. https://web.archive.org/web/20200925012541/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nigeria/coronavirus
notes_C8: ON ARRIVAL IN NIGERIA  Passengers who have arrived in Nigeria must self-isolate for 14 days and remain in the city/state where the point of entry is located (i.e. Lagos or Abuja) throughout the duration of self-isolation  Passengers must provide their correct address and phone number before exiting the airport. They must comply with self-isolation/quarantine guidelines and ensure that they can be reached during the period  Passengers not resident in Lagos or Abuja must arrange for accommodation at their own cost (please note that the Federal Government will not be responsible for providing accommodation nor transportation to the place of abode)  Passengers will be cleared through the Nigeria Immigration System’s Migrants Identification Data Analysis System (MIDAS) and their passports retained until after successful completion of the 14 days self-isolation (this why correct contact information must be provided)  All passengers will be tested within 72 hours of arrival based on appointment at a sample collection centre located in Lagos or Abuja for a repeat COVID-19 PCR test  Persons who are unable to remain in Lagos or Abuja throughout the period of self-quarantine may return to their states of residence ONLY after:       (a) They have had their samples collected and are NEGATIVE for COVID-19, and    (b) They have provided public health officials with their full and correct address and phone number where they can be reached    Persons who have completed the 14 days of self-isolation/quarantine will undergo an exit interview. Their details will be forwarded to the Nigeria Immigration Service for release of their passports. Alternative arrangements can be made to collect passports via special delivery e.g. DHL  At the seaports, ships arriving are subjected to mandatory health screening and clearance by the Port Health Services. This particularly applies to ships that have been at sea for less than 14 days and/or that have crew members who are ill.    Source:http://web.archive.org/web/20200821231028/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/advisory/
notes_C4: On 29 July the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 announced the extension of Phase Two of the eased lockdown, therefore the prohibition of gatherings of more than 20 people outside of a workplace remain in place.    Source:  The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control website  https://web.archive.org/web/20200812053903/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/advisory/
notes_C1: On 21 December, the Nigerian Government announced that schools will remain closed until at least 18 January 2021.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210103223527/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nigeria/coronavirus
notes_H6: Government Twitter says 'mandatory use of non-medical masks outdoors'- 7 May      https://web.archive.org/web/20201015090445/https://twitter.com/NCDCgov/status/1258441725472841729/photo/1    BBC Article about Nigeria lockdown says 'But to limit the spread of Covid-19, the (the president)  announced that the government would impose a curfew across the country between 20:00 and 06:00, require everyone to wear face masks in public, and stop "non-essential inter-state passenger travel".' as of 4 May, which warrants a 3 coding    https://web.archive.org/web/20201015091337/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-52445414
notes_C2: "...Federal and State government offices to operate normal working hours, but only essential staff from GL.12 and above can resume work  Limit government meetings to virtual as much as possible while maintaining restrictions on physical meetings including official trips, oversight visits and board meetings until further notice...    ADVICE FOR BUSINESSES  The NCDC has published a guideline for employers and businesses in Nigeria however, the agency is working with various industries to develop sector-specific guidelines as the financial sector and manufacturing industry is fully open while the informal sector will have a phased opening."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200821231028/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/advisory/
notes_E2: On the contrary, the Nigerian government decided that regulated fuel prices be reduced, and an automatic fuel price formula introduced to ensure fuel subsidies are eliminated. Electricity tariff was increased.     Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201108130923/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: According to the IMF;  The social register was increased by 1 million households to 3.6 million to help cushion the effect of the lockdown. A broader economic stimulus plan that includes the N500 billion COVID-19 intervention fund was introduced to support the real sector.     At the time of this reporting, it was not expressly determined if the support is still ongoing.     Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201108130923/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: "Limit government meetings to virtual as much as possible while maintaining restrictions on physical meetings including official trips, oversight visits and board meetings until further notice  Lifting of restrictions on outdoor communal sports and opening of recreational parks for supervised exercise  Mandatory use of non-medical facemasks in public spaces with access to government and commercial premises to be denied for persons not wearing facemasks. ‘No mask, no entry. No mask, no service.’  Maintaining the prohibition of gathering of more than twenty (20) persons outside of a workplace"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200821231028/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/advisory/
notes_C6: Curfew: Imposition of overnight curfew nationwide from 8pm to 6am.  General movement:  May go out for work, to buy necessary foods and for exercise; Persons above age of 65 years and those with underlying chronic illness e.g. diabetes, high blood pressure are advised to remain at home    https://web.archive.org/web/20200525230111/http://statehouse.gov.ng/covid19/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/IMPLEMENTATION-GUIDELINES-FOR-EASING-LOCKDOWN-Phase-1-May-4-to-May-17-2020.pdf    Please also see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201108141902/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/04/27/nigeria-buhari-to-unwind-covid-19-lockdown-in-key-states/?gb=true
notes_C5: Transportation Options:  Are commercial flights operating? Yes  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Passengers must wear face masks when taking public transportation.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201004075437/https://ng.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
