notes_C8: Updating indicator based on Decree Law No. 1 of 2021 published on 5 January 2021, which states that starting 7 January through 16 January, travel to and from San Marino in the Italian Regions where restrictive measures of containment of a high epidemiological risk of maximum severity (red zones) are prohibited except for proven work needs, health reasons or situations of need.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110184644/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49121874.html
notes_C4: max 6 persons for private gatherings
notes_C1: schools reopen after christmas break, high schools still on virtual learning  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110184644/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49121874.html
notes_H6: "open spaces also are allowed provided they are in static form, it is expected to use requirement of protective equipment"  http://web.archive.org/web/20201101201343/https://www.sanmarinortv.sm/news/attualita-c4/san-marino-emesso-il-decreto-n-193-in-vigore-dalle-18-di-venerdi-a196334  May not be very reliable : http://web.archive.org/web/20201101213116/https://www.tripsguard.com/destination/san-marino/
notes_C2: bars and restaurants are closed from Dec 25th to Jan 6th included  https://web.archive.org/web/20210103183934/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49121722.html
notes_E2: The key measures approved by the government include: i) suspension of payment deadlines for government tax and non-tax obligations, utility bills, and other dues to provide liquidity to the private sector; ii) temporary freeze of all non-essential government spending and reduction in public sector wage bill to redirect spending to the health sector; and iii) extension of supplemental wage scheme to support workers displaced by COVID-19 containment measures; iv) deferral of income tax payment; v)minimum guaranteed income for poorer households; vi) other measures to support businesses, including tax credits, tax payments postponement and rescheduling. Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200729163904/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: "Viene introdotto, "dal 1° marzo 2020 e fino alla data di cessazione della emergenza sanitaria", il reddito minimo garantito per le famiglie, "già costituiti alla data del 1° marzo 2020, anche se composti da una persona sola, che si trovano in stato di difficoltà economica e con insufficienti mezzi di sostentamento". L'importo erogato alle famiglie bisognose sarà di 580 euro mensili per ogni nucleo familiare, maggiorato di 150 euro per il coniuge o per il convivente more uxorio o per il contraente l’unione civile, e di 50 euro per ogni altro convivente del nucleo familiare." Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200606125817/http://www.libertas.sm/notizie/2020/04/22/san-marino-coronavirus-decreto-a-favore-di-imprese-operatori-lavoratori-e-famiglie.html
notes_C3: Updating indicator to 2G to adhere to guidance of when private gatherings of only 10 or less are permitted (e.g. C4=4), this restriction would prevent public events from taking place, so they are recorded as required to cancel.    According to the Decree Law No. 1 of 2021 published on 5 January 2021, starting 7 January through 16 January, for presence at private homes, the following are referred to in Article 1, paragraph 6 Decree - Law no. 206/2020, which states it is strongly recommended to avoid lunches, dinners, aperitifs and in any case any other situation which involves the convivial aggregation of more than four people not belonging to the same cohabiting unit at private homes except for family support needs.    Since the referenced Decree went into effect on 27 November 2020, I'm back-dating the indicator to that date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110184644/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49121874.html
notes_C6: From Dec 18 until new measures are announced, a curfew is in place from 00.30 am to 06.00 am, except for people who need to go out for work reasons, or have health emergencies  https://web.archive.org/web/20201220183153/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49121647.html
notes_C5: Public transportation has been restablished on May 4. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200517044419/https://www.sanmarinortv.sm/news/comunicati-c9/start-romagna-da-lunedi-via-alla-fase-2-del-trasporto-pubblico-locale-in-romagna-a187741

name: Somalia
notes_H1: Coordinated public health campaign includes website updates, a twitter feed, and a WhatsApp chat bot with up-to-date COVID information. It is unclear when this campaign was put in place.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201113104455/https://moh.gov.so/en/    Other reports describe:    "The Somali authorities have ramped up a national public information campaign on COVID-19, using both traditional and new ways of reaching the public. This includes using radio, billboards and outdoor posters to alert and inform citizens about coronavirus symptoms and preventive measures and guidelines, as well as social media platforms."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201107150711/https://www.un.org/ru/node/79362    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113105214/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/COVID19_Oct_2020.pdf
notes_H3: According to the US embassy website, Somali authorities have established a quarantine unit at Aden Adde International Airport (AAIA) in Mogadishu to isolate passengers who demonstrate symptoms of coronavirus.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200829182419/https://so.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H2: "Since then the WHO country office has shipped over 150 samples collected from different parts of the country to KEMRI and many of them have tested positive. Considering that the country would need to build its testing capacity rapidly for COVID-19 and decentralize laboratory testing in order to rapidly isolate and treat cases while tracking close contacts in line with WHO’s strategy to “Test, track and treat” for detecting and preventing community transmission, 3 laboratories with molecular testing facility were rapidly established by WHO in April with the financial support from the Italian Development Cooperation. These laboratories were established in Mogadishu, Garowe and Hargeisa."         https://archive.fo/U23qj
notes_C7: As of October 16th, 2020, there are no restrictions on internal movement between cities or states:    https://web.archive.org/web/20201112205511/https://so.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19)  Screening on arrival – Somalia  A negative COVID-19 negative test, taken no more than 96 hours before travel, is required for entry into Somalia.    Screening on departure – Somalia  A negative COVID-19 test, taken no more than 72 hours before travel, is required for exit from Somalia.    Screening on arrival - Somaliland  A negative COVID-19 test, taken no more than 96 hours before travel, is required for entry into Somaliland. If you do not have this evidence on arrival, then you may have to spend 14 days in quarantine at your own expense in a government approved facility.    Egal International Airport has put in place additional measures to screen passengers arriving into Hargeisa by air, including temperature checks.    Those people displaying symptoms linked to the virus may be transferred to a nearby isolation facility while further tests are carried out.    Land borders  Restrictions remain in place in neighbouring countries, including land border closures and quarantine measures. You should check before travelling to the borders of Ethiopia, Djibouti or Kenya.    https://archive.fo/iultK
notes_C4: According to a Voa News article from January 3rd, restrictions on gatherings are no longer enforced or followed:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210109220248/https://www.voanews.com/africa/somalia-covid-19-vaccines-are-distant-virus-spreads
notes_C1: While it is difficult to find recent official reports, no policy change has been identified. It appears that even restrictions that are in place are not being followed to a significant extent. Moreover, recent reporting suggests that no restrictions are in place at all for schools at the present moment:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124155745/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/432306/somalia-authorities-maintain-coronavirus-disease-restrictions-as-of-jan-20-update-8    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124160228/https://floridanewstimes.com/in-somalia-the-covid-19-vaccine-is-farther-away-as-the-virus-spreads/76664/
notes_H6: It appears that there is no national guidance on mandatory mask wearing, but that masks are required under public health guidance in some public places like schools:    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113105214/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/COVID19_Oct_2020.pdf
notes_C2: As of October 26, "most business operations" have resumed.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201112204135/https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/traveladvisories/somalia-travel-advisory.html
notes_E2: The three-month tax holiday that started on April 15th would  have ended by July 15th. This perhaps should be coded 0 since July. See: https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 (web archive not available, accessed 10th September 2020)
notes_C3: According ot a Voa News article posted on January 3rd, 2021, public events are no longer cancelled. A recent football match hosted 30,000 attendees.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210109220248/https://www.voanews.com/africa/somalia-covid-19-vaccines-are-distant-virus-spreads
notes_C6: While it is difficult to find recent official reports, no policy change has been identified. It appears that even restrictions that are in place are not being followed to a significant extent:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210124155745/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/432306/somalia-authorities-maintain-coronavirus-disease-restrictions-as-of-jan-20-update-8    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124160228/https://floridanewstimes.com/in-somalia-the-covid-19-vaccine-is-farther-away-as-the-virus-spreads/76664/

name: Serbia
notes_H1: Government launches Coronavirus website: https://covid19.rs/
notes_H3: Predrag Kon (head of the Infectious Diseases Unit of the City Institute of Public Health and government spokesperson on epidemiology): "some parts of the health care system will be severely burdened simply because it is necessary to trace all those contacts. In this case, fortunately, because of his self-isolation and his independent decision to quarantine, we do not have such a huge number [of cases]"  -> This indicates the presence of comprehensive contact tracing for the first contact.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200407232501/https://balkaninsight.com/2020/03/06/serbia-confirms-first-case-of-coronavirus/
notes_H2: The Ministry of Health published a list of health centers where people showing COVID-19 symptoms get COVID-19 PCR tests.   Link: https://archive.fo/wip/JCFv8
notes_C7: PM explained that the introduction of more stringent measures was necessary, and expressed hope that in five to ten days they will contribute to reducing the number of infected people in Belgrade, where the situation is the most critical.    According to her, a ban on movement and curfew would undoubtedly be the most effective measure, because it was already seen in March and April that it contributed to reducing the number of infected people in a short time.  Linkhttps://web.archive.org/web/20200718091317/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/158523/restrictive-measures-to-help-curb-coronavirus.php
notes_C8: "Deputy Director of the Institute of Public Health of Serbia "Dr Milan Jovanovic Batut" Darija Kisic Tepavcevic said that the COVID-19 crisis response team proposed to the government to make a decision that all citizens coming to Serbia from the territory of Croatia, North Macedonia, Bulgaria and Romania should have a negative PCR test that is not older than 48 hours.    In a statement to the press after the session of the COVID-19 crisis response team, she explained that the decision is valid from tomorrow,15 August, and does not refer to our citizens who come from the territory of those countries."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200817062634/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/159955/mandatory-pcr-test-for-citizens-of-four-neighbouring-countries.php
notes_C4: No major changes    6-Nov - Ban on gathering of more than five persons introduced - the number of persons that can gather in an open and closed space reduced from 30 to five.    Link 1 - https://archive.fo/vfyta  Link 2 - https://web.archive.org/web/20201116224059/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/163210/ban-on-gathering-of-more-than-five-persons-introduced.php
notes_C1: The Education Ministry said earlier that elementary and high schools would reopen using the same model for classes that was in place since September 1 which means that elementary school children in grades 1 to 4 will go to school every day in smaller groups while grades 5 to 8 will go to school every other day and online. High school students will either go to school one week and have online classes every other week or stay at home for online schooling to the end of the year. Classes will be 30 minutes long instead of the customary 45 and the school year will be five days longerr because of the coronavirus pandemic.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210118234843/https://rs.n1info.com/english/news/serbian-schools-start-second-semester-teachers-unhappy/
notes_H6: "The use of face coverings is required in all indoor locations, as well as outdoors when required physical distancing is not possible, for example waiting in line to enter stores or at bus stops.  Face coverings are recommended elsewhere outdoors."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200921080116/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/
notes_C2: On July 1 in response to a new wave of infections, the government introduced new measures including limiting hours of operation for restaurants and bars; and closure of swimming pools, spa and wellness centres.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200903125436/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E2: The Minister of Finance announced the deferral of payment of payroll taxes and contributions for all private companies during the state of emergency, and for a minimum of three months, deferral of payment of income tax for the second quarter of 2020 and exemption from VAT for all those who donate and deal with donations. Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200501000306/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/152964/state-sets-aside-51b-to-mitigate-coronavirus-economic-blow.php
notes_E1: The Government of the Republic of Serbia launched the second aid package on 30 July. 'This package includes the payment of 60 percent of the minimum wage twice , as well as the postponement of taxes and contributions on wages for one month, and it is worth 66 billion dinars [c.667 million US$].' The benefits will be paid in two times, one by 10 August and another in September.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200806165949/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/480712/usvojen-pravni-okvir-za-sprovodjenje-drugog-paketa-ekonomskih-mera.php
notes_C3: From 1st July, sports and entertainment events banned. https://web.archive.org/web/20200903125436/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C6: From 24 November, the Serbian government adopted new measures to suppress the epidemic caused by the COVID-19 infectious disease, whose implementation will begin on 24 November 2020. Including, but not limited to:  Strict control of the implementation of home isolation, house quarantine (self-isolation), as well as all other anti-epidemic measures in force.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219200700/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/163819/government-passes-new-anti-coronavirus-measures.php
notes_C5: Intercity, urban and suburban bus and rail services have resumed as of 17/5.http://web.archive.org/web/20200521212855/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/
notes_H7: Pfizer, Sputnik V, and Sinopharm are currently in use. Negotiations are in progress for the AstraZeneca vaccine.    On 19 January, mass vaccinations began at the Belgrade Fair, Brnabic reiterated that mass vaccination of Serbian citizens is starting today and to that purpose, the first big vaccination site is opened at the Belgrade Fair and at the Torlak Institute. She specified that the first ones to be vaccinated are members of the Ministry of the Interior, the Serbian Army and other security services.    The Secretary of State appealed to the citizens to apply for vaccination in as many numbers as possible, but also to adhere to the protection and distance measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220302/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166671/very-good-start-of-immunisation-in-serbia.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220013/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166467/mass-vaccination-at-18-points-starts-in-belgrade.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220138/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166398/mass-vaccination-in-serbia-starts-today.php

name: South Sudan
notes_H1: President Salva Kiir Addresses the Nation on COVID-19 (sharing prevention strategies with the public) Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200601142549/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wm_x0scA4KI https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wm_x0scA4KI
notes_H3: Changing to limited to reflect the now shared limited testing supplies: https://web.archive.org/web/20210104160746/https://ss.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H2: COVID-19 testing is available for those with symptoms in South Sudan, however it is limited due to a shortage of testing kits. Travelers arriving in South Sudan will receive a test if they exhibit active signs of COVID-19 infection. COVID-19 testing is available through the South Sudan Rapid Response Team by calling 6666 or by presenting to a health facility.  COVID-19 testing is available but limited for outbound international travelers who need a negative COVID-19 certificate for arrival to their destination. The John Garang Infectious Disease Unit in Juba has 250 tests for travelers available per day. Testing is available 7 days a week, 9:00 a.m.-2:00 p.m. Tests require pre-registration the day before the test is to be administered; pre-registration is done in person at 7am at the testing facility. Results are available 1-2 days after testing. Testing is free of charge.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201209215506/https://ss.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: [...] There are also some restrictions on public transport and inter-state movements. Passengers are required to wear face masks. [...]    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118160237/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-sudan/coronavirus    [...] Interstate and intercity public transportation is fully operational. [...]    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118162213/https://sd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Coded "0" due to the ambiguous data from the US embassy and it UK counterpart.
notes_C8: "All passengers, excepted as stated in the following bullet point, must possess a certified negative polymerise chain reaction (PCR) test certificate dated within 96 hours of arrival. Persons 6 years old and younger are exempt."    "Effective immediately, the Sudanese Civil Aviation Authority passengers who originate from or transit through the UK, South Africa, and the Netherlands must possess a certified negative polymerise chain reaction test certificated dated within 72 hours of arrival.  These passengers are subject to a mandatory 14-day home quarantine."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118162213/https://sd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: Public places and services  Hotels are open to the public. Shops, restaurants and businesses are open but subject to strict social distancing, even if it is not consistently observed. Public rallies are not allowed, schools are partially closed, and public gatherings for funerals are limited to a maximum of 50 people.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111140748/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-sudan/coronavirus
notes_C1: Public places and services  Hotels are open to the public. Shops, restaurants and businesses are open but subject to strict social distancing, even if it is not consistently observed. Public rallies are not allowed, schools are partially closed, and public gatherings for funerals are limited to a maximum of 50 people.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111140748/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-sudan/coronavirus
notes_H6: Facemasks are required to be worn on public transportation. https://web.archive.org/web/20210104160746/https://ss.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: South Sudan’s Information Minister Makuei also said restrictions on working hours had been lifted and that offices will open from 8am to 5pm beginning next week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201007081524/https://africa.cgtn.com/2020/09/13/covid-19-south-sudans-schools-set-to-reopen-minister-says/
notes_E1: 28 April policy change is incorrect as it reflects a World Bank policy. Therefore changing this indicator to 0.
notes_C3: Since there is a restriction on gatherings it will affect public events
notes_C6: Conflict between UK embassy site and US embassy site.     UK says that there is a 10pm - 6am curfew. US says no curfew.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201209213934/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-sudan/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20201209215506/https://ss.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    According to the US Embassy in South Sudan, there are no restrictions but reducing movements other than essential travel is encouraged.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122230826/https://ss.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: Interstate and intercity public transportation is fully operational.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201007083020/https://sd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Suriname
notes_H1: On Saturday, March 14, 2020, the government held a press conference that extensively discussed the latest state of affairs regarding the outbreak of the COVID 19 virus in our country. Every day at 6 p.m., the community can count on the latest news.  /web/20200510055526/https://covid-19.sr/corona-in-suriname/
notes_H3: You should immediately call number 178. Then the investigation process starts.  • Test material is taken from the patient (preferably at home) and then the material is tested to AZP and CL.  • If a person does not need extra care, home quarantine takes place for 14 days (possibly with surveillance), provided the test is positive.  • If a patient has complaints, that patient is taken to AZP (Paramaribo) or MMC (Nickerie). These clinics have trained personnel (SARI) in taking samples for the lab. And the patient is transferred to the quarantine unit.  • Housemates of the suspect case must also stay home under surveillance during the incubation period.  • Treatment must be done according to protocol.   /web/20200510170255/https://covid-19.sr/covid-19/
notes_H2: From Suriname's epidemiologist speaking on 27 July:  "Doctor Ori says it is aiming to conduct mobile COVID-19 tests again this week. The RGD now also has mobile test units in eleven places. “The procedure there is somewhat different. The opportunity to step there and have yourself tested is not available now.”  http://archive.fo/10aH1    This indicates that testing is limited to symptomatic individuals, and therefore meets a coding of 2
notes_C7: There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200923123510/https://sr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information
notes_C8: Incoming flights from Cuba and Haiti banned as of December 2, 2020.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201213235010/http://health.gov.sr/
notes_C4: "Gathering: maximum 10 people. This also applies to funeral services"  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111204403/http://health.gov.sr/actueel/2020/overheid-verscherpt-covid-19-maatregelen/
notes_C1: School closed from the third week in December, currently planned reopening on Jan 18th  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111203833/http://education.gov.sr/actueel/2021/openstelling-van-de-scholen-op-alle-niveaus/
notes_H6: It is mandatory to wear a face mask outside.  https://sr.usembassy.gov/health-alert-u-s-embassy-paramaribo-suriname-31/
notes_C2: Total lockdown ended on September 14.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200923125829/https://sr.usembassy.gov/health-alert-u-s-embassy-paramaribo-suriname-37/
notes_E2: On 9 April 2020, Suriname’s Minister of Finance issued an announcement with tax measures to alleviate the cash flow challenges faced by corporations and individuals due to COVID-19. The tax measures include:  1:Extension of tax return filing dates  2Based on the applicable Suriname tax legislation, any amount due and payable upon the filing of the preliminary tax returns for the year 2020, could be paid in four equal instalments on 15 April, 15 July, 15 October and 31 December 2020.  3:Taxpayers who are experiencing cash flow challenges because of COVID-19 can submit a substantiated request to the Tax Collector of Direct Taxes to qualify for a deferred payment arrangement  3:The statutory filing and payment due date for the turnover tax returns is the 16th of each month. Whereas, wage tax returns should be filed and any tax due should be paid by the 7th business day following the previous month. The tax authorities will be lenient with these filing and payment dates for the taxable periods of March, April, May and June 2020, provided the taxpayer submits a request for the postponement of the filing of the returns and payment of any wage tax or turnover tax due on these returns.  Link Lin:https://web.archive.org/web/20200611111255/https://www.ey.com/en_gl/tax-alerts/suriname-announces-tax-measures-to-mitigate-impact-of-covid-19
notes_C3: he Government of Suriname has announced that it is instituting a “total” lockdown that will last from 1800 on Thursday, June 4, until 0600 hours on Friday, June 12. This means that all residents of the country should stay at home except for short trips for essential needs.  Linkhttps://web.archive.org/web/20200611101527/https://www.osac.gov/Content/Report/feb64421-b9e6-477b-9a97-18e1807ac1d7
notes_C6: It is strongly advised to stay at home and only leave home for necessary work, medical emergencies or to run essential errands.
notes_C5: Public transportation is operating and taxis and buses are available.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200923123510/https://sr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information

name: Slovak Republic
notes_H1: Government started to regularly inform the public about the developments concerning coronavirus, based on the Facebook account of the Cabinet of PM https://www.facebook.com/UradVladySR/ In addition to the regular updates by the Ministry of Health since 27 January 2020 https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanky?stranka=8 http://web.archive.org/web/20200520114315/https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanky?stranka=8
notes_H2: "Once travelers register with the Regional Office of Public Health upon entry, they will receive information about where to get tested after their fifth day of home quarantine. The Slovak government pays for COVID-19 testing in these cases. Once they receive negative test results, free movement in Slovakia is permitted.  Private testing is also available at www.lab.online.sk or www.medirex.sk in various locations throughout the country. If not ordered by the Regional Public Health Authority or a medical provider, the fee for testing is paid by the traveler. The standard cost is €50-€60."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200914173717/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: From 07 January, movement within the Nitra region, including to work and for essential errands, is only permissible with the results of a negative COVID-19 test taken within the last 7 days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210109224013/https://korona.gov.sk/tlacove-spravy/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109220424/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: "Should you enter the territory of the Slovak Republic as of 1 September, 7:00 a.m., and:    You have visited an EU country not mentioned on the list of less-risky countries:  You are obliged to self-isolate,  If you have symptoms you are obliged to get tested for COVID-19 on the fifth day of your self-isolation at the latest,  If you are asymptomatic, your self-isolation is completed after your 10- day self-isolation period is over,  Self-isolation is also mandatory for persons living with you in a common household.  You have visited a country which is not an EU member and is not mentioned on the list of less-risky countries:  You are obliged to self-isolate  You are obliged to get tested for COVID-19 on the fifth day of self-isolation at the latest  Self-isolation is also mandatory for persons living with you in a common household."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200914174304/https://korona.gov.sk/en/travelling-to-slovakia-and-covid19/
notes_C4: From January the 1st, under the partial lockdown restrictions, family units are not allowed to mix with others from outside of the household.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210118155140/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Pupils and student cannot come back to school after the school holidays and are obliged to distance learning on a national level. Only nursery schools for children of legal representatives from critical infrastructure and for children of parents who are not permitted to work from home will be open.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210118153659/https://www.minedu.sk/distancne-vzdelavanie-pokracuje-aj-buduci-tyzden/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118155140/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    From 11 January, all schools will continue to distance themselves from teaching. Only kindergartens for children of legal representatives from critical infrastructure and for children of parents who are not permitted to work from home will be open.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109222835/https://www.minedu.sk/minister-skolstva-b-groehling-mame-plan-na-navrat-deti-do-skol-ten-vsak-zavisi-od-aktualnej-situacie/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109223412/https://www.minedu.sk/informacia-pre-materske-skoly/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109223845/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=frontpage&Itemid=1  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109224013/https://korona.gov.sk/tlacove-spravy/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109220424/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    The University of Bratislava- Since 5 October 2020, all classes should be held online. Exceptions may apply to certain practical lessons and laboratory exercises.  Students will be instructed by their teachers/faculty study department.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120121112/https://uniba.sk/en/comenius-university-news/coronavirus/
notes_H6: Extra restrictions were introduced on 15 October. Masks are now to be worn at all times, not only in enclosed spaces but also outdoors. The only exception is forests and other vast outdoor spaces, "if you are with others that live in the same household or can maintain a five-metre distance."    Mask-wearing in schools was further restricted, too. Previously, pupils in 5th grade and above were required to wear a mask. This has now been extended to include grades 1-4. Exceptions are in place for pupils with disabilities and learning differences. Masks are also recommended to kindergarten pupils.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201130232824/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22507697/masks-outdoors-no-mass-events-special-hours-for-seniors-slovakia-reintroduces-strict-measures.html
notes_C2: "Following the nationwide testing and curfew, the pandemic commission decided on lifting some measures that were imposed to fight the coronavirus.      As a result, cinemas, theatres and churches were open on November 16, while some sports competitions were given a green light, although without spectators. On the other hand, restaurants, hotels and also schools remain closed for now."    Source: The Slovak Spectator, an independent English-language newspaper     http://web.archive.org/web/20201130220822/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22536069/coronavirus-in-slovakia-measures-in-place-after-november-16.html
notes_E2: The government announced the possibility to defer mortgage and loan repayments by 1 to 9 months for sole proprietors, small and medium-sized companies  medium-sized companies. In addition it also announced an automatic postponement of the deadline for filing a tax return until the end of the month following the end of the pandemic period.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200518210520/https://korona.gov.sk/pomoc-zamestnancom/
notes_E1: According to the Budapest Business Journal, the Prime Minister announced 1.5 billion Euros per month to refund 80% of salaries received by people employed in facilities that have been obliged to close. Compensation will also be offered to the self-employed and employees depending on the drop in revenues of the affected businesses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200518201927/https://bbj.hu/region/slovak-govt-drafts-first-aid-economic-package-due-to-coronavirus_180667
notes_C3: "A ban is imposed on organising mass sporting, cultural, entertainment, social events, or events of other nature with more than 50 attendees at one time. If the number of persons at the above events performing on the organiser’s behalf exceeds 50 persons (performers, athletes, sports event organisers, etc.), a mass event will be held without live audience.    In parallel, it is prohibited to:    organise mass, cultural, entertainment, social gatherings or gatherings of other nature (discotheques, dance events, etc.) in catering establishments (restaurants, bars, nightclubs, bars, etc.) and in accommodation facilities. The restriction does not apply to the regular provision of catering services in food establishments,  organise large social gatherings (wedding  receptions, celebrations, dance balls, funeral feasts, green ribbon parties of students, etc.)."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201013192040/https://korona.gov.sk/en/platne-hygienicke-opatrenia-okt-en/
notes_C6: "Slovakia will shut most of its schools and require the population to stay home apart from work, essential shopping and nature trips, in a partial lockdown to slow the spread of the coronavirus"  https://web.archive.org/web/20201029225257if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSKBN2772PF
notes_C5: Local public transport is running normally in Slovakia, but face masks are required.    There is not an exact policy change occurring on this day, however, I didn't find the exact date in which public transport went back to normal operations in the country.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200806183129/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H7: Update immunization policy is in place from 18 January – currently health care professionals and other workers in health care facilities are eligible + newly also old people in nursing homes. People from critical infrastructure will be moved to the list of replacements, meaning they will receive the vaccination only if there is unused vaccine or someone fails to attend.    In the second phase:  residents of senior's homes and people over 65, patients with serious diagnoses, such as diabetes, oncological diseases, auto-immune diseases, cardiovascular issues and other chronic diseases     In the third phase: people in communities with a high risk of fast coronavirus spread like teachers, people living in marginalised Roma communities, homeless people and asylum seekers    In the fourth phase: members of the general public older than 18     https://web.archive.org/web/20210118213749/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22574807/vaccination-strategy-to-change.html

name: Slovenia
notes_H1: COVID-19 Website  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/    Coronavirus: Preparedness and measures in Slovenia and COVID-19 Helpline  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/koronavirus-preparedness-and-measures-in-slovenia/    Coronavirus: Preventing infections  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/coronavirus-preventing-infections/    Coronavirus: Symptoms of infection and treatment  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/coronavirus-symptoms-of-infection-and-treatment/    Government measures  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/government-measures/    Recommendations for washing hands cough etiquette  Link: https://www.gov.si/assets/vlada/Koronavirus-zbirno-infografike-vlada/Infografike/Anglescina/Recommendations-for-washing-hands-Cough-etiquette.pdf    Quotation: So far Slovenia has prepared hospital isolation rooms and urged citizens to be particularly careful with hygiene. Many hospitals have prohibited or limited visitations in recent days. (4th March 2020)  Link: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-slovenia-idUSKBN20R33X    COVID-19 Press Conference: Official updates on the occurrence of the coronavirus infection (7 March 2020)  Link: gov.si/en/news/2020-03-07-official-updates-on-the-occurrence-of-the-coronavirus-infection/    Latest information about coronavirus (Covid-19) in Slovenia (9 March 2020)  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/news/2020-03-09-latest-information-about-coronavirus-covid-19-in-slovenia/    Quotation: The National Institute of Public Health (NIJZ) has drafted a leaflet with key information about the coronavirus, which will be distributed to all Slovenian households via the Post of Slovenia (10 March 2020)  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/news/2020-03-10-measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-coronavirus-are-in-force/
notes_H3: https://web.archive.org/web/20201014122231/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/slovenia/countrypage.aspx
notes_H2: Quotation: Slovenia confirmed its first case of coronavirus, Health Minister Ales Sabeder told a news conference on Wednesday (4 March 2020).  Link: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-slovenia-idUSKBN20R33X  Quotation: "If you have COVID-19 symptoms, testing is available for both foreign nationals and Slovenians. There is no charge for this test."   Link: https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: Movement is restricted between 9.00 p.m. and 6.00 a.m., with exceptions.
notes_C8: https://web.archive.org/web/20201019094355/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/380571/slovenia-authorities-to-tighten-covid-19-restrictions-nationwide-from-september-19-update-12
notes_C4: Regardless of the type of region, events, such as weddings, anniversaries, religious ceremonies and other events or gatherings are no longer allowed anywhere in Slovenia. The ordinance adopted today also restricts the gathering of people, which means that as of today not more than 6 persons are allowed to meet; the only exception applies to members of the same household if such has more than 6 family members.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201022190747/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2020-10-19-restriction-of-movement-between-statistical-regions-and-movement-at-night-and-gatherings-limited-to-no-more-than-6-people/
notes_C1: On October 30th the Government of the Republic of Slovenia decided to extend the validity of the ordinances on measures and restrictions for seven days to prevent the spread of COVID-19   Ordinance temporarily prohibiting gatherings of people in educational institutions and universities and independent higher education institutions,   https://web.archive.org/web/20201104165807/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2020-10-30-the-government-decides-to-extend-the-measures-arising-from-the-ordinances-to-contain-and-manage-the-covid-19-epidemic/
notes_H6: Masks or other forms of protection covering the mouth and nose, and disinfection are mandatory:  in all closed public spaces,  on public transport,  in open public spaces where it is not possible to stay two metres from other people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022191348/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/
notes_C2: Hence, a maximum of 50 people may gather and socialise in public at the same time and same place. In addition, accommodation providers with more than 30 rooms are open and available again, as are spa accommodations, wellness centres, gyms, swimming pools, and water activities.    Until further notice, discos and night clubs remain closed, as do stores on Sundays and holidays, except for petrol stations and pharmacies, which may be open, as at July28 and even before then.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200730001344/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/
notes_E2: As part of an economic stimulus package of € 1 billion (2.2 percent of GDP) announced on March 9, the authorities have adopted some tax and spending measures, including (i) tax deferrals for up to 24 months or tax payments in installments in 24 months; (ii) wage subsidies for suspended workers due to pandemic-related closures and quarantined people as at July 22 and before.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200730012123/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: https://web.archive.org/web/20201019095117/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/slovenia/livinghit.aspx?Section=6.+Measures+in+other+sectors&Type=Chapter
notes_C3: On 19 March, the Slovenian government issued an ordinance prohibiting the movement and gathering of people in public places and areas in the Republic of Slovenia and access to public places and areas the Republic of Slovenia until further notice. There are exceptions for those going to work, grocery shopping, or being outside with members of the same household but a safe distances (1.5 meters) from other people.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200427180655/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2020-03-19-ordinance-on-the-temporary-prohibition-of-public-gathering-at-public-meetings-and-public-events-and-other-events-in-public-places-in-the-republic-of-slovenia/
notes_C6: The Slovenian government declared the end of the pandemic, late on 14 May.   Citizens will still have to follow basic rules to prevent a possible spread of infection, the government said without elaborating. People have been required to wear masks in indoor public spaces, stand at least 1.5 metres (5 feet) apart and disinfect hands upon entering public spaces. No mention of any specific stay at home recommendations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200525132342/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/05/bars-travellers-brazil-coronavirus-live-updates-200524234147993.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20200525132347/https://www.euractiv.com/section/coronavirus/news/slovenia-calls-an-official-end-to-its-coronavirus-epidemic/
notes_C5: Public passenger transport is carried out in a limited capacity. Considering that faculties, secondary and primary schools, and kindergartens are still closed, public passenger transport is carried out according to the school holiday timetable.    The recommendations of the National Institute of Public Health on mask wearing, hand disinfection, vehicle occupancy, and entering and exiting vehicles must be followed.     https://archive.vn/508cI
notes_H7: A, C:    "Residents and employees of homes for the elderly who have not been infected with SARS-CoV-2 will be vaccinated first, with the aim of vaccinating as many residents and employees of homes for the elderly as possible."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210109015041/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2020-12-26-first-batch-of-vaccine-arrives-in-slovenia/    "Vaccination will be free for all citizens, regardless of whether they are insured."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210110171517/https://www.gov.si/teme/koronavirus-sars-cov-2/cepljenje-proti-covid-19

name: Sweden
notes_H1: FAQ about COVID-19 (Link): https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/  Protect yourself and others from the spread of infection in different languages (Link): https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/information-pa-olika-sprak/
notes_H3: Report from 23 March suggest that Public Health Agency thinks that contact tracing would no longer be as effective and have shifted resources to focus on risk groups. The official government website as on 05 April stated that contact tracing is the responsibility of the doctors treating covid-19, and news sources indicated that some form of tracing was ongoing. Sources: 1. https://web.archive.org/web/20200406132606/https://www.thelocal.se/20200320/fact-check-has-sweden-stopped-testing-people-for-the-coronavirus 2. https://web.archive.org/web/20200406132712/https://www.thelocal.se/20200313/what-you-need-to-know-about-the-coronavirus-outbreak-in-sweden-your-questions-answered 3. https://web.archive.org/web/20200406132847/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/  Other news reports seems to suggest that contact tracing has since been stopped as it is no longer considered effective or practical. However, this could not be verified officially.  Source:https://web.archive.org/web/20200423094726/https://www.thelocal.se/20200421/the-swedish-words-weve-learned-during-the-coronavirus-outbreak
notes_H2: The Government announced that it would provide free testing for anyone showing coronavirus symptoms, and conduct contact tracing for those who are infected.   https://archive.vn/wip/LpKn5
notes_C7: In force from 14 December, the Public Health Agency replaced its regional advice with national regulations and general advice, in light of the upcoming Christmas holidays. This means that previous regional advice that explicit recommended against internal travel is no longer in force. I have not changed the code (only from T to G), because the new nation-wide advice, though less explicit compared to the regional advice, still seeks to limit travel incl travel between regions, e.g. "think through whether planned trips are really necessary to carry out".     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164556/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/
notes_C8: "In response to the European Council’s and the European Commission’s call for travel restrictions, the Government decided on 17 March to temporarily stop non-essential travel to Sweden from all countries except those in the EEA and Switzerland so as to mitigate the effects of the outbreak of the COVID-19 virus and reduce the spread of the disease.  The decision takes effect on 19 March and will initially apply for 30 days. This is an exceptional measure that will not apply for longer than necessary."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201112160008/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/03/temporary-ban-on-travel-to-sweden-due-to-covid-19/
notes_C4: On 24 Nov, a new ban on public gatherings over 8 people came into effect. For private gatherings, people are "strongly recommended" to follow the regulations for public gatherings.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130190632/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud
notes_C1: "The Swedish Public Health Agency recommends that upper secondary schools partially close and transfer to distance education from Monday 7 December 2020 until Wednesday 6 January 2021.    The temporary regulations give principals a certain flexibility to make decisions about their activities based on the current infection control situation or local needs. There are opportunities for the principal to take action if the school is open or if the school is or has been closed."    Note: Since principals have the authority to decide whether to close high-schools, depending on the regional situation, and this is only a recommendation - making it unlikely for upper-secondary schools to close countrywide - a Targeted flag has been selected.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201207154159/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin
notes_H6: From 7 January, there is a new general recommendation for people born before 2004 (16 and above) to wear face masks on public transport between 7-9 am and 4-6 pm on weekdays, if it is not possible to ensure good social distance by booking a separate seat.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210108131814/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2020/december/munskydd-i-kollektivtrafiken-fran-den-7-januari/
notes_C2: On 24 Nov, a new ban on public gatherings of over 8 people came into effect. This does not apply to most workplaces, but does affect some sectors to the point where they are required to close, such as amusement parks, markets and fairs. For theaters and cinemas, the official rule is that seated audiences of up to 300 are allowed as long as social distancing measures are adhered to, although the reality on the ground is much stricter as the regions have issued non-binding recommendations which extend the 8-people limit to seated audiences.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130190632/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130190831/https://www.thelocal.se/20201123/no-public-events-for-more-than-8-people-in-sweden-including-seated-events
notes_E2: "Parliament has decided that families with housing allowance will receive a temporary additional payment each month from July to December 2020.    If you receive housing allowance for families you will automatically receive the extra money. You do not have to apply for it.    The additional payment will be 25 percent of what you receive every month."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123145121/https://www.forsakringskassan.se/privatpers/coronaviruset-det-har-galler/%21ut/p/z0/04_Sj9CPykssy0xPLMnMz0vMAfIjo8ziLQI8TDy8DIx8LXxNTQwCDT0dTSx8fA3MnI31g1Pz9AuyHRUB_z6F2g%21%21/?keepNavState=true
notes_E1: Quotation: "To reduce the risk of the virus spreading in society, the qualifying day for sick pay will be discontinued between 11 March and 31 May, in that central government will pay sickness benefit for the first day of sickness.    Central government will temporarily assume responsibility for sick pay for two months."  Link: https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/03/crisis-package-for-swedish-businesses-and-jobs/
notes_C3: "The Government is making use of the possibility in the Public Order Act (Chapter 2, Section 15) to prohibit public gatherings and events if this is necessary to combat an epidemic. The prohibition is issued in an ordinance.    The ordinance means that, as of Thursday 12 March and until further notice, it is forbidden in the whole of Sweden to hold public gatherings and events with more than 500 participants.    The Government will continuously examine the need for this ordinance and it will be revoked when the prohibition is no longer needed.    Public gatherings include demonstrations, lectures, gatherings for religious practice, theatre performances, cinema screenings and concerts.    Public events include sporting events, dance performances, markets and fairs.    For a gathering to be considered public, it is necessary for it to have been arranged for the public or for the public to have access to it, or that the gathering should be regarded as equivalent to such a gathering given the conditions that apply for access to it.    For an event to be considered public, it is necessary for it to have been arranged for the public or for the public to have access to it."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200322142423/https://www.government.se/articles/2020/03/ordinance-on-a-prohibition-against-holding-public-gatherings-and-events/
notes_C6: FT. As of 25 Mar.  "Swedish authorities have banned public gatherings of more than 500 people, closed universities and higher education colleges, and advised workers to stay at home if possible."     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200523152613/https://www.ft.com/content/31de03b8-6dbc-11ea-89df-41bea055720b
notes_C5: "On April 1, Swedish Public Health Agency expanded guidance for individuals and organizations to comply with Sweden’s Law on the Prevention of the Spread of Infectious Diseases:  - Public transport companies should limit the number of passengers and adapt their schedules to avoid crowds."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201112192626/https://se.usembassy.gov/covid-19-coronavirus-information/
notes_H7: A, C:    The first vaccinations took place on 27 December. The Public Health Agency has recommended different phases for the vaccination, according to the need for protection of respective groups. During Phase 1, which started on 27 December, elderly living in care homes or receive home care under the Social Services Act, staff working directly with these people, and adults living with someone belonging to this risk group are eligible. Phase 2 is expected to start in February 2021.         https://web.archive.org/web/20210104161641/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2020/december/vaccinationerna-i-sverige-har-inletts/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104162056/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/rekommendationer-for-vaccination-mot-covid-19/

name: Eswatini
notes_H1: Swazi government has a dedicated spokesperson, advisories, public info/guidance on COVID-19. Since the government does actually start messaging on Coronavirus after this day (e.g. https://web.archive.org/web/20200302152522/https:/twitter.com/EswatiniGovern1/status/1234481721447452672), 2 is maintained as coding; https://web.archive.org/web/20200229191745/https:/twitter.com/EswatiniGovern1/status/1233771535556579330
notes_H3: After April 23, statements from the ministry of health omit "contact tracing was initiated" from any updates (still present on the April 22) and together with the rising case numbers, it is likely an indication that comprehensive contact tracing may no longer be in place, though some form of contact tracing seems to be still in place. Since the comprehensive rating was based on that specific evidence, H3 is downgraded to 1 from here on out;    https://web.archive.org/web/20200611234220/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/Press-Statement-Health-23-April-2020.pdf
notes_H2: The Ministry of Health wishes to emphasize that the definition of a suspect case has  changed due to the fact that Eswatini has an established local transmission. This means all flu-like illnesses must be considered suspect cases of Coronavirus infection hence the public is encouraged to seek health care as soon as they can. https://web.archive.org/web/20200611234729/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/Health-statement-5-May-COVID19.pdf
notes_C7: Movement Restrictions:  Is a curfew in place? Yes. Non essential traveling between 11PM and 4AM is prohibited.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes. There are roadblocks between cities where temperatures are checked.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104082247/https://sz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Specific conditions must be met in order to enter Eswatini:    A COVID-19 test must be performed no more than 72 hours before departure and you must be able to demonstrate a negative test result on entry  Upon arriving in Eswatini, you will be screened for COVID-19 symptoms and asked about your country of origin and any transit stops  If you do not present a negative COVID-19 result on entry, or if you display COVID-19 symptoms, you will be required to take a COVID-19 test on arrival at your own cost  You may be required to undergo a quarantine period not exceeding 14 days, or isolation as advised by the port health officers  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104091520/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/eswatini/entry-requirements
notes_C4: All gatherings of all sizes prohibited except for burials.    See the Acting Prime Minister's Statement on COVID-19 Response Interventions, 7 January 2021, (https://web.archive.org/web/20210107115246/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/Acting-PM-statement-7-January-2021-final-Restrictions.pdf).
notes_C1: All schools closed. "Government continues to monitor the situation on the ground and will only open schools when it is safer to do so."    See the Acting Prime Minister's Statement on COVID-19 Response Interventions, 7 January 2021, (https://web.archive.org/web/20210107115246/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/Acting-PM-statement-7-January-2021-final-Restrictions.pdf).
notes_H6: It is compulsory to wear a mask everywhere, even when travelling alone in a vehicle.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104090733/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/eswatini/coronavirus
notes_C2: As of August 28th, the July 3rd PM statement is still the most recent on the SZ gov website. Per that statement, as of July 13 Casinos, cinemas, gyms, health and beauty spas and auctioneers have been allowed to open subject to hygienic measures.     In further research, I could not find any evidence that other businesses are still closed.     http://web.archive.org/web/20200716175048/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/PM-statement-3-July-2020-final.pdf
notes_E2: • Provisional tax payments: Taxpayers projecting losses will file loss provisional returns, hence no payment will be required. Extension of returns filing deadlines by 3 months before penalties kick-in; payment arrangements for taxpayers facing cash flow problems; waiver of penalties and interest for older tax debts if principal is cleared by the end of September 2020  • Decreasing electricity price  • Fuel prices will come down during the first week of April 2020  • For old debts, SRA will waive of penalties and interest if principal is cleared by the end of September 2020.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200611225159/http://www.gov.sz/index.php/component/content/article/115-finance/2413-government-press-statement-ministry-of-finance?Itemid=799; https://web.archive.org/web/20200611225332/https://www.undp.org/content/dam/rba/docs/COVID-19-CO-Response/ESwatini-economic-analysisreport-1.pdf; https://web.archive.org/web/20200611225337/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Festive season sports tournaments are prohibited  https://web.archive.org/web/20201222133514/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/december-legal.pdf
notes_C6: Curfew in place from 11PM to 4AM, no change from the previous coder's notes and in line with my subsequent notes. I have recorded this a 2 in line with the Coding Interpretation Guide.
notes_C5: Private and local transport at 80% capacity. Public transport at 50% capacity. No local freight transport between 11PM and 4AM, unless holding a permit related to COVID-19 supplies and PPE.     See the Acting Prime Minister's Statement on COVID-19 Response Interventions, 7 January 2021, (https://web.archive.org/web/20210107115246/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/Acting-PM-statement-7-January-2021-final-Restrictions.pdf).

name: Seychelles
notes_H1: https://web.archive.org/save/https://data.humdata.org/dataset/acaps-covid19-government-measures-dataset, General recommendations for social distancing and hygienic practices.
notes_H3: Contact tracing and testing by the Seychellois authorities will begin on Monday 15 March. Members of the public are reassured that public health officials have begun contact tracing, the process of identification of all persons who may have come into contact with an infected person and, to continue to follow the guidelines advocated by the Department of Health.     https://web.archive.org/save/http://www.health.gov.sc/index.php/2020/03/16/seychelles-records-first-cases-of-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20200408225720/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/seychelles/coronavirus
notes_H2: https://web.archive.org/web/20200408225720/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/seychelles/coronavirus
notes_C7: Effective May 4, 2020, restrictions on the movement of people are no longer in effect, however social distancing measures remain in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200528193959/https://mu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-seychelles/    http://archive.vn/QvV5w#selection-849.0-851.30    https://web.archive.org/web/20200528193834/https://www.seychellesbookings.com/seychelles-corona
notes_C8: The Seychelles health authorities has announced that during the phase one of the re-opening of the Seychelles borders, only travelers from “low-risk” countries arriving through private jets and chartered passenger direct flights will be granted entry.    /web/20200611103043/https://www.eturbonews.com/573567/seychelles-travel-restrictions-from-covid-19-gradually-lifted/
notes_C4: No restrictions on private gatherings are noted in government sites. In addition, the US embassy specifically captures that "Restrictions on the movement of people are no longer in effect, however, social distancing measures remain in place." For this reason, it seemed best to reduce the restriction coding to mirror that of public events. https://web.archive.org/web/20201026183524/https://mu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-seychelles/
notes_C1: "Faure said that: "From 11 May, all child-minding and day-care services, all post-secondary institutions including A-Levels, Guy Morel Institute and the University of Seychelles, will reopen. From 18 May, all primary and secondary schools will reopen."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200522050520/http://www.seychellesnewsagency.com/articles/12813/Seychelles+and+COVID-+Movement+restrictions+to+be+lifted+next+week%3B+schools%2C+daycare+to+reopen+later+in+May
notes_H6: Masks are required on public transportation. See: https://mu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-seychelles/ [web archive unavailable, accessed 11 January 2021, webpage last updated 7 January 2021]
notes_C2: Effective January 3, 2021, additional restrictions, were implemented for the next 10 days. These additional measures stipulate that all retail stores except grocery stores will be closed. See: http://www.seychellesnewsagency.com/articles/14124/Seychelles+again+increases+measures+as+COVID+cases+rise%253B+movements+restricted [web archive unavailable, accessed 11 January 2021]
notes_E2: The CBS also announced that commercial banks, the Development Bank of Seychelles (DBS) and the Seychelles Credit Union have agreed to consider a moratorium of six months on the repayment of principal and interest on loans to assist businesses in impacted sectors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200608135237/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://www.cbs.sc/Downloads/covid19/PolicyMeasures/Press%20Conference%20Presentation%20-%20Private%20Sector%20Relief%20Scheme.pdf (Not archivable)
notes_E1: The Financial Assistance for Job Retention (FA4JR) program was announced on 20/3/20 and launched in April onwards, to pay the salaries of employees of businesses and NGOs that were negatively affected by COVID-19, to ensure that no staff were to be made redundant. See government website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20200918152706/http://www.finance.gov.sc/uploads/resources/FA4JR_FAQs_final.pdf AND https://web.archive.org/web/20200918152746/http://www.finance.gov.sc/press-releases/256/UPDATED-LATEST-FIGURES-FROM-THE-FINANCIAL-ASSISTANCE-FOR-JOB-RETENTION-COMMITTEE-THURSDAY-17TH-SEPTEMBER-2020
notes_C3: 3rd January 2021, new measures that come into effect as of today, for the next 10 days.    The new measures are:    1. Closure of Restaurants, except those in hotels and guest houses to serve their resident clients and airside restaurant at the airport  2. Closure of mobile food vans and takeaways except for the provision of bulk orders for delivery or collection by previous arrangements.  3. Suspension of all sporting activities, including watersports, except for individual exercises activities involving members of a household (e.g. jogging, walking, swimming in the sea)  4. Closure of all public swimming pools including hotel swimming pools for shared use. (Personal swimming pool attached to a villa is permitted)  5. Closure of all children’s club in tourism establishments  6. Closure of all retail stores except grocery stores (existing opening hours) and hardware stores (8:00 am to 12:00 noon)  7. Wholesales of groceries by delivery only    https://web.archive.org/web/20210105053451/http://www.health.gov.sc/index.php/2021/01/04/new-measures-effected-as-covid-19-cases-rise/
notes_C6: Effective January 3 until January 13, workers will now work from home except for those in essential services. There is also a ban on visits to hospitals and elderly people's homes to see relatives. See: http://www.seychellesnewsagency.com/articles/14124/Seychelles+again+increases+measures+as+COVID+cases+rise%253B+movements+restricted [web archive unavailable, accessed 11 January 2021]
notes_C5: Buses are instructed to reduce maximum capacity. Masks are required on public transportation. See: https://mu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-seychelles/ [web archive unavailable, accessed 11 January 2021, webpage last updated 7 January 2021]

name: Syria
notes_H1: There is no evidence that the "For Syria stay at home" campaign is still ongoing and no campaign seems to have been announced recently. Since the curfew and movement restrictions have ended it is likely the campaign has ended.    The website, which shows the distribution of registered Coronavirus cases in Syria, is still active.    Sources: https://archive.vn/Met25  https://archive.vn/9jv5Y
notes_H3: no noted updates via regularly used sources - https://web.archive.org/web/20210105000231/https://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syrian-arab-republic-covid-19-humanitarian-update-no-22-23-december-2020
notes_H2: https://web.archive.org/web/20200518202732/https://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syrian-arab-republic-covid-19-response-update-no02-6-may-2020  OCHA  “On 16 April, the WHO Regional Office for the Eastern Mediterranean (EMRO) shared information indicating that a 53-year-old man from Al-Hasakeh City who had been admitted to Qamishli National Hospital on 27 March had died on 2 April. A test for the virus subsequently tested positive.”
notes_C7: "Beginning today, the government will lift an overnight curfew and allow movement between its provinces."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200527094103/https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/05/syria-coronavirus-curfew-uptick-cases-damascus-idlib.html    "Restrictions remain in place at most other crossing points inside Syria. Abu Zendin, Um Jloud and Awn Dadat in Aleppo remain closed, as do Akeirshi and Abu Assi crossing points in Ar-Raqqa. Ghazawiyet Afrin and Al-Taiha in Aleppo are reported open for commercial traffic; the latter is also reported to be currently open for university students to move into GoS areas, in addition to some medical cases (...)"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201110223052/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Syria_COVID-19_Humanitarian%20Update%20No%2011_30May2020_FINAL.pdf
notes_C8: "The necessary precautions to ensure Syrians are protected from the arrival of the coronavirus were on the discussion table for government ministers at the cabinet session headed by Imad Khamis on Sunday.    The cabinet stressed the need to monitor the precautionary and preventive measures taken at all ports, land, sea and air crossings, to ensure that no cases of coronavirus occur on Syrian territory. It decided to suspend visits and trips to and from the neighboring countries of Iraq and Jordan by individuals and groups, including for purposes of religious tourism, for one month. It also suspended visits to countries that have declared a state of epidemic for two months, while conducting preventive quarantine for a period of 14 days for those coming from these countries to ensure their safety."    Sources:   https://syrianobserver.com/EN/news/56590/the-government-takes-precautionary-measures-and-forbids-visits-to-iraq-and-jordan-for-a-month.html (unable to archive)
notes_C4: Unable to find any other information except this, posted on Nov 12th: On 30 October, a 10-day partial curfew came into effect across NES lasting until 8 November. All major markets/public facilities have been ordered closed for the duration of the ban, excluding shops selling food and restaurants (for takeaway orders only provided they close by 3pm in the afternoon); places of worship must close except for Friday prayers and Sunday mass and; mass gatherings (wedding halls, condolence tents and conference meetings all specifically mentioned) are prohibited.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201124000615/https://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syrian-arab-republic-covid-19-response-update-no-12-9-november-2020
notes_C1: "More than 3 million Syrian students started school in government-held areas Sunday, marking the first school day amid strict measures to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, state media reported.  Among the precautionary measures taken by the Ministry of Education were the sanitizing of all classrooms, walls, floors, stairs and bathrooms of schools, state news agency SANA said. Students’ temperatures will be checked as well."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200924120319/https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/syrias-schools-open-amid-anti-coronavirus-measures-72982448    "The GoS continues to maintain a widespread easing of preventive measures introduced throughout May, albeit with some ongoing changes, including recent ad-hoc suspension of (...) some schools/classrooms where students or teachers had confirmed to have contracted COVID-19."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201111123618/https://www.ecoi.net/en/file/local/2038347/Syria_COVID-19_Humanitarian+Update_No+19_29Sept2020_FINAL.pdf
notes_H6: The Government team concerned with adopting measures to confront corona epidemic decided on 14 December to impose wearing masks for citizens and employees at public institutions, and users of public transportation, customers at markets and bakeries. It also decided to shut tourist facilities and restaurants, which don’t adhere to the preventive measures taken to confront the coronavirus.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221231309/https://www.mecc.org/mecc/2020/12/21/mecc-coronavirus-covid-19-weekly-report
notes_C2: "Due to the expanding threat of Coronavirus around the world as it has become a global pandemic, the Syrian government took a number of precautionary and preventative steps to protect citizens.    (...)The team also decided to reduce work hours at administrative public sector establishments to around 40%, suspending handprint sign-in for a month. Economic services establishments are to reorganize work to function in the optimal manner with the minimum amount of workers for 15 days. Work in the public and private sectors will continue for technicians and production workers after providing the suitable preventative measures and providing medical staff for conducting regular checkups.    In addition, restaurants and cafes are to refrain from providing hookah (water pipe), and venues for social gatherings have been closed, while a plan has been devised to sanitize public transportation."    Source: https://archive.vn/AA0so
notes_C3: "The GoS continues to maintain a widespread easing of preventive measures introduced throughout May (...) markets, restaurants, cafes, gyms, parks, theaters, cinemas and most  leisure facilities remain open, with mandated precautionary measures. Mosques and churches are open, with physical distancing requirements."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201108205948if_/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Syria_COVID-19_Humanitarian%20Update_No%2020_29Oct2020_FINAL.pdf
notes_C6: Lockdown occurred 6 November to last until 19 November. no further notations if it continued past 19 Nov. https://web.archive.org/web/20201124000615/https://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syrian-arab-republic-covid-19-response-update-no-12-9-november-2020    Under this lockdown, schools (excluding shops selling food between 6 am and 1 pm), places of worship, shops, restaurants, playgrounds and private clinics will be closed, while movements in and out of Derik city will be prohibited (excluding emergency cases and food shipments). Humanitarian actors are exempted from these restrictionsOn 3 November, following a recent surge in cases in Malakiyeh (Derik), the Executive Council of Jazeera Canton announced a full 14-day lockdown in ‘Derik city and its countryside’ (understood as the whole of Malakiyeh District) which will come into effect on 6 November and last until 19 November.    Under this lockdown, schools (excluding shops selling food between 6 am and 1 pm), places of worship, shops, restaurants, playgrounds and private clinics will be closed, while movements in and out of Derik city will be prohibited (excluding emergency cases and food shipments). Humanitarian actors are exempted from these restrictions.
notes_C5: Unable to find any information:   https://web.archive.org/web/20201124000615/https://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syrian-arab-republic-covid-19-response-update-no-12-9-november-2020

name: Chad
notes_H1: The government of Chad first announced that travellers who have been to China, Italy or South Korea will be quarantined for 14 days at a local health facility on 7 March 2020.     The Chad Government issued the first Health Alert on 20 March 2020. Thereafter, On 13 April 2020 the Government finalised the National Contingency Plan for Preparedness and Response to the Epidemic of Coronavirus COVID-19 to prevent the spread of the disease, the Chad Government has taken a series of measures with the major ones focused on: suspension of all international flights, closure of schools, universities, places of worship, and of non-essential businesses, a ban on public transport, closure of the main markets and a curfew in the capital of N’Djamena and 4 provinces of Logone Occidental, Logone Oriental, Mayo-kebbi Ouest and Mayo-kebbi Est.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200501080941/https://reliefweb.int/report/chad/chad-coronavirus-covid-19-situation-report-no-1   https://web.archive.org/web/20200501080113/https://www.cnbcafrica.com/africa-press-office/2020/03/20/health-alert-u-s-embassy-ndjamena-chad/     https://web.archive.org/web/20200501071153/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#C     https://web.archive.org/web/20200501080336/https://www.iata.org/contentassets/b308ae421f9d4f83bec899ea64a04ffc/chad-ncov-measures.pdf
notes_H3: No change in policy found
notes_H2: No new change found
notes_C7: Per German embassy site and US embassy site Transit The land borders are closed. Commercial flight operations at N'Djamena Airport resume. Air France, Egypt Air, Turkish Airlines and Ethiopian Airlines offer flights, but irregularities must be expected.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201101162030/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201101161745/https://ndjamena.diplo.de/td-de/laenderinfos/reise-sicherheit
notes_C8: International TravelAs of Jan. 8, international commercial passenger travel to and from Chad has been suspended, as have domestic flights. Cargo and emergency flights are unaffected. International land borders are closed to passenger traffic.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111105707/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/427056/chad-authorities-tighten-covid-19-related-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-jan-8-international-and-domestic-passenger-air-travel-suspended-update-26
notes_C4: Domestic Measures in N'Djamena Authorities have imposed containment measures on N'Djamena and surrounding areas, restricting travel to and from the capital until further notice. Surrounding areas include the east as far as N'Djamena-Koura, west to Mara, in the south to Koundoul, and in the North to Djermaya. A nightly 1900-0500 curfew is in effect. All nonessential businesses must close, as must public and private schools and universities, places of worship. Public gatherings will be limited to 50 people. Facemasks are mandatory. Residents are advised to only leave their homes for work, school, and essential shopping.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111105707/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/427056/chad-authorities-tighten-covid-19-related-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-jan-8-international-and-domestic-passenger-air-travel-suspended-update-26

All nonessential businesses must close, as must public and private schools and universities, places of worship. Public gatherings will be limited to 50 people. Facemasks are mandatory. Residents are advised to only leave their homes for work, school, and essential shopping. notes_E2: IMF lists measures to alleviate hardship on households including (i) temporary suspension of payments of electricity and water bills for the lifeline consumption...   https://web.archive.org/web/20201101164704/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: They have also introduced new measures in N’Djamena limiting attendance at baptisms, marriages and funerals. Bars, restaurants, small shops and large markets are closed. Public or private meetings of more than 50 people are banned.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111110259/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/coronavirus
notes_C6: The Government has changed the curfew hours in N’Djamena. The curfew hours are from 7pm to 5am. The curfew hours in 6 provinces (Guera, Kanem, Logone Occidental, Logone Oriental, Mayo-Kebbi Ouest, Mayo-Kebbi Est) and in the districts of Mandelia and Logone-Gana are from 8pm to 5am. The curfew hours in Mayo-Kebbi Ouest and Moyen Chari are 7pm to 5am. The Government has extended the health emergency, restricting movement and public gatherings throughout the country until 10 March 2021.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111110259/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/coronavirus
notes_C5: Public transport services operating, albeit with limits on the number of passengers allowed in vehicles.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111105707/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/427056/chad-authorities-tighten-covid-19-related-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-jan-8-international-and-domestic-passenger-air-travel-suspended-update-26

name: Togo
notes_H1: Directions about handwashing, social distancing etc on gov website.   "Renforcement de la surveillance et des mesures individuelles et collectives de prévention et de protection: se laver les mains au savon, recourir au gel hydro-alcoolique, ne pas se serrer les mains en se saluant, éviter des accolades et des embrassades, etc"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200615195439/https://covid19.gouv.tg/
notes_H3: They appear to have an an app that can track residents as well as inbound travelers.
