Travelers can avoid quarantine by using the app and supplying a negative test sample.   /web/20210124203924/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/  information/covid-19/  IMF Policy Response:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124213332/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  TOGO Covid Website:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210108182326/https://covid19.gouv.tg/#website  TOGO Covid Tracking/Contact Tracing Apps:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124212943/https://togosafe.gouv.tg/en/home/
notes_H2: UNDP has rolled three testing vans out to support citizens. https://www.republicoftogo.com/Toutes-les-rubriques/Sante/Mobilite-sanitaire
notes_C7: Is a curfew in place? [Yes]  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? [Yes]  As part of the monitoring of the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemic, in response to the Coronavirus, the Government of Togo has been observing a worrying increase in new cases of coronavirus infection throughout the country for several weeks, particularly in the following towns: Sokodé, Tchamba and Adjengré.  Having noted that the infected persons have had many contacts, and in order to prevent this spread from increasing further in the populations of these localities and throughout the country, the government has decided the following as of August 25, 2020:  1- The closure of the cities of: Sokodé, Tchamba and Adjengre.  2- The establishment of a curfew from 21.00 to 5.00 in the prefectures of Tchaoudjo, Tchamba and Sotouboua.  All land border crossings with Ghana, Burkina Faso and Benin remain closed. If you reside outside of Togo in West Africa,  please contact the U.S. Embassy in your country for assistance. For a detailed list of the flights available in country, visit our COVID-19 page.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201015075535/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/
notes_C8: I chose screening although it is more of tracking via TOGO app which was referenced on the US Embassy Site - They have a contact tracking app that is for residents and travelers alike.    /web/20210124203924/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124212943/https://togosafe.gouv.tg/en/home/
notes_C4: Restrictions are placed on business as they have to follow social distancing guidelines, and also churches are mostly closed except for the small number that are open on a trial bases as of 01.19.2021   /web/20210124203924/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/  Confirmed that gatherings limited to less than 100 people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124203202/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: Schools are open for International primary & secondary schools.  Local schools present some difficulties in reopening, however according to UNESCO's site as of 01/24/2021 all schools in TOGO are open.    /web/20210124203924/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/
notes_H6: Per the US Embassy in Togo, "Everyone must adhere to the barrier measures such as hand washing, masking and distancing – at all times and in all places" https://web.archive.org/web/20210104223511/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/
notes_C2: All business are open as long as all social distancing mandates are followed.    NOTE:  Some cultural centers and also some religious sites remain closed, with cavoites for a small number on a trial bases as of 01/19/21.    /web/20210124203924/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/
notes_E2: The Government subsidized water and electricity use for groups paying social tariffs for three months. The total cost is estimated at CFAF 3.8 billion ($6 million; 0.1 percent of GDP).  The Government did also subsidize water and electricity use for groups paying social tariffs for three months. The total cost is estimated at CFAF 3.8 billion ($6 million; 0.1 percent of GDP).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201015095720/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: "Le Gouvernement lance « Novissi », un programme de transferts monétaires pour soutenir les populations les plus affectées par les mesures prises dans le cadre de la riposte nationale contre le coronavirus (COVID-19) au Togo."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200615195439/https://covid19.gouv.tg/To support eligible Togolese citizens in the informal sector whose daily income has been disrupted by the Coronavirus crisis, the Government of Togo has set up the “NOVISSI” cash transfer scheme. NOVISSI provides monthly financial aid to the most vulnerable individuals and families throughout the duration of the state of health emergency."https://web.archive.org/save/https://novissi.gouv.tg/en/home-new-en/
notes_C3: Cultural centers must reduce number of activities and most religious services and churches remain closed.    NOTE:  Some cultural centers and also some religious sites remain closed, with cavoites for a small number on a trial bases as of 01/19/21.    /web/20210124203924/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/
notes_C6: I was unable to find any evidence to show that there are currently any guidelines pertaining to the stay at home requirment.  /web/20210124203924/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/
notes_C5: No measures for closing public transportation, however they have instituted airline schedules per days of the week as specified on the Embassy's site below.  All public transpiration is open and operating at a reduced compacity, face coverings are required.    /web/20210124203924/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/

name: Thailand
notes_H1: Gov's Information Center for COVID-19 Response Measures set up. Gives daily press briefing.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200823161200/https://thailand.prd.go.th/ewt_news.php?nid=9101&filename=index
notes_H3: 23rd Jan 2021: No recent evidence could be found to suggest that Thailand has a comprehensive contact tracing system in place. The Thai government does use contract tracing Apps MorChana and ThaiChana .    https://web.archive.org/web/20210123121330/https://www.xn--b3czh8ayeuf.com/faq.html      A recent Thai PBS News article covered the APP: "A closer look at Thailand’s (non-mandatory) contact tracing apps"https://web.archive.org/web/20210109053728/https://www.thaipbsworld.com/a-closer-look-at-thailands-non-mandatory-contact-tracing-apps/
notes_H2: Testing is expanded to asymptomatic people in vulnerable groups, and to some random testing of the general population. However, it is still not generally available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200511213623/https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-thailand/thailand-to-expand-coronavirus-testing-as-new-cases-dwindle-idUKKBN22J0HG
notes_C7: A lockdown in Samut Sakhon province is in place. Movements in and out of this province have been restricted.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210104063718/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/thailand/coronavirus  http://web.archive.org/web/20210104062002/https://thailand.prd.go.th/ewt_news.php?nid=10520&filename=index
notes_C8: 23 Jan 2021.   Foreigners cannot enter Thailand, including for transit flights, except in extremely limited circumstances. If you're allowed to enter Thailand you'll be subject to strict quarantine measures.  According to The Notification on Conditions for Aircraft Permission to Enter Thailand (No.2) which appears to have been in effect since 2nd July and appears to be current: people allowed into Thailand are: "In order to provide a guideline for those involved and ensure the consistency with Regulation Issued under Section 9 of the Emergency Decree on Public Administration in Emergency Situations B.E. 2548 (2005) (No. 12) issued on 30 June B.E. 2563 (2020) and Order of the Centre for the Administration of the Situation due to the Outbreak of the Communicable Disease Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) No. 7/2563 Re : Guidelines based on Regulations Issued under Section 9 of the Emergency Decree on Public Administration in Emergency Situations B.E. 2548 (2005) (No. 6) issued on 30 June B.E. 2563 (2020), by virtue of Section 27 and 28 of the Air Navigation Act B.E. 2497, the Director General of the Civil Aviation Authority of Thailand hereby issues the notification as follows:                       1. The Notification of the Civil Aviation Authority of Thailand on Conditions for Aircraft Permission to Enter Thailand issued on 29 June B.E. 2563 (2020) shall be abolished.                       2. Aircraft carrying persons shall be banned from entering into the airport in Thailand unless it falls with any of the following categories:                       (1) State or military aircraft                       (2) Emergency landing flights                       (3) Technical landing flights without disembarkation                       (4) Humanitarian aid, medical and relief flights                       (5) Repatriation flights                       (6) Cargo flights                       (7) Passenger flights carrying the persons permitted to enter Thailand as prescribed in 3.                       3. The entry into Thailand of the persons of any of the following types, by aircraft, shall be permitted, provided that they comply with the conditions, time limits and rules of the authorized persons under the Thai immigration law, communicable diseases law, air navigation law, and the Emergency Decree on Public Administration in Emergency Situation, for the prevention of the spread of disease and the organization of the number of persons entering Thailand in accordance with the capability of the competent officers or the communicable disease control officers for the screening and arrangement of facilities for isolation, quarantine and control for observation :                       (1) Thai nationals                       (2) Persons with exemption or persons being considered, permitted or invited by the Prime Minister, or the head of responsible persons accountable for resolving state of emergency issues to enter the Kingdom, pertaining to necessity. Such consideration, permission or invitation may be subject to specified conditions and time limits.                       (3) Persons on diplomatic or consular missions or under International organizations, or representatives of foreign government performing their duties in the Kingdom, or persons of other international agencies as permitted by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs pertaining to necessity, including their spouse, parents, or children.                       (4) Carriers of necessary goods, subject to immediate return after completion.                       (5) Crew members who are required to travel into the Kingdom on a mission, and have a specified date and time for return                       (6) Non-Thai nationals who are a spouse, parents, or children of a Thai national.                       (7) Non-Thai nationals who hold a valid certificate of permanent residency in the Kingdom, or permission to take up residence in the Kingdom                       (8) Non-Thai nationals who have work permit or have been granted permission from government agencies to work in the Kingdom, including their spouse or children."    Thailand boarders are effectively closed.  Therefore coded 4.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210123111256/https://www.smartraveller.gov.au/destinations/asia/thailand  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123111206/https://www.caat.or.th/en/archives/51895
notes_C4: The Thailand Government Public Relations Department published a release on 19th Jan 2021 stating:  "Government Spokesperson Anucha Burapachaisri, in light of the recent political gathering, disclosed that with the Emergency Decree and Communicable Diseases Act being enforced to control the spread of COVID-19, the Government would like to seek cooperation from the public to refrain from attending any mass gathering. While the Government has been putting utmost effort to implement various economic stimulus measures to relief the plight of people as a result of the current phase of outbreak, the least that it would want to happen is an increased number of infected patients, especially from any political gathering."  From this it appears that there are some restrictions on gatherings. However, no information could be found on restrictions for private gatherings.  Therefore coded 0 as per OxCGRT Coding Interpretation Guide recommendation.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123102347/https://thailand.prd.go.th/more_news.php?offset=20&cid=2&filename=index
notes_C1: The Bangkok Metropolitan Administration (BMA) has announced a set of measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in the wake of a new surge of COVID-19 cases, especially among foreign workers in Samut Sakhon province. In these measures, schools and early childhood development centers, under the supervision of BMA, with areas adjacent to Samut Sakhon will be closed for 14 days, starting from 21 December onwards.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210104062002/https://thailand.prd.go.th/ewt_news.php?nid=10520&filename=index
notes_H6: 23rd Jan 2021: Regulation Issued under Section 9 of the Emergency Decree on Public Administration in Emergency Situations B.E. 2548 (2005) (No. 17) effective since 7th Jan 2021 and appears to be current states in part that  "1. Intensifying the Enforcement of Disease Prevention Measures: Competent officials,  communicable disease control officers and responsible persons of places, activities or businesses  shall ensure that customers, travellers and the general public strictly comply with disease  prevention measures, by maintaining social distancing, wearing cloth masks or surgical masks,  washing hands, checking body temperature, ..."  No further detail is provided as to where and when specifically masks wearing is required. This is a nation wide regulation.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210123115637/https://www.mfa.go.th/en/content-category/press-release-and-information-2?p=2  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123111659/https://image.mfa.go.th/mfa/0/mkKfL2iULZ/0904-64/%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%A1_64/13-01-63/%E0%B8%82%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%B3%E0%B8%AB%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%94_%2817%29_Eng.pdf    The Bangkok Metropolitan Administration released a statement on 21 January 2021 "Bangkok asks everyone for cooperation to wear face masks". In part it states "Mrs. Silpa Suayrawee Saengsoon, Permanent Secretary of Bangkok, revealed that due to information from many agencies that Wearing a face mask can help prevent the spread of COVID-19. The best and most economical Nowadays, people are keen to wear surgical masks in public or crowded places such as establishments, shops, bus stops. Including people traveling by the pathways In the morning and evening, which is an urgent time where many commuters have to travel to work or return to their accommodation. " https://web.archive.org/web/20210123120324/http://www.bangkok.go.th/main/page.php?3-=&type=detail&id=114334
notes_C2: 23rd Jan 2021 The Thailand Government Public Relations Department website has a press release dated 21 Jan 2021.  This is the most recent official government release regarding COVID-19 Restrictions.  It states, in part, "Dr. Taweesilp Visanuyothin, the Spokesperson of the Center for COVID-19 Situation Administration (CCSA), stated in the daily briefing on 21 January that 31 January 2021 will be the day to make a decision whether the country should strengthen or relax prevention measures" http://web.archive.org/web/20210123082318/https://thailand.prd.go.th/ewt_news.php?nid=10687&filename=index    However, The Thailand Government Public Relations Department website has a press release dated 19th Jan 2021 stated that  "Samut Sakhon has announced relaxation of measures [from prior strict 'lock down'] on salons and restaurants in the controlled area. In every district, salons may open from 06.00 hr to 21.00 hr. Restaurants, except in eight sub-districts in the city district, may also open from 06.00 hr to 21.00 hr. This relaxation will be in effect from 16 January to 21 February 2021."     The Bangkok Metropolitan Administration announced "For today's meeting [Bangkok Communicable Disease Committee Meeting No. 3/2021] , the meeting agreed to provide relief. 13 types of establishments can be opened from tomorrow (22 Jan '64) onwards as follows: 1. Arcade game venues 2. Gaming cafes and Internet cafes 3. Elderly care facilities 4. All types of race fields except the field Horse boxing 5. Property catering Banquet Location Including any other places that are similar. 6. Field amulets Amulet Center 7. Beauty Salon (Non-medical clinic) place for tattooing or piercing the skin or any part of the body 8. Exercise place, fitness 9." Massage shops and spas – but not massage parlours10. Boxing gyms11. Bowling alleys and skating rinks12. Dance academies (no contests)13. Martial arts schools.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210123082710/http://www.bangkok.go.th/main/page.php?3-=&type=detail&id=114335     Therefore Code changed to 2T (Salons - not considered essential).
notes_E2: Note: On September 22, the government passed a new shopping subsidy package for welfare cardholders worth THB 51 billion, financed by the government’s additional borrowing. See: https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 [accessed 5 October 2020, web archive unavailable]
notes_E1: The Thai Government Public Relations Department released a statement 20th Jan 2021 "State Welfare cardholders have received additional funding aimed at helping them weather the economic downturn caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The additional funding of 500 baht applies from January to March. Cardholders making below 30,000 baht a year will receive a cash subsidy of 800 baht a month, up from 300, while those earning over 30,000 baht but not exceeding 100,000 baht annually will see their 200-baht monthly financial aid raised to 700 baht. The state welfare cardholders registered for the subsidies will begin receiving them this week."         The Thai Government Public Relations Department released a separate statement 20th Jan 2021 "The Ministry of Finance has assured that online registrations will be available for the extension of the “Co-pay” campaign and the newly introduced Rao Chana, 2-month stipend campaign. Deputy Government Spokesperson Traisuree Taisaranakul said the government will soon extend coverage for the “Co-pay” general purchases subsidy program for an additional 1 million people. The Rao Chana campaign meanwhile offers eligible applicants a stipend of 3,500 baht per month for 2 months. According to Traisuree, registrations for the “Co-pay” campaign open on Wednesday, January 20th, while registrations for Rao Chana campaign are scheduled for some time between late-January and early-February. "    In statement one - The funding amounts per total earning amounts to not account for more than 50% of earnings.    While not a lot of detail could be found - The terminology "state welfare card holders" in the first release and then "eligible applicants' appears to suggest that not all workers are eligible.  Therefore changed to 1 Formal only or informal only.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210123095511/https://thailand.prd.go.th/more_news.php?offset=0&cid=2&filename=index
notes_C3: 23/01/2021 - Bangkok restriction on gatherings coded on on 21st of December was announced as being in place for a fortnight.  Additionally this appears to have been for the Bangkok Metropolitan area only.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210104062002/https://thailand.prd.go.th/ewt_news.php?nid=10520&filename=index     While not specifically mentioning public events, The  Bangkok Communicable Disease Committee Meeting No. 3/2021, relaxed restriction measures on 22nd Jan 2021. "For today's meeting, the meeting agreed to provide relief. 13 types of establishments can be opened from tomorrow (22 Jan '64) onwards as follows: 1. Arcade game venues 2. Gaming cafes and Internet cafes 3. Elderly care facilities 4. All types of race fields except the field Horse boxing 5. Property catering Banquet Location Including any other places that are similar. 6. Field amulets Amulet Center 7. Beauty Salon (Non-medical clinic) place for tattooing or piercing the skin or any part of the body 8. Exercise place, fitness 9...."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123082710/http://www.bangkok.go.th/main/page.php?3-=&type=detail&id=114335    No other evidence of canceling public events could be found except for political gatherings. The Thailand Government Public Relations Department published a release on 19th Jan 2021 stating: "Government Spokesperson Anucha Burapachaisri, in light of the recent political gathering, disclosed that with the Emergency Decree and Communicable Diseases Act being enforced to control the spread of COVID-19, the Government would like to seek cooperation from the public to refrain from attending any mass gathering. While the Government has been putting utmost effort to implement various economic stimulus measures to relief the plight of people as a result of the current phase of outbreak, the least that it would want to happen is an increased number of infected patients, especially from any political gathering."   https://web.archive.org/web/20210123102347/https://thailand.prd.go.th/more_news.php?offset=20&cid=2&filename=index    Because it appears that there is a nation wide ban on political gatherings and it is stated that this is due to COVID-19, have coded G2 from 19th Jan.
notes_C6: 23rd Jan 2021: It is not clear that there is a nation wide recommendation to stay at home in Thailand.  Currently (from the 22nd Jan), it is also not clear that there are targeted mandated shelter at home.      On January the 18th 2021 the Thailand Government Relations Department published as release stating "The Bank of Thailand forecast that the economy during the new outbreak of COVID-19 would be impacted less than it was during the first wave, even though the new outbreak has spread more widely and quickly than the first wave did. It made the following four points; 1) The Government has not ordered a nationwide lockdown; ...."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123113205/https://thailand.prd.go.th/ewt_news.php?nid=10660&filename=index       The Thailand Government Public Relations Department website has a press release dated 19th Jan 2021 stated that  "Samut Sakhon has announced relaxation of measures [from prior strict 'lock down'] on salons and restaurants in the controlled area. In every district, salons may open from 06.00 hr to 21.00 hr. Restaurants, except in eight sub-districts in the city district, may also open from 06.00 hr to 21.00 hr. This relaxation will be in effect from 16 January to 21 February 2021."     The Bangkok Metropolitan Administration announced on 21st Jan 2021 "For today's meeting [Bangkok Communicable Disease Committee Meeting No. 3/2021] , the meeting agreed to provide relief. 13 types of establishments can be opened from tomorrow (22 Jan '64) onwards as follows: 1. Arcade game venues 2. Gaming cafes and Internet cafes 3. Elderly care facilities 4. All types of race fields except the field Horse boxing 5. Property catering Banquet Location Including any other places that are similar. 6. Field amulets Amulet Center 7. Beauty Salon (Non-medical clinic) place for tattooing or piercing the skin or any part of the body 8. Exercise place, fitness 9." Massage shops and spas – but not massage parlours10. Boxing gyms11. Bowling alleys and skating rinks12. Dance academies (no contests)13. Martial arts schools.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210123082710/http://www.bangkok.go.th/main/page.php?3-=&type=detail&id=114335     Therefore changed the code to 2T from 16th Jan - 21st Jan 2021 and then to 1T on 22nd Jan, noting that while they have eased restrictions remain in place for Bangkok and  Samut Sakhon (though it is difficult to find clear information as to what they are in detail).
notes_C5: 23/01/2021 Unable to find any current information about whether Thailand's public transport is  open or closured.    Website selling bus tickets  https://www.busonlineticket.co.th/booking/bus-tickets.aspx appears to be operating as normal.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210123105613/https://www.busonlineticket.co.th/booking/bus-tickets.aspx

name: Tajikistan
notes_H1: Tajikistan strengthens anti-epidemic measures.      In accordance with the order of the President of Tajikistan dated March 18, 2020, in order to implement measures to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infection (COVID - 19), the Republican headquarters was established to strengthen anti-epidemic measures.    The management of the headquarters is entrusted to the Prime Minister of the Republic of Tajikistan Kohir Rasulzoda.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200529124529/https://asiaplustj.info/ru/news/tajikistan/power/20200320/kohir-rasulzoda-vozglavil-novii-shtab-po-usileniyu-protivoepidemicheskih-meropriyatii
notes_H3: The Khovar state news agency has reported that between February 1 and April 30, nearly 11,000 people have been placed in preventative quarantine. Of that total, 8,438 were discharged without showing signs of ill-health. More than 2,000 are still under observation.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200528225850/https://eurasianet.org/tajikistan-finally-confirms-its-first-15-coronavirus-cases
notes_H2: According to Tajik Deputy Minister of Health Mirhamuddin Kamolzoda, only patients with signs of the virus will be tested. To date, none have been identified in the country.    Tajikistan received a large batch of Russian diagnostic tools, but the Ministry of Health plans to use them only in case of the appearance of primary signs of coronavirus.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200529131935/https://regnum.ru/news/society/2849024.html
notes_C7: There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel. See: https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ (web archive no available, page updated last on September 3, accessed 17th September 2020)
notes_C8: The land borders with Afghanistan, China, Kyrgyzstan, and Uzbekistan are currently closed, though some border crossings with Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan are open for freight vehicles. Limited international flights are operating.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112101554/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/417141/tajikistan-covid-19-entry-restrictions-in-effect-as-of-dec-17-update-6
notes_C4: "Religious gatherings and other large events are prohibited."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201231113810/https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: "Local schools and universities opened in mid-August."  Link: https://web.archive.org/save/https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    "Ministry of Education and Science should strictly monitor the observance of the rules of personal and public hygiene in all educational institutions."  Link: https://web.archive.org/save/http://moh.tj/?p=24325&lang=en
notes_H6: Masks are required at all times outside the home and those who do not comply can be fined. However, due to a lack of economic resources, not all inhabitants can afford buying masks, hence indicator 3.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200907104155/https://www.currenttime.tv/a/tajikistan-masks-law/30674428.html
notes_C2: Workplaces like bazzars and cafes are open. They are required to adhere to strict social distance and hygiene measures.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E2: Higher educational institutions of Tajikistan, according to the decree of the head of the Ministry of Education and Science, cannot expel contract students for late payment of tuition fees, the press service of the department reports.    This category of students will be able to pay for their studies after the stabilization of the epidemiological situation in the country, the report said.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200529074006/https://regnum.ru/news/society/2939280.html
notes_E1: June 19  Up to 50,000 low-income families with young children in Tajikistan will receive a one-time payment of 500 Tajik somoni as emergency social assistance. These payments are provided as part of the World Bank-financed Tajikistan Emergency COVID-19 Project (TEC-19), which is supporting Tajikistan’s efforts in responding to the health and social risks associated with the global COVID-19 pandemic.  NOTE: this funding has been given to the government from external sources such as the World Bank.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200628120135/https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2020/06/19/world-bank-supported-project-finances-cash-transfers-to-protect-vulnerable-children-in-tajikistan  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200618201302/https://reliefweb.int/report/uzbekistan/world-bank-s-covid-19-response-europe-and-central-asia-glance-enru
notes_C3: Since April 18, mosques have been banned from conducting mass prayers and religious rites.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200528180117/https://rus.ozodlik.org/a/30594031.html
notes_C6: "There are no local restrictions or localised lockdowns in place, however you must wear a face covering in public spaces, including in vehicles. Breaches of regulations can result in fines or eventually imprisonment."  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/tajikistan/coronavirus
notes_C5: In connection with the exacerbation of the economic and financial crisis and the growth of unemployment in a number of countries, the activity of service centers, parks and squares, venues for events and holidays in these countries is closed again, public transport is restricted and another quarantine regime has been declared.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/save/http://moh.tj/?p=24325&lang=en

name: Turkmenistan
notes_H1: Facemasks are made compulsory from 13 July. Also, parents are being encouraged to educate children about sanitation. Video grab from TV of a campaign : https://t.me/anthabar/604  http://web.archive.org/web/20201012223737/https://en.turkmen.news/news/turkmenistan-makes-face-masks-compulsory-but-remains-silent-on-covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20201012223408/https://en.hronikatm.com/2020/09/schoolchildrens-parents-are-obliged-to-educate-their-children-about-precautionary-measures/
notes_H2: As per this article, there is hardly any testing happening.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201020210458/https://www.hhrjournal.org/2020/10/covid-19-in-turkmenistan-no-data-no-health-rights/  Officially there are no Covid cases in Turkmenistan as per the same source and this one : http://web.archive.org/web/20201020210712/https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/warning/coronavirus-turkmenistan
notes_C7: "Security forces have erected checkpoints on roads entering Ashgabat. Checkpoints have also been reported on highways in Balkan, Mary, Lebap, and Dashoguz provinces, where health screenings have been carried out. Special permits are required for travel within or between provinces."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064217/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/423761/turkmenistan-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-international-and-domestic-travel-restrictions-until-at-least-jan-31-update-8
notes_C8: "All commercial passenger flights in and out of Turkmenistan are suspended. See Return to the UK. Mandatory quarantine is in place for all arrivals from abroad for up to 14 days. See Entry requirements."  web.archive.org/web/20200706225920/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/staying-during-coronavirus    All international commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan have been cancelled and?land borders?are?closed?to passenger traffic. International?flight restrictions are expected to continue at least through?October 1, 2020.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200909112702/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    At present, entry to Turkmenistan is prohibited except for Turkmen nationals and accredited diplomats, permanently registered foreigners and some employees of international companies and organizations  https://web.archive.org/web/20200816123428/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan
notes_C4: According to an update of the US Embassy in Turkmenistan on 8 Sep 2020, it seems the Turkmenistan government has imposed measures to restrict large gatherings. But the cap on the number of people is not clear. According to the archived webpage, such measures were not in place on 13 Aug 2020, and then showed up at latest on 8 Sep 2020. Such measures remain in place.    "Mosques and places of pilgrimage are closed and large gatherings are restricted."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200909112702/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201016191509/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Schools are open. However, the government is leading an information campaign on sanitary measures due to COVID-19 among school learners. Consequently, school operations result in significant differences as compared to usual, non-Covid-19 operations.    Link: https://archive.vn/bdh45
notes_H6: Not a very authoritative source, but it mentions that from 13 July, face masks are compulsory  http://web.archive.org/web/20201012223737/https://en.turkmen.news/news/turkmenistan-makes-face-masks-compulsory-but-remains-silent-on-covid-19/
notes_C2: Turkmenistan suspended rail links between provinces this week, closed large shopping venues and banned mass gatherings, but the government did not cite COVID-19 as the reason. It said it was taking precautions against viruses, dust and other harmful substances carried across the region by the wind.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200716014003/https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2020/07/15/world/15reuters-health-coronavirus-turkmenistan.html
notes_C3: "Additionally, while there is no official ban on public gatherings, authorities in Ashgabat have deactivated ATMs in shopping centers and semi-enclosed market areas, including the Terkinsky bazaar, to prevent crowds from congregating. All persons are required to observe social distancing of at least 1 meter (3 feet) and wear protective face coverings in public."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064217/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/423761/turkmenistan-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-international-and-domestic-travel-restrictions-until-at-least-jan-31-update-8    "Recreational facilities, non-essential shops, bars and restaurants, entertainment facilities, sports, spa and beauty facilities, and mosques are closed to the public."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064017/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus
notes_C5: Public transport remains severely limited - railways not running and road travel restrictions in place  http://archive.today/2020.10.01-172413/https://rus.azathabar.com/a/30866535.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20201012221726/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

name: Timor-Leste
notes_H1: The Ministry of Transport and Communication launched a hotline for citizens to solves doubts and provides assistance on COVID-19-related matters.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200530110247/http://www.tatoli.tl/2020/03/23/governu-kria-lina-telefonika-numeru-119-asesu-informasaun-kona-ba-covid-19/
notes_H3: Protocols for case detection and contact tracing have been updated based on the new revised  surveillance guidelines. Surveillance teams and rapid responders at national and municipality level have been trained and are on standby to detect and respond to COVID-19 alerts in the country.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200530153458/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/searo/timor-leste/03-03-2020-tls-sitrep-15-ncov-eng.pdf?sfvrsn=e7702ec7_2
notes_H2: "Timorese citizens and foreign nationals can obtain COVID-19 testing at the National Hospital, free of charge. Those seeking to test should call the COVID-19 hotline at +670-7556-0000 via WhatsApp first to receive further guidance on scheduling testing. Fees for testing may be imposed and those seeking testing should confirm the cost when scheduling an appointment."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200831010604/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: No curfew in place, however the below restrictions are in place:    Travel by land and sea between the Special Administrative Region of OecusseAmbeno (RAEOA) and other municipalities of Timor-Leste is prohibited until 23:59 on January 18, 2021.    Additionally, all individuals who have any of the following symptoms – fever greater than 37.5 degrees Celsius, cough, and/or breathing difficulties – are prohibited from boarding buses, ships, or aircrafts and must complete the Mandatory Medical Declaration form. They will be taken to a health facility for COVID-19 testing; positive cases will be subject to therapeutic isolation.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104153050/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Government of Timor-Leste (GOTL) announced it had temporarily closed its airports, ports, and land borders.  During this temporary border closure, the following exceptions will apply:    - Transit of diplomatic or consular personnel, members of international organizations and bilateral cooperation agencies, and workers in the petroleum sector;  - Operation of medical evacuation; and,  - International transportation of goods.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104154759/http://www.tatoli.tl/en/2020/12/24/tl-government-decides-to-close-the-borders-until-january-2021/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104153050/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: Meetings, demonstrations, social, cultural, religious, and sporting events of more than ten people are forbidden.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104153050/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: The Ministry of Education has announced that all the students and professors will return to schools on 18 of january to prepare for the enrolment and the orientation for the new students in Timor-Leste.    The Director-General of the Basic Education, Apolinário Serpa Rosa said Ministry of Education demand the school to be resumed from Kindergarten to high school to continue their classes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118122239/http://www.tatoli.tl/en/2021/01/12/ministry-of-education-announces-schools-to-be-resumed-next-week/
notes_H6: During the state of emergency, all individuals, should wear a face mask covering the nose and mouth when they have to remain in closed public spaces and frequently sanitizing their hands, namely at the entrance of business premises and public administration service buildings.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201014013705/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/EN-CdI_RCM_2020-10-03.pdf
notes_C2: The government approved an extension on the state of emergency, whose restrictions now only regard to the sanitary control at the entrance and exit points of the national territory, circulation in national territory and establishment of residence are maintained. The execution measures relating to workplace closure are clarified in a decree approved on April 29 stating the following:    As in the previous regulation, private businesses are allowed to operate provided that they implement social distancing and sanitary measures.     Now the public sector is also allowed to operate at full capacity. They must ensure social distance and that implement sanitary measures.    Link:   http://web.archive.org/web/20200606073432/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/JRPresDec35Lei4-27Maiu2020pt.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20200606071429/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/?p=24530&lang=en  http://web.archive.org/web/20200606073342/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/GovDec9-29May2020en.pdf
notes_E2: No info. Assumed that policy is over.
notes_E1: On September 23, the government decided to distribute cash transfers for basic staple foods to eligible households, worth US$25 per month per household, lasting for 2 months (November and December) to provide short-term economic stimulus and encourage production and trade, as part of the Economic Recovery Plan.     The beneficiaries of the basic food basket are those who are members of households registered in the “Uma-Kain Register Book” and who are on national territory when the basic food basket is distributed, as well as Timorese citizens who currently attend social, educational, religious, health or prison institutions on a boarding or imprisonment  basis, and for this purpose, they will be treated separately from the respective households listed in the “Uma-Kain Register Book”.    The food basket may be replaced by a shopping voucher for the corresponding goods, in the same amount.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200930222657/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/?p=25696&lang=en  https://web.archive.org/web/20200930223925/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Meetings, demonstrations, social, cultural, religious, and sporting events of more than ten people are forbidden. GOTL recommends that all individuals, who are not subject to compulsory quarantine or engaged in professional activity, remain at home and limit their public activities to the indispensable minimum.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104153050/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: State of emergency extended till December 3rd.  (Refer to the below link)  http://web.archive.org/web/20201130092546/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    In the state of emergency: "You are required to wear a protective mask covering your mouth and nose and a safe distance of at least 1.5 meters must be observed. Anyone who displays a body temperature of higher than 37.5°C, or has a sore throat, or a cold, or respiratory distress including shortness of breath is forbidden to board buses, ships or aircrafts (the only exception is in the case of medical evacuation). Grocery shops, fuel stations, pharmacies, clinics, banking facilities and building material stores remain open but enforce a 1 metre minimum distance between each person."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201130094305/https://travelbans.org/asia/east-timor/
notes_C5: In Government Decree no. 8/2020 of April 30 on the Measures for the Implementation of the Declaration of State of Emergency introduced by Decree of the President of the Republic no. 32/2020, of 27 April, the Government ruled that public transport is permitted, under the public p provided that (1) vehicles are cleaned daily before starting each journey, (2) drivers, crews and passengers wear protective masks, (3) individuals are refused entry if they do not comply, (4) Social distancing is adopted among passengers.    This regulation holds for the entire State of Emergency, now set to end on May 27, 2020.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200525203857/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/D8-2020MedidasEE30Apr2020en.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20200525203950/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/?p=24225&lang=en

name: Tonga
notes_H1: No official announcement of a coordinated campaign was found, however there is evidence of such a campaign including regular government announcements, a dedicated Covid-19 link on the government website, information leaflets on the government website (in Tongan).  Following the coding rules regarding an announcement of a campaign, H1 could be coded as "1G", however the observations noted above suggests it was more coordinated than "Public officials urge caution", hence the code of 2G.
notes_H3: First suspected case of Covid-19.  Article refers to contact tracing.  "He said Health had started to track down people she might have had contact with here in Tonga, from passengers on the aircraft she arrived on from Sydney on Monday, and people close to her."    http://archive.today/2020.12.12-192144/https://matangitonga.to/2020/03/04/suspected-case-coronavirus-tonga
notes_H2: First suspected case of Covid-19 in Tonga.  Article refers to testing, however at this time, Tonga did not have testing equipment and so the samples were sent abroad.      http://archive.today/2020.12.12-192144/https://matangitonga.to/2020/03/04/suspected-case-coronavirus-tonga
notes_C7: The easing of restrictions from 12th April include the reopening of "most" public services, schools and businesses.  There is no reference to restrictions on internal movement (other than curfew which is coded under C6) and so C7 is coded as "0" (no measures)    http://archive.today/2020.12.16-170315/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/331721/tonga-authorities-extend-restrictive-covid-19-measures-until-april-17-update-4
notes_C8: "Tonga declares State of Emergency"  "Starting today, Friday 20 March, at 8:00 pm:   Foreign Nationals are banned from entering Tonga.   Tongan nationals must be quarantined for 14-days upon arrival."  "The State of Emergency applies to all the land and sea areas of Tonga starting today, March 20 to April 17, unless further renewed."  Link: http://archive.today/2020.12.12-162440/https://matangitonga.to/2020/03/20/tonga-declares-state-emergency  Note that there is a slight timing difference between the news article above and Travel Advisory No.6 issued on 23rd March (see link below) which suggests that the border closure policy was implemented from 23rd March  http://archive.today/2021.01.04-191750/https://www.gov.to/press-release/travel-advisory-no-6-for-travelers-arriving-in-or-intending-to-travel-to-tonga/
notes_C4: "Tonga declares State of Emergency"  "Starting today, Friday 20 March, at 8:00 pm:   Public gatherings are restricted.   People are to practice social distancing.   Concerts, sports events, funerals, weddings and birthdays are banned."  "The State of Emergency applies to all the land and sea areas of Tonga starting today, March 20 to April 17, unless further renewed."  "This extends to public gatherings, restricted to a maximum of 20 people inside a building or 40 people outside, and people are to practice social distancing. Concerts, sports events, funerals, weddings and birthdays are also banned."  Link: http://archive.today/2020.12.12-162440/https://matangitonga.to/2020/03/20/tonga-declares-state-emergency
notes_C1: Article about hand-washing at one school in Tonga.  New wash basins had been installed in this and other primary schools in Tonga.  Coding changed to "1" based on the coding guidance for C1 which reflects that the school environment has significantly changed for students.  "She said some children wash their hands at every opportunity they can as it wasn’t always like this at school."  http://archive.today/2020.12.17-173852/https://matangitonga.to/2020/05/05/students-step-hand-hygiene-school
notes_C2: To date, the codes "2G" and "1G" have largely reflected restrictions placed on the opening of bars, night clubs and kava bars.  However, with the further easing of restrictions, such venues are permitted to open Mon-Sat between the hours of 5am - 11pm.  A code of "0" (no measures) was felt to reflect the new policy.    http://archive.today/2020.12.16-193122/https://matangitonga.to/2020/05/29/tongas-covid-19-restrictions-eased-further
notes_E2: See earlier note for E2 on 6th May
notes_C3: Announcement on SoE restrictions    "Night clubs, clubs, bars and kava clubs may be opened for business on Fridays and Saturdays only; from 5:00am to 9:00pm.  Kava drinking sessions prior to church services are permitted on Sundays only.  Daily early morning church services and on Sundays are allowed.     Mass gatherings under the restrictions, which are limited to only 20 people indoors and 40 people outdoors, does not apply to religious services and educational institutions.  All gyms, sporting events and activities, celebration of birthdays, marriages and other recreational or related gatherings shall be permitted, but they shall not exceed the maximum number defined as Mass Gatherings: not exceeding 20 people indoors and 40 people outdoors.  Events such as bingos and contact sports are prohibited.  Funeral gatherings shall be restricted to 20 people indoors and 40 people outdoors."    http://archive.today/2020.12.15-200143/https://matangitonga.to/2020/05/02/tonga-relaxes-covid-19-restrictions-under-state-emergency    In this announcement, there is no general reference to public events other than specific examples such as church gatherings. However,  the limitations on gatherings (20 inside/40 outside) suggests that there are likely to be limits on the type of public event that would meet the policy requirements.  As such, it is coded as "1" recommended rather than "2" (required) or "0" (no measures)
notes_C6: Restoration of curfew (Midnight-5am).  See 21st December for policy announcement
notes_C5: "The government is, however, easing some restrictions, and has stated that certain activities now deemed essential, such as most public services, schools, businesses, and trade operations, will be permitted to reopen. These operations are set to resume normally as of 13:00 on Sunday, April 12. "    It is assumed that the reopening of "most public services, schools, businesses and trade operations" will include public transport, hence the change of code to "0" (no measures)    http://archive.today/2020.12.16-170315/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/331721/tonga-authorities-extend-restrictive-covid-19-measures-until-april-17-update-4

name: Trinidad and Tobago
notes_H1: Government begins releasing daily 'Trinidad and Tobago COVID-19 (Novel Coronavirus) Updates'.   https://web.archive.org/save/http://www.news.gov.tt/content/trinidad-and-tobago-covid-19-novel-coronavirus-update-1#.XpRoalNKg1I
notes_H3: Prime Minister states "Our protocols have been operationalized for some time now. We had tested over fifty cases and this is the first one that tested positive. Contact tracing is taking place. Our professionals have been and are handling the situation and situations."    (https://web.archive.org/web/20200413122852/https://www.opm.gov.tt/prime-minister-dr-the-hon-keith-rowleys-parliament-statement-on-covid-19/)
notes_H2: According to the Ministry of Health's guidelines, a PCR test will be conducted if a public health official decides so.    In accordance with the guidance provided by the WHO, not everyone with flu-like symptoms needs to be tested. If a person does not fit the criteria, testing will not be performed and factors such as clinical history, travel history and/or contact with a COVID-19 positive patient are considered.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200901013919/http://www.health.gov.tt/sitepages/default.aspx?id=305
notes_C7: Changed from 2-Required, to 0-No Measures, because restrictions were eased for movement between the islands of Trinidad and Tobago.    Prime Minister Dr the Hon Keith Rowley announced several adjustments to the Public Health Ordinance Regulations during a media conference held at the Diplomatic Centre, St Ann’s today (Saturday 10th October, 2020).  -Caribbean Airlines will operate six flights daily to Tobago.  **Previously, Air and Sea bridge Transportation to Tobago were limited to essentials.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201123214337/https://www.opm.gov.tt/prime-ministers-media-conference-saturday-10th-october-2020/
notes_C8: "National Security Minister Stuart Young has announced the closure of all borders effective midnight on Sunday. He said no international flights would be allowed to enter the country. This will apply to both nationals and non nationals."  (https://web.archive.org/web/20200413134259/https://trinidadexpress.com/newsextra/t-t-s-borders-closed-to-all/article_5061e42c-6b8b-11ea-8328-3f8003c18b6f.html)
notes_C4: No evidence of a policy change, the number of people gathering should not exceed 10. This was coded as a level 4 not level 3 as the new and revised wording of level 4 permits a gathering up to and including 10 people.  source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102172147/http://www.health.gov.tt/covid19/GuidelinesRegulations/PublicHealthRegulations/PublicHealthRegulations.pdf
notes_C1: 'The Government will advise that from tomorrow all schools and Universities and other places of learning would remain closed for one week in the first instance in order to slow the potential spread of any infection that might be with us at this time.' - The Prime Minister, 13/03.  (https://web.archive.org/web/20200413110343/https://www.opm.gov.tt/prime-minister-dr-the-hon-keith-rowleys-parliament-statement-on-covid-19/)
notes_H6: From 31 August, the Government amended the existing Public Health Ordinance to make the use of face masks in public mandatory. According to Section 6 (7) of the regulation: "No person shall, without reasonable excuse, be in a public space without wearing a face mask, face shield, or face covering in a manner which covers his mouth, nose and chin."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200901020028/http://www.looptt.com:8080/content/7-things-know-about-new-face-mask-legislation
notes_C2: In line with phased reopening announced by government, Phase II began on May 21 and allowed additional industries beyond essential businesses to open.    Government graphic explaining closure stages  https://web.archive.org/web/20200528205540/https:/twitter.com/newsgovtt/status/1263153842201509891/photo/1    Story about manufacturing opening:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200528210025/http://www.guardian.co.tt/news/slow-phase-2-reopening-for-some-businesses-6.2.1121329.a259194645
notes_E2: Following Tamoi's note, there is no evidence of a debt/contract relief program in the country from 1 August onwards.
notes_E1: I am changing policy value from 0 to 1 (<50% lost income) because announcements were made to support some workers who have lost income, but the percentage is unclear at this time since it was just announced.      Prime Minister Dr the Hon Keith Rowley has instructed the Ministry of Finance to allocate an additional $10 million to assist employees of bars and restaurants who have either lost their jobs or suffered a reduction in income, due to the COVID-19 pandemic.    An additional $20 million is also to be provided to the Ministry of Social Development and Family Services to assist self-employed citizens who lost income as a result of the pandemic. Dr Rowley appealed to public servants to be empathetic when dealing with these cases.    The Prime Minister made these announcements during a media conference held at the Division of Community Development, Enterprise Development and Labour, Scarborough today (Saturday 21st November, 2020).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201123195224/https://www.opm.gov.tt/prime-ministers-media-conference-saturday-21st-november-2020-2/
notes_C3: Public gatherings limited to 10 people. "On March 21, the GOTT announced restrictions on gatherings at public places." (https://web.archive.org/web/20200413124105/https://tt.usembassy.gov/information-on-government-of-trinidad-and-tobago-stay-at-home-order-public-health-ordinance/)
notes_C6: As of 26 October, 2020, clubs, theatres, gaming houses, and gyms have all reopened with maximum fifty per cent allowed capacity, indicating that there is no longer a recommendation to stay at home.      According to the Minister of Public Health T. Deyalsingh, in Public Health Regulations 25 October, 2020:  4. (1) For the purposes of controlling and preventing the spread of the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV), it shall be an offence, during the period specified in regulation 17, for any person to--  (7) A maximum of fifty per cent of the allowed capacity of a building is permitted in the following places:  (a) a club as defined in section 2 of the Registration of Clubs Act;  (b) a theatre licensed under the Theatres and Dancehalls Act;  (c) a theatre licensed under the Cinematograph Act;  (d) a common gaming house or betting office licensed under the Gambling and Betting Act; and  (e) a gym or fitness centre.  **Subregulation (7) above is all new since the Public Health Regulations 11 October, 2020**  17. These regulations shall have effect from 26th October, 2020 to 8th November 2020.    Public Health Regulations 25 October, 2020  https://web.archive.org/web/20201123201624/http://www.health.gov.tt/covid19/GuidelinesRegulations/PublicHealthRegulations/PublicHealthRegulations.pdf    For historical reference:  Public Health Regulations 11 October, 2020  http://web.archive.org/web/20201123202223/https://www.covid19.gov.tt/the-public-health-2019-novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-no-29-regulations-2020/
notes_C5: On 15 August, the Government of Trinidad and Tobago announced new measures to contain the surge of COVID-19 cases. The new measures, which are in place from 17 August, require all public taxis and maxis have to operate at 50% capacity and public service also remains at 50% rotation.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200901005409/https://www.opm.gov.tt/prime-ministers-media-conference-saturday-15-august-2020/

name: Tunisia
notes_H1: Dedicated Public Health information Website gives out general advice for the public.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200608201759/https://covid-19.tn/blog/%d9%81%d9%8a%d8%b1%d9%88%d8%b3-%d9%83%d9%88%d8%b1%d9%88%d9%86%d8%a7-%d8%a7%d9%84%d8%ac%d8%af%d9%8a%d8%af-%d9%86%d8%b5%d8%a7%d8%a6%d8%ad-%d8%b9%d8%a7%d9%85%d8%a9/
notes_H3: https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/tunisia-launches-contact-tracing-app-track-coronavirus-spread  https://archive.is/yWNYQ    Tunisia has launched a contact-tracing mobile phone app that identifies and alerts users if they have been in close contact with someone who later reports positive for the novel coronavirus.    The E7mi application, available on Android and awaiting validation for Apple's iOS, was developed by a Tunisian start-up specialised in digital marketing tools for foreign companies, the health ministry told AFP on Tuesday.    If a user tests positive for Covid-19, Tunisia's Observatory of Emerging Diseases (ONME) contacts other users whose cell phones have been detected close to the infected user's device to notify them of the risk.
notes_H2: "If you think you have COVID-19 symptoms, you should call 190 (emergency services SAMU). They will ask a series of questions to assess whether it is likely that you have COVID-19. If COVID-19 is suspected, then they will arrange for someone to come to your home or hotel to conduct a test and they will advise you to self-isolate. COVID-19 PCR tests are only offered free if you are displaying symptoms. You can also pay for a test, if required for travel purposes, at the Institut Pasteur."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200806161617/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/tunisia/coronavirus
notes_C7: "Tunisia has tightened precautionary measures amid a rapid spread of COVID-19 across the country, according to a statement released by the government on Thursday.    The measures, taken after a meeting between Tunisian Prime Minister Hichem Mechichi and members of Tunisia's committee to confront COVID-19 and several ministers, included the extension of the night curfew, suspension of the collective prayer, a ban of gatherings and suspension of classes.    (....)    It was also decided to ban travel and inter-provincial traffic, "except for absolute and exceptional emergencies," the statement said."    "Also, movement between provinces will be prohibited, except for work, students and exceptional cases that can be justified."    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201031131417/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-10/29/c_139476377.htm  http://web.archive.org/web/20201031132054/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/latest-on-coronavirus-outbreak/tunisia-imposes-new-measures-to-stem-coronavirus-/2023792
notes_C8: Tunisia Government has suspended all air travel with Britain, Australia and South Africa regardless of nationality, citing fears of a new coronavirus strain.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210112131345/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-tunisia-int/tunisia-bans-air-travel-with-uk-australia-and-south-africa-over-new-virus-idUSKBN28V1M9
notes_C4: No change in policy.
notes_C1: According to UNESCO, schools in Tunisia are partially open.    Source: https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse (unable to archieve)
notes_H6: Travel in Tunisia  All modes of public transport (taxis, buses, trains and others) are permitted to operate. There may be restrictions on travel between regions. You should follow the advice of local authorities.    The Tunisian authorities have announced that wearing a face mask in public places is mandatory. This includes public transport, health and educational institutions, shopping centres, sports and cultural venues as well as places of worship. Failure to wear a mask may result in a fine or imprisonment.    On 6 December, the Tunisian authorities revised the health measures in place and extended them until 30 December in response to the detection of infection clusters:    A national curfew in all regions across the country,from 8pm to 5am every day.  All cafes and restaurants must close at 7pm, but from 4pm it will be take away only. When they are open they must observe a maximum of 30% capacity in enclosed spaces and 50% capacity in open spaces.  A maximum limit of 30 people is set for private events and funerals.  All prayers in mosques are temporarily suspended.  Additional curfews and lock downs can be imposed at short notice as the government’s response to COVID-19 develops. You should follow the guidance of local authorities when travelling around the country.    https://archive.is/jg7ll
notes_C2: "Tunisian authorities will ban all gatherings and reduce working hours for employees in the public sector in order to stop the rapid spread of the coronavirus, Prime Minister Hichem Mechichi said on Saturday (October 3).    The decision? was taken amid strong fears that hospitals in the North African nation will be unable to cope with a high number of patients because of the shortage of intensive-care beds."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201031132808if_/https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-tunisia/tunisia-to-ban-gatherings-cut-public-sector-work-hours-due-to-pandemic-idUSKBN26O0ZJ
notes_E2: no change since last update   https://archive.is/KkSWz#T
notes_E1: A 2.5 billion TND emergency plan ($0.71 billion or 1.8 percent of GDP) was announced on March 21. From the social side, this also includes cash transfers for low income households, disabled and homeless people (450 TND million for three months). The plan also includes a support for those who will be on temporary unemployment because of the COVID19 shock (300 TND million).   Sources:    https://web.archive.org/web/20200608195445/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19   https://web.archive.org/web/20200608195532/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/tunisia-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html
notes_C3: "Tunisian authorities will ban all gatherings and reduce working hours for employees in the public sector in order to stop the rapid spread of the coronavirus, Prime Minister Hichem Mechichi said on Saturday (October 3).    The decision? ?was taken amid strong fears that hospitals in the North African nation will be unable to cope with a high number of patients because of the shortage of intensive-care beds."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201031132808if_/https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-tunisia/tunisia-to-ban-gatherings-cut-public-sector-work-hours-due-to-pandemic-idUSKBN26O0ZJ
notes_C6: "Tunisia has tightened precautionary measures amid a rapid spread of COVID-19 across the country, according to a statement released by the government on Thursday.    The measures, taken after a meeting between Tunisian Prime Minister Hichem Mechichi and members of Tunisia's committee to confront COVID-19 and several ministers, included the extension of the night curfew, suspension of the collective prayer, a ban of gatherings and suspension of classes.    Mechichi authorized all 24 governors to announce a curfew in their provinces, from Monday to Friday between 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. local time and on Saturday and Sunday from 7 p.m. to 5 a.m."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201031131417/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-10/29/c_139476377.htm
notes_C5: On June 8, 2020, the Tunisian president, Kais Saied, issued an order completely lifting COVID-19 restrictions and the nationwide curfew. An 8 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew had initially been implemented in March 2020 to curb the spread of COVID-19 disease. (Sources 1, 2)    According to the Tunisian minister in charge of major national projects Lobna Jribi, travel between all Tunisian governorates resumed without authorization.(Source 3)    Source 1:   https://web.archive.org/save/http://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/tunisia-president-lifts-covid-19-restrictions-and-lockdown/#:~:text=(June%252015%252C%25202020)%2520On,spread%2520of%2520COVID%252D19%2520disease.    Source 2:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200615155256/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/06/tunisia-orders-lifting-coronavirus-lockdown-200608162437503.html    Source 3:   https://web.archive.org/save/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-06/05/c_139114808.htm

name: Turkey
notes_H1: Turkish Ministry of Health informs about Coronavirus in a series of videos; https://web.archive.org/web/20200211204229/https://twitter.com/saglikbakanligi/status/1225755162737827841, https://web.archive.org/web/20200210073346/https://twitter.com/saglikbakanligi/status/1225737365160939520, https://web.archive.org/web/20200211032634/https://twitter.com/saglikbakanligi/status/1225759617629577218,  https://web.archive.org/web/20200210133127/https://twitter.com/saglikbakanligi/status/1225696129578258432,  https://web.archive.org/web/20200313112513/https://twitter.com/saglikbakanligi/status/1225731397022879745
notes_H3: Ankara also ramped up use of contact tracing to map out the chain of interactions in COVID-19 cases. A staff composed of doctors and other professionals scan the information on confirmed patients in a call center and dispatch teams in protective gear to find the contacts of patients who are viewed as prospective patients themselves. Crews arrange a 14-day quarantine for those potential patients and treatment if they test positive.https://web.archive.org/web/20200422155344/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/turkey-ranks-7th-worldwide-with-600000-coronavirus-tests/news
notes_H2: Coronavirus Scientific Advisory Board issues guidance on testing: "All patient samples conforming to the 2019-nCoV possible case definition should also be evaluated for 2019-nCoV (with a PCR test)."; https://hsgm.saglik.gov.tr/depo/haberler/ncov/2019-nCov_Hastal_Salk_alanlar_Rehberi.pdf (not archivable, https://web.archive.org/web/20200406142757/https://www.aa.com.tr/tr/koronavirus/turkiye-koronaviruse-karsi-tedbirlerini-aldi/1744654
notes_C7: Intercity travel permits are required for Turkish citizens and residents aged 65 and over. Foreigners in the country temporarily for tourism are exempt from curfews and travel permit requirements. In Istanbul, the use of all means of public mass transport has been banned for persons under 20 and over 65 part of COVID-19 restrictions  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/2qeZb
notes_C8: Passengers failing to submit a digital or paper copy of a negative PCR test result are not permitted to board the flights. Those who are in transit, are not required to submit a PCR test in Turkey. Passengers departing from the United Kingdom will not be allowed to enter Turkey. All passengers arriving in Turkey through third countries, who visited The United Kingdom within the last 10 days, will be quarantined for 14 days at places selected by the Turkish officials following their arrival. Passengers arriving from Denmark and South Africa should declare their residency address and stay in isolation for 7 days.   Link: https://archive.fo/2qeZb
notes_C4: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/378526/turkey-istanbul-authorities-introduce-covid-19-social-gathering-restrictions-september-12-update-33  Specifically focused on Istanbul, cancelled parties and weddings. Numbers unspecified
notes_C1: All education and training activities for preschool and kindergarten are suspended.   Link: https://archive.fo/3dmIF
notes_H6: “As of 8 September the wearing of masks is mandatory at all times outside the home throughout Turkey. This includes, but is not limited to, all public places, including streets, side streets, parks, gardens, picnic areas, markets, sea side and public transportation including Metro, buses, taxis and ferries. Masks are also mandatory in all shops, restaurants, hairdressers and barber shops.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200909213906/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkey/coronavirus
notes_C2: On June 1, "Turkey has reopened restaurants and cafes in addition to many other public areas, as the government further eased coronavirus restrictions". Bars, hookah bars and nightclubs were required to remain closed.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200610025346/https://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory/turkey-eases-lockdown-restaurants-reopen-flights-resume-70996794  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/06/turkey-reopens-public-places-coronavirus-lockdown-200601143056501.html (unable to archive)
notes_E2: https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#T  The CBRT has lowered the policy rate by a cumulative 250bps to 8.25 percent as of May 21.  A package of financial measures was introduced at the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic. Specifically, liquidity facilities were augmented, including with longer-term instruments and at discounted rates. The reserve requirements on foreign currency deposits were reduced by 500 bps for banks meeting lending growth targets. A new TL lending facility for SMEs in the export sector was set up. Exporters’ inventory financing is being supported by extending maturities for existing and new export rediscount credits. A second package of CBRT measures (March 31) allowed for an increase in outright purchases of sovereign bonds, and broadened the pool of assets for use as collateral in CBRT transactions. A third package of measures of CBRT increased the upper limit for CBRT’s funding through Open Market Operations and regulated the primary dealer banks outright sovereign bond sales to the CBRT to maintain market depth, strengthen the monetary policy transmission mechanism and support the Primary Dealership system. The bank regulator announced forbearance measures, primarily to limit the accounting impact of TL depreciation and fall in securities’ prices. The LTV limit on mortgages was raised from 80 to 90 percent. The minimum payment for individual credit cards was reduced to 20 percent, and banks postponed repayments on credit card loans for housing, consumer and vehicle purchases. Bank regulator implemented a new regulatory ratio incentivizing banks support for the real economy and government financing Public banks granted firms affected by the crisis a 3-month moratorium on bank loan repayments (principal and interest). Debt enforcement and bankruptcy proceedings (except in alimony cases) have been suspended. Firms’ dividend payments limited to 25 percent of 2019 profits. Exporters will be provided with inventory financing, and reimbursement of rediscount credits have been extended by 90 days.    On May 20, the CBRT announced that the overall limit of the bilateral swap agreement between Turkey and Qatar was increased from US$ 5 billion to US$ 15 billion equivalent. On May 29 the BRSA amended the calculation of the Asset Ratio (AR), imposed on banks to be effective as of May to encourage domestic lending through long term funding.  On June 1, Public deposit banks Ziraat Bank, Halkbank and Vakifbank launched new retail loan campaigns for house purchases and consumer spending. On June 3, the withholding tax on returns from FX mutual funds was raised to 15 percent from 10 percent for real persons and zero for legal persons, and the Capital Markets Board (SPK) imposed some limitations on the portfolio composition of FX mutual funds. On June 5, the CBRT announced the reallocation of TL 20 billion of the TL 60 billion TL rediscount credit facility for exporters towards advance loans for investment in support strategic projects. On June 9, BRSA raised the upper limit on instalment plans for credit card purchases of services from airlines, travel agencies and hotels to 18 months from 12 months.
notes_E1: As part of the measures, the government will pay 60% salaries of staff salaries in the event a firm goes out of business.  Any firm forced out of business due to a force majeure, such as the pandemic, in this case, can approach the government, and the state will pay 60% of the staff salaries for a period of three months. https://web.archive.org/web/20200502095115/https://www.dailysabah.com/business/economy/protecting-smes-employment-priorities-in-turkeys-effort-to-cushion-coronavirus-fallout
notes_C3: “The Interior Ministry sent a circular on expanding virus restrictions from 14 to all of Turkey’s 81 provinces. As of Friday [September 4th], large gatherings such as outdoor weddings and other traditional celebrations will be toned down. The duration of a wedding ceremony in Turkey has been limited to an hour, with a ban on dancing and serving of food. People aged 65 and above and under 15, who are not first and second degree relatives of the bride and groom, will not be allowed to attend the wedding. At least one public officer will attend the wedding ceremony to monitor the measures.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200909231135/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/latest-on-coronavirus-outbreak/turkey-imposes-new-nationwide-virus-restrictions/1961415
notes_C6: Turkish citizens and residents are subject to a weekend curfew (Friday, 9 PM- Monday, 5 AM). Turkish citizens and residents aged 65 and older are restricted to their place of residence, and only allowed outside between 10:00 and 13:00. Turkish citizens and residents aged 20 and below are only allowed outside during the hours of 13:00 and 16:00.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/QZDze
notes_C5: Busses, ferries, and trains are operating, but there are limits to passenger capacity on buses and all passengers must wear a mask. In Istanbul, anyone over 6 years old must be connected with his HES code for Istanbul Kart to use public transportation. Also, in Istanbul, the use of all means of public mass transport has been banned for persons under 20 and over 65 part of COVID-19 restrictions.   Link: https://archive.fo/wip/QZDze and https://archive.fo/wip/2qeZb
notes_H7: A:    Turkey began administering the shots developed by China’s Sinovac to health workers on Thursday, rolling out a nationwide vaccination program.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/Pl16u and https://archive.fo/wip/thTBc

name: Tanzania
notes_H1: In contrast to all other countries I coded so far, the government of Tanzania provides very little to no information about the Covid-19 status in the country. For example, no coronavirus infection updates have been communicated since May.   https://archive.vn/4Up5A    Also, contrary to almost all other countries I coded for, the official government homepage has no prominent link to an overview page of Covid-19 related information.  https://archive.vn/2O54c    Likewise, the government’s Facebook page has no Covid-related information (again, contrary to most other countries I have coded):  https://archive.vn/Acgqo    Same for the government’s Twitter account feed:  https://archive.vn/a8CGE    There is information on the health ministry’s website, via a tab in the top level navigation.  https://archive.vn/ZNPmE  On that website, the government provides a 76 page document from May 2020 that outlines the government’s response to the Covid-19 outbreak. There also were regular situation reports, but those were stopped being posted after May. There do not seem to be any more recent updates.   https://archive.vn/EB6Bk    Given this, there does not appear to be any COVID-19 public information campaign at this time or indeed from June onwards. I am coding this with 0 for this period, and suggest revising to 0 probably from June, given the above.
notes_H3: Tanzania is definitely denying any spread of the virus. A foreign citizen has resulted positive to the virus weeks after the country was declared covid-free. Despite him knowing of at least other 25 people getting COVID, there was no attempt by the govt to trace contacts.  http://archive.fo/zQhLc
notes_H2: Travelers from other countries with symptoms and signs related to COVID-19 infection will undergo enhanced screening and may be tested on arrival.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928033423/https://tz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: According to the US embassy website, all travelers whether foreigners or returning residents whose countries or airlines require them to provide negative testing for COVID-19 as a condition for traveling will be required to present a certificate on arrival. Travelers from other countries with symptoms and signs related to COVID-19 infection will undergo enhanced screening and may be tested on arrival.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928033423/https://tz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: According to the IMF website, effective June 1, 2020, the authorities allowed the opening of upper-secondary and tertiary schools and the resumption of sport activities and events. On June 29, 2020 all other educational institutions reopened. As a result, all the restrictions due to Covid-19 have been lifted by July 2020.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928023258/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: Per coding from Chenxi Zhu from 17 Sep:  According to the UNESCO website, schools are fully open. http://web.archive.org/web/20200928021827/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse According to the IMF website, effective June 1, 2020, the authorities allowed the opening of upper-secondary and tertiary schools and the resumption of sport activities and events. http://web.archive.org/web/20200928023258/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    Per coding from Scott McCullers from 26 Oct:  Schools have re-opened as of late June, but with strict hygiene measures:  -	Wearing of masks  -	Social distancing  -	Hand washing and sanitizers  https://web.archive.org/web/20201026221049/https://www.africanews.com/2020/07/01/all-tanzania-schools-reopen-amid-strict-virus-protocols//    Per the revised C1 coding guidance, given these alterations as health precautions, this should be coded as 1G. It has previously been coded as 0, so I updated this coding for the period from 29 June.     Note however that the education ministry’s website does not provide any Covid-19 related information or guidance.  https://archive.vn/zlgBF
notes_H6: With a higher number of COVID-19 confirmed cases recorded in Tanzania's commercial capital Dar es Salaam, authorities ordered residents to wear face masks beginning Monday April 20th.
