notes_C8: "Local authorities have also instituted:  • the suspension of all international and domestic flights from March 18, until further notice"  From French Government website:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200430113845/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays-destination/venezuela/
notes_C4: Although there is no specific number, President Maduro has insisted during the last week on the need to avoid all types of gatherings.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200516164834/http://mppre.gob.ve/2020/05/10/medidas-decretadas-frenar-avance-covid-19-pais-mantienen-vigentes/  https://web.archive.org/web/20200516155135/https://pandectasdigital.blogspot.com/2020/05/decreto-n-4198-de-fecha-12-de-mayo-de.html  The president addressed ministers and local leaders who have organised public events.   https://web.archive.org/watch?v=wPgGIirIO4M
notes_C1: All schools with classes suspended until no further notice https://www.caraotadigital.net/nacionales/delcy-rodriguez-anuncio-suspension-de-clases-tras-llegada-del-coronavirus-a-venezuela
notes_H6: “People have been instructed to wear face covering at all times when outside.” “Travel in Venezuela…The use of face covering is mandatory at all times, including when travelling via land in private vehicles.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201102203502/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/venezuela/coronavirus
notes_C2: Local authorities have recently moved on to an alternating lockdown/flexible scheme where during a “flexible week” certain specific economic sectors are allowed to operate limited hours; on a “lockdown week” only essential businesses and medical services remain operational..  "7 más 7 plus" plan remains in effect, with one week having strict measures and the next week more relaxed requirements.
notes_E2: From March 22 and during the following six months banks must put the collection of credit payments on hold, telecommunications services would not be cut off, and rent payments for homes and businesses would be suspended (...) He [Nicolás Maduro] also banned companies from laying off employees through December 2020”  http://web.archive.org/web/20200504191924/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-venezuela-idUSKBN21A02V  Although the government has announced the implementation of the Comités Locales de Abastecimiento y Producción (CLAP), as a measure to counteract social necessities because of COVID-19, experts stated that the country has no capacity to finance it.  The government also announced that they will assume the payment of payrolls for small and medium-sized companies for six months. Also, those that are “paying a mortgage will have the possibility to stop paying the installments to the bank, but the bank must assume how to modify and adapt the debt.”  http://web.archive.org/web/20200504192146/https://www.elnacional.com/economia/medidas-economicas-populistas-anunciadas-por-maduro-podrian-enterrar-al-sector-privado/
notes_C6: "Only one member per family is allowed to go outside of their home to access supermarkets/pharmacies." all outings are banned but for essential purpose. https://web.archive.org/web/20200803083037/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/venezuela/coronavirus
notes_C5: Venezuela is increasing lockdown measures in a "radical quarantine" from January 4th to January 10th. Under this new policies all land terminals are closed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110053753/https://www.elnacional.com/venezuela/politica/cuarentena-radical-tras-la-flexibilizacion-de-diciembre-venezuela-retoma-el-esquema-77/

name: United States Virgin Islands
notes_H1: From March 13, Governor Bryan declares a state of emergency and established coordinated public campaign reflected through a timeline.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200730103133/https://www.vi.gov/usvi-covid-19-timeline/
notes_H3: The specific testing benchmark beyond 2% will likely vary considerably by state and dependent upon local disease burdens. The Harvard Global Health Institute has suggested two methods to assess whether testing is adequate. Their benchmark is based on how much testing would be needed for a state to test all infected people and contacts that at predicted burdens. A testing capacity to test all symptomatic people and their close contacts (contact-tracing) is critical to prevent epidemic transmission. The second benchmark that the Harvard Global Health Institute suggests is that communities that demonstrate positivity rates (total positives/total tests) of 10% or lower are likely testing adequately.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201014190157/https://www.covid19usvi.com/sites/default/files/2020-05/Lab%20Faqs.pdf
notes_H2: Tests appear to be available to anyone with symptoms.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.covid19usvi.com/testing
notes_C7: There do not appear to be any restrictions on internal movement.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210117212512/https://usviupdate.com/
notes_C8: All visitors and residents must provide proof of a negative PCR test to enter the Territory or must go into 14-day quarantine upon arrival.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201014181944/https://www.vi.gov/governor-bryan-moves-territory-to-safer-at-home-status/
notes_C4: As of November 9th, by the eighteenth supplemental executive order and proclamation by the governor, gatherings of up to and including 100 people are now permitted.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201121235059/    https://www.covid19usvi.com/sites/default/files/2020-10/2020-09.30%2018th%20Supplemental%20Exec_%20Order--fully%20signed.pdf
notes_C1: US Virgin Islands continue to remain in yellow 'safer at home' stage of reopening. According to guidelines, Virgin Islands Re-opening Schools Guidance 2020-2021, "Phase Yellow: Combination (Hybrid) of virtual and face to face classroom instruction."     http://web.archive.org/web/20201014180644/https://www.covid19usvi.com/sites/default/files/2020-2021%20Reopening%20of%20Schools.pdf Link: https://archive.fo/6xQbb The University of Virgin Islands still remains closed to in-person teaching. Link: https://archive.fo/RUOyn
notes_H6: Masks are required in all public places where distancing is not possible.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201121235059/https://www.covid19usvi.com/sites/default/files/2020-10/2020-09.30%2018th%20Supplemental%20Exec_%20Order--fully%20signed.pdf
notes_C2: "During his weekly press briefing on Tuesday, Governor Albert Bryan Jr. allowed a number of restrictions under the “Stay at Home” order to expire, effectively moving the Territory up to “Safer at Home” status, meaning that nonessential businesses are allowed to reopen."     http://web.archive.org/web/20201014181944/https://www.vi.gov/governor-bryan-moves-territory-to-safer-at-home-status/
notes_E1: CARES Act assistance expired in the USVI on 31 December 2020.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210117213426/https://www.vidol.gov/news/vidol-provides-cares-act-transition-updates/
notes_C3: The Governor of the Virgin Islands announced the prohibition of gatherings of more than 10 persons in all parades, fairs, festivals, churches (Stay at home phase). Later in the Safer at home and Open Doors phase, the government allows these events to take place but participants (less than 50 people) must maintain 6 feet apart and wear masks. - Stay at home:     https://web.archive.org/web/20200729141201/https://www.vi.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/2020-03.23-12-54pm-Order-Suppl-Exec-Order-re-Restrictions-to-Movement-Gatherings-Operations-of-Business-Govt.-and-Schools-.pdf - Safer at home:     https://web.archive.org/web/20200729141325/https://www.vi.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/6th-Supplemental-Exececutive-Order-COVID-19.pdf - Open doors:     https://web.archive.org/web/20200729141731/https://www.vi.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/8th-Supplemental-Exec-Order.pdf - Summary of 3 phases:     https://web.archive.org/web/20200729141833/https://www.vi.gov/covid/phases/
notes_C6: “As a community, we are trying to find a new normal. Our success in this endeavor is dependent on our willingness to adhere to the health guidelines and restrictions,” the Governor said. “Although we are now in week three of the moratorium on leisure guests, the virus is still being transmitted through person-to-person contact. This continues to be the most prevalent mode of transmission for the virus. We must all commit to doing our part to keep each other safe.”     http://web.archive.org/web/20201014181944/https://www.vi.gov/governor-bryan-moves-territory-to-safer-at-home-status/
notes_C5: Begin from May 4, 2020, a Stay safer at home order went into effect. There is no measure related to the closure of public transportations.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200729141325/    https://www.vi.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/6th-Supplemental-Exececutive-Order-COVID-19.pdf
notes_H7: A, C  Pfizer and Moderna  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117214847/https://www.covid19usvi.com/node/3075

name: Vietnam
notes_H1: Gov't created Covid-19 Website for information, followed by numerous information sources.     First press release on site dated for Jan 29. May have been released earlier.     https://ncov.moh.gov.vn/web/guest/-/bo-y-te-ra-khuyen-cao-moi-nhat-huong-dan-7-cach-phong-ngua-virus-corona
notes_H3: “health professionals analyzed and evaluated information related to the 17th patient, including her residential area, travel record, possible people having in contact with her and and possible infection risks in order to conduct epidemiological investigations and make a list of suspected cases subject to quarantine as regulated.”  http://news.chinhphu.vn/Home/COVID19-fight-Everything-remains-under-control-health-official-says/20203/39079.vgp
notes_H2: "As of mid-November, Viet Nam had 86 laboratories nationwide which are capable of providing confirmatory testing for COVID-19, according to the Ministry of Health.  The total include 37 in the North, eight in the Central, three in the Central Highlands and 38 in the South.   In late August, the Government agreed with the Ministry of Health’s proposal to allow public and private medical establishments to conduct COVID-19 testing."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201118111536/http://news.chinhphu.vn/Home/86-establishments-capable-of-providing-confirmatory-testing-for-COVID19/202011/42164.vgp
notes_C7: Public transportation is fully operating, with no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201116113215/https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Jan 4, 2021: "Vietnam's heath ministry has proposed suspending or limiting incoming flights from at least 34 countries and territories that have detected cases of the new COVID-19 variant first found in Britain, the government said on Monday."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104201902/https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-01-04/vietnam-proposes-suspending-all-flights-from-countries-with-uk-covid-19-variant      "Sources from the Vietnam Aviation Authority- Ministry of Transport said that so far, no flight has been permitted to bring Vietnamese citizens from countries around the world to their home in January 2021. In order to effectively control another possible COVID-19 break, it is essential that citizens strictly adhere to the Ministry of Health’s instruction on 5K message: Khau trang (facemask)- Khu khuan (disinfection) – Khoang cach (distance)- Khong tu tap (no gathering) – Khai bao y te (health declaration)."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104202133/https://vietreader.com/news/29316-vietnam-covid-19-updates-jan-4-prevention-measures-tightened-for-lunar-new-year.html
notes_C4: "Vietnam has suspended inbound flights from countries with new COVID-19 variants, initially Britain and South Africa, the nation's health ministry said."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111060543if_/https://www.abc.net.au/web/20210111060543/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-01-06/vietnam-bans-flights-from-countries-with-covid-variant/13035016      "On January 5, 2021, the Vietnamese government issued Directive 01/CT-TTg calling for stricter border control, quarantine surveillance, and more drastic COVID-19 prevention measures.  The Directive also discouraged large gatherings, events, and festivals; requested that high-risk venues, including supermarkets, transport stations, airports, schools, hospitals, and factories, etc., be monitored more closely; and requested that individuals who refuse to wear face masks in public places be given strict penalties."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111061753/https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/    "For further details, please see the Vietnamese government’s website here (in Vietnamese only)."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111061724/https://baochinhphu.vn/Chi-dao-quyet-dinh-cua-Chinh-phu-Thu-tuong-Chinh-phu/Tang-cuong-phong-chong-COVID19-bao-dam-nhan-dan-don-Tet-an-toan/418952.vgp
notes_C1: All schools from kindergartens to universities in HCMC are closed. 170,000 students and teachers are asked to stay at home to combat the latest COVID-19 outbreak.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201208000631/https://e.vnexpress.net/news/news/170-000-hcmc-students-teachers-stay-home-over-latest-covid-19-outbreak-4201147.html
notes_H6: "Hanoi city’s government announced November 11 that wearing a face mask is mandatory at the following locations: 1) hospitals; 2) parking lots; 3) public transportation; 4) shopping malls; and 5) supermarkets and traditional markets.  Other localities in Vietnam may take similar measures without prior notice."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130194455/https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/      Mandatory wearing of masks in public, especially the 5 places enumerated above.  "Theo dó, Phó Ch? t?ch UBND Thành ph? Ngô Van Qúy d? ngh? các don v? ti?p t?c tuyên truy?n nh?t là vi?c b?t bu?c deo kh?u trang noi công c?ng; qu?n lý ch?t ch? các khu cách ly, các tru?ng h?p nh?p c?nh trái phép. 5 d?a di?m: B?nh vi?n, b?n bãi d? xe, phuong ti?n công c?ng, trung tâm thuong m?i, siêu th?, ch? ph?i b? trí ngu?i ki?m soát ch?t ch?, ai không có kh?u trang không cho vào, b? trí di?m bán kh?u trang ngay ? c?a."     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130201649/http://thanglong.chinhphu.vn/khong-duoc-vao-5-dia-diem-neu-khong-deo-khau-trang
notes_C2: "All activities including the opening of bars and clubs resumed in Da Nang on September 25 after it controlled the pandemic. However, Hanoi city authorities closed some bars and karaoke temporarily for failing to comply with anti-pandemic measures like face mask-wearing and public gatherings."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130185225/https://www.vietnam-briefing.com/news/vietnam-business-operations-and-the-coronavirus-updates.html/
notes_E2: According to IMF, the SBV has issued guidelines to commercial banks to reschedule loans, reduce/exempt interest, and provide loan forbearance.   Newly approved measures include deferring excise tax on domestically produced cars, lowering land rental, cutting or exempting various fees and charges, cutting CIT rate for small and micro firms, and raising PIT deduction.  Financial institutions are also exempting and reducing fees. Affected firms are eligible to concessional loans from Vietnam Social Policy Bank (VSPB) with no interest for making salary payment to their workers who temporarily stopped working.   http://web.archive.org/web/20200723164138/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: Vietnam on April 9 issued Resolution No. 42/NQ-CP (Resolution 42) to help individuals and businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Resolution consists of a financial package for those affected by the pandemic and targets six categories of individuals and businesses not covered by unemployment insurance. Individuals affected are eligible for $43 per month (https://web.archive.org/web/20200507062819/https://www.vietnam-briefing.com/news/covid-19-vietnam-issues-financial-assistance-employers-employees.html/) GDP per capita in Vietnam is about $225 a month (https://web.archive.org/web/20200507063130/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/vietnam/overview)
notes_C3: November 30, 2020: "A number of festivals and events in Vietnam have been cancelled or postponed in alignment with the government’s directive to avoid public gatherings"    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130195050/https://vietnam.travel/things-to-do/information-travellers-novel-coronavirus-vietnam
notes_C6: A partial lockdown of Da Nang has been applied from midnight 27 July. This includes staying at home, wearing masks and adhering to social distancing if there is an essential need to leave the home. Residents in several districts in Da Nang are asked to stay at home and only go out in emergencies, such as going to the store or the pharmacy, in emergencies or when working in factories.https://web.archive.org/web/20200730103756/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/vietnam/coronavirus
notes_C5: Public transportation is fully operating, with no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201116113215/https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

name: Vanuatu
notes_H1: Not sure about the starting date. I am considering the state of emergency declaratory http://web.archive.org/web/20200614235155/https://covid19.gov.vu/
notes_H3: In previous comments, the absence of confirmed cases was noted and the code H3=1 has been unchanged for several months.  The first confirmed case on 10th November was followed up by detailed contact tracing as described in Situation Report 27 on the Ministry of Health Covid-19 website.      The details provided on contact tracing suggest that it is comprehensive:    "CONTACT TRACING AND QUARANTINE OF CLOSE CONTACTS OF THE CONFIRMED CASE  • Contact tracing commenced on 11 November 2020 following confirmation of the first COVID-19 case.  • The case was interviewed to identify people with whom they were in close contact*.  • Of the 152 other passengers on the same flight, 17 were identified as close contacts as they sat within two rows of the case on the plane; no other close contacts were identified.  • All close contacts have been in quarantine since arrival on 4 November 2020 and will remain so under health clearance is provided. All close contacts had received daily health monitoring and had been tested for SARS-CoV-2; all tests were negative. Subsequent tests will be conducted as per established quarantine protocols. "    In addition, workers at the airport:    "AT RISK ASSESSMENT FOR OCCUPATIONAL EXPOSURE^  • Investigations commenced on 11 November 2020 also targeted workers involved in the repatriation process (including airline, airport, customs, immigration, biosecurity, health, transport and hotel staff) so as to identify those who were at occupation risk.  • 19 people have so far been identified and all were interviewed on 11 November 2020. 12 people met the screening criteria for potential exposure; all reported low-risk exposure and proper use of personal protective equipment.  • As a precautionary measure, tests were conducted for the 12 at risk people; all results were negative. All are currently in quarantine."    The report is a PDF (Situation Report No.27, dated 12th November)  Link:  http://archive.today/2020.11.16-171059/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/situation-reports
notes_H2: Only those who meet the case definition will be able to be tested for COVID-19. This Includes people who have clinical symptoms, and travel history or contact with a COVID-19 case. People with clinical symptoms without travel history or contact with COVID-19 case will not be tested.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200614235453/https://covid19.gov.vu/images/Information-Sheets/Community_messaging_lab_testing_v2.pdf
notes_C7: "As of 1st December 2020, Vanuatu has no active cases of COVID-19. According to the the COVID-19 Health Sector Preparedness and Response Plan, Vanuatu is now in Scenario 1 (no cases)."    "Scenario 1 (no cases):   - No restrictions on schools, workplaces, public or private gatherings.  - Installation of handwashing stations.  - Preparation of response plans.  - Follow hygiene and prevention measures."    "Inter-islands travel restrictions" apply only for Scenario 3 (Community Transmission).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201204143207/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php
notes_C8: All borders closed from state of emergency /web/20200615003756/https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2020/mar/24/coronavirus-travel-updates-which-countries-have-restrictions-and-fco-warnings-in-place
notes_C4: A State of Emergency is in place in Vanuatu until 31 December 2020, in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. There are no restrictions in place on social gatherings. Restaurants, bars and supermarkets are permitted to open as usual, although some are operating a restricted service or have closed altogether in response to falling trade.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200828083359/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/vanuatu/coronavirus
notes_C1: "The Ministry of Health confirmed on 11 May 2020 that there are no confirmed cases nor suspected cases of COVID-19 in Vanuatu since the first declaration of State of Emergency on 26 March 2020. Thus, the MoET announced the re-opening of the schools to students on Monday 18 May 2020. The schools are required to resume all classes and to have good hygiene and hand washing practices in place for students and staff." https://web.archive.org/web/20200618131359/https://www.gov.vu/index.php/events/news/72-schools-to-reopen-on-monday-18-05-2020
notes_C2: No measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200828083359/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/vanuatu/coronavirus
notes_E2: Rent tax cancelled for all tenants and landlords for the year 2020:  "Part of the Governments economic and fiscal stimulus package in response to the Covid-19 Virus is to cancel rent tax in respect of the 2020 year.  This means that there is no requirement to file rent tax returns or make payments of rent tax in the 2020 year.  The rent tax returns and payments usually due on 29th June 2020 and 28th December 2020 are not required."    https://vanuatucustoms.gov.vu/images/public_notice/2020/Public_Notice_no003_2020.pdf
notes_E1: Employment Stabilization Payment came to an end in June. The Vanuatu Chamber of Commerce and Industry (VCCI) has requested that an extension of a minimum of three months be made to the Employment Stabilization Payment (ESP) so that affected businesses can retain staff (but this has not yet been confirmed) http://archive.fo/IY1og
notes_C3: A State of Emergency is in place in Vanuatu until 31 December 2020, in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. There are no restrictions in place on social gatherings. Restaurants, bars and supermarkets are permitted to open as usual, although some are operating a restricted service or have closed altogether in response to falling trade.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200828083359/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/vanuatu/coronavirus
notes_C6: No measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200828084538/https://covid19.gov.vu/
notes_C5: No measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200828084538/https://covid19.gov.vu/

name: Yemen
notes_H1: "The Ministry of Public Health and Population announces the state of comprehensive health mobilization for doctors, health personnel, technicians, and preventive quarantine experts, in preparation for facing the Coronavirus." (Translated from Arabic)  http://web.archive.org/web/20200510135933/http://www.moh.gov.ye/news_details.aspx?id=2264
notes_H2: Authorities in Aden setup a new specialized field hospital in Al Mualla district for patients with fever. On 04 October 2020, a COVID-19 examination unit opened at the isolation center in Ataq, Shabwah Governorate. Fifteen sea border points and three land border points are partially open for movements. There have been ten transit points for public movement between southern and northern governorates. Since the COVID-19 pandemic outbreak, the Yemeni authorities have put additional preventive measures and health screenings for people passing through these transit points, specifically at points located in Taizz and Al-Bayda. For Yemeni returnees from KSA through the Al’Wadeeah border entry point, carrying a COVID PCR test report is mandatory by the Yemeni authorities. Authorities at Al’Wadeeah entry point have established and installed a PCR testing facility at the entry point for travelers who arrive without a PCR test report.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201029155117/https://displacement.iom.int/yemen
notes_C7: in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the local authorities of Yemen declared a nationwide health emergency and introduced many preventative measures similar to those adopted by rest of the world starting in March 2020 in order to reduce the transmission of COVID-19. These measures include the adoption of restrictions on movement countrywide.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201029155916/https://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/covid-19-movement-restrictions-yemen-mobility-restriction-dashboard-14-21-october-2020
notes_C8: Recently, on December 2020 ,20. Saudi authorities announced the closure of Al Wadeeah border entry point for a week, and it was extended for another week within the framework of the comprehensive closure of all its borders  https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/20201230_COVID19_DTM%20Yemen%20Mobility%20Restrictions%20Dashboard%20%2319.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118220329/https://dtm.iom.int/reports/yemen-covid-19-mobility-restrictions-30-dec-2020  The Yemeni authorities have announced entry restrictions aimed at limiting the spread of COVID-19. The majority of land, sea and air ports are closed until further notice, with only very limited international flights taking place. Exemptions are in place for humanitarian relief and essential goods.   /web/20210118220734/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/yemen/entry-requirements
notes_C1: Schools are reported as fully open (in policy) on UNESCO tracker; confirmed in independent media reports. Public health prevention measures in place (e.g. hand washing). However, in practice armed conflict has also forced some school closures as reported in media, regardless of stated COVID-19 school closure policy.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201215001741/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse    http://web.archive.org/web/20201215001546/https://www.unicef.org/yemen/stories/schools-reopen-yemen-after-months-closure-due-covid-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026164301/https://www.middleeasteye.net/fr/news/classrooms-rebel-held-yemen-shuttered-first-day-school-799916572
notes_H6: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the local authorities of Yemen declared a nationwide health emergency and introduced many preventative measures similar to those adopted by rest of the world starting in March 2020 in order to reduce the transmission of COVID-19.  But there is a lack of PPE means it not generally followed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201029163154/https://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/yemeni-women-take-lead-fight-against-covid-19
notes_C2: Due to the civil war yemen is split in two with Saudi-backed government and the  Iran-backed Houthi rebels. Travel between area controlled by the different groups is restricted and controlled. but there is no No curfew is in effect anywhere in Yemen. In the southern governorates, all markets are open. Authorities in Aden setup a new specialized field hospital in Al Mualla district for patients with fever. On 04 October 2020, a COVID-19 examination unit opened at the isolation center in Ataq, Shabwah Governorate. On 13 July 2020, in the northern governorates, local authorities reopened public places, such as wedding halls, restaurants, cafeterias, steam and traditional baths, public parks and sports fields, with the condition of following COVID-19 preventive measures like st sterilization and social distancing.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201029155916/https://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/covid-19-movement-restrictions-yemen-mobility-restriction-dashboard-14-21-october-2020
notes_C3: On 13 July, businesses in Houthi-controlled areas of the country were ordered to open, including "restaurants, wedding halls, public baths, parks and playgrounds", while maintaining social distancing, according to the Associated Press.     Reported by Xinhua: "The decision came after the imposed measures have resulted "positive impact" related to control the spread of the coronavirus, said the television, citing a statement by the local health authorities."    Additionally, a 13 July report from an IRC representative in Yemen indicates cancellations of public events are no longer in effect in government-controlled regions despite official recommendations to practice social distancing.    Reported in the Telegraph: "Few precautions have been enacted to stop the spread, said Tamuna Sabadze, head of the International Rescue Committee aid agency in Yemen.  “There are no restrictions on movement, the shops, malls, markets, everything is open. There is no social distancing, public transport is moving freely. There are no prevention measures in place that can actually prevent the spread of the virus and it doesn't just disappear on its own.”"    With this announcement, it is likely that public event cancellations are effectively no longer in place in both government and Houthi controlled regions of Yemen, hence a coding of 0.    http://archive.fo/ICkpZ  http://archive.fo/qhC5u  http://archive.fo/KtSes
notes_C6: Curfews are in effect in Marib governorate from nine in the evening until six in the morning.  https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/20201230_COVID19_DTM%20Yemen%20Mobility%20Restrictions%20Dashboard%20%2319.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118220329/https://dtm.iom.int/reports/yemen-covid-19-mobility-restrictions-30-dec-2020

name: South Africa
notes_H1: 5 March 2020 - South Africa's President Cyril Ramaphosa has warned that the coronavirus will turn into a "national crisis" and its impact will be "huge".  His warning came after the first case of the coronavirus was detected in South Africa.     https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-51752974     https://www.gov.za/Coronavirus
notes_H3: 7th March- tracing of all members of a group of 10 from Italy from which one tested positive.  The public must be notified that we have information and know the whereabouts of all the other 10 people who were part of the group that had travelled to Italy. All those who came back to South Africa, are currently being tested. We are now awaiting their test results to come out. Since being traced, they have remained in isolation to avoid any further contact with third parties.  	https://web.archive.org/web/20200406162441/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/2020/03/07/confirmation-of-second-case-of-covid-19-in-south-africa/
notes_H2: South Africa’s mass screening helps stem the coronavirus tide https://web.archive.org/web/20200611185300/https://www.ft.com/content/98d0d7c6-9bfb-4a64-bcab-19e0854a3b4d
notes_C7: Movement Restrictions:  Is a curfew in place?   Yes  Under Alert Level 3, the curfew will apply from 2100 until 0600 daily.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  https://web.archive.org/web/20210114090801/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/
notes_C8: Per US Embassy, On November 11, President Ramaphosa announced that the Government of South Africa is opening up international travel to all countries subject to the necessary health protocols and the presentation of a negative COVID-19 certificate.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201129221233/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/    All international travel will resume subject to-  (a) the traveler providing a valid certificate of a negative test which was obtained not more than 72 hours before the date of travel; and  (b) in the event of the traveler's failure to submit a certificate as proof of a negative test, the traveler will be required to quarantine him or herself at his or her own costs.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201218092127/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/individuals-and-households/travel-coronavirus-covid-19
notes_C4: Limiting gatherings of any kind to 10 persons maximum with few exceptions.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210110225944/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/
notes_C1: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted education across the globe, and while schools have managed to carry on using online resources and dividing attendance days, some students have been unable to return to school as a result of this disruption.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201220235137/https://www.globalcitizen.org/en/content/south-africa-children-school-drop-out-covid-19/  Academic break. https://web.archive.org/web/20201220234525/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H6: (2) The wearing of a face mask is mandatory for every person when in a public place, excluding a child under the age of six years, and any person who fails to comply with a verbal instruction by an enforcement officer to wear a face mask, commits an offence and is, on conviction, liable to a fine or a period of imprisonment not exceeding six months, or to both such fine and imprisonment.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210114094809/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/2021/01/12/summary-of-level-3-regulations-as-of-12th-january-2021/
notes_C2: According to the government website. People can go to work. Cases are spiking.  Anyone who is sick or displaying symptoms should not go to school or work. If you have been in close contact with a confirmed COVID-19 case, you should self-isolate for 14 days from the date of close contact. If you are concerned, contact your medical practitioner for further advice.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201029001720/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/faqs/
notes_E2: The government has put in place a loan guarantee scheme for companies below a certain turnover. The government also announced measures for relief for borrowers from banks  https://web.archive.org/web/20200608210933/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: President Cyril Ramaphosa has announced that government will direct R50 billion towards grants, in which child grant recipients will receive R300 in May and R500 in June. https://web.archive.org/save/https://ewn.co.za/2020/04/21/watch-live-ramaphosa-says-r50bn-allocated-towards-grant-recepeints  South African President Cyril Ramaphosa announced a 500 billion rand ($26.3 billion USD) rescue package, equivalent to 10% of the GDP of Africa’s most industrialised nation, to try to cushion the economic blow of the coronavirus pandemic.  The package will target large increases in existing welfare grants, funds for protecting jobs.   Additionally, 200 billion rand ($10 billion USD) in loan guarantees in partnership with the central bank of South Africa, finance ministry and commercial banks, and tax deferral for firms with more than 100 million rand turnover.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200501072953/https://www.ft.com/content/e07b70bd-71ae-4b8a-9855-09665330fed9     He is addressing the nation on Tuesday night on additional economic and social relief measures that form part of the national response to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic.    All the other recipients will receive R260 extra for the next six months    The unemployed, with no source of income, will receive a monthly stipend of R350 for the next six months.    Ramaphosa said Sassa will be distributing food through the provision of vouchers for the vulnerable for the poor.
notes_C3: Nearly all indoor gatherings and outdoor gatherings are prohibited.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110225944/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/
notes_C6: 33. (1) Every person is confined to his or her place of residence from 21H00 until 05H00 daily, unless a person-  (a) has been granted permission through directions by the relevant Cabinet member or a permit, which corresponds with Form 7 of Annexure A, to perform a service other than a service related to an activity listed under Table 2; or  (b) is attending to a security or medical emergency.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210113090424/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/alert-level-3-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown
notes_C5: Per US embassy, Public rail, minibus taxi, and bus services have resumed at reduced levels subject to social distancing and mandatory use of face masks for passengers and drivers.  Minibus taxis and buses must reduce their maximum licensed passenger seating capacity to 70% a vehicle, e-hailing services that are licensed to carry up to four passengers are limited to carrying 50% of their permissible passenger carrying capacity.  Transport services are required to provide adequate sanitizers for washing of hands of all passengers.  Operators must ensure that their vehicles are sanitised before picking up and after dropping off passengers.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201129221233/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

name: Zambia
notes_H1: Zambia’s Ministry of Health (MoH) has implemented several measures as of Friday, February 21, to prevent the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19) into the country. Health workers have deployed to points of entry to conduct temperatures scans and a hospital in Chilanga district has been designated as an isolation center for treating possible cases.    https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/316201/zambia-coronavirus-screening-measures-implemented-as-of-february-21
notes_H3: Minister of Health confirmed that every contact associated with the cases that emerged in Zambia will be traced and put under surveillence. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200406203416/https://diggers.news/local/2020/03/26/coronavirus-cases-jump-to-16/
notes_H2: https://archive.vn/MFKur and  http://web.archive.org/web/20201004151532/https://www.moh.gov.zm/ - while not explicitly called out, both websites imply testing is available for walk-in or by appt for anyone (for a price)
notes_C7: Movement Restrictions:    Is a curfew in place? No  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201004153230/https://zm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/
notes_C8: Zambia’s borders are open, but under tight screening. All visitors to Zambia must have proof that they have tested negative for COVID-19 in the 14 days before their arrival.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201018205447/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/zambia/entry-requirements
notes_C4: Public gatherings of more than 5 people, who are not a family, need written approval from the local authority.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201004152728/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/zambia/coronavirus
notes_C1: C1 1G The Zambian Ministry of General Education announced phased re-opening dates for educational facilities for classes of graduating students between 14 and 28 September 2020 via Facebook posting on 12 September, non-graduating & foreign students to continue with e-learning. https://archive.vn/4CB1w and https://web.archive.org/web/20201223020359/https%3A%2F%2Fzambiatoday.com%2Fcollegesuniversities-to-reopen%2F
notes_H6: "Per the Minister of Health’s statement today, President Lungu issued a directive making the wearing of masks in public mandatory as part of increased COVID-19 prevention measures in Zambia. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20200831022334/https://www.osac.gov/Country/Zambia/Content/Detail/Report/251986cc-38ee-4e4c-ad78-1875ef77459e    https://web.archive.org/web/20200831022503/https://www.zimeye.net/2020/04/17/zambia-makes-wearing-of-masks-mandatory-in-public-areas/
notes_C2: Restaurants, gyms and casinos are allowed to open, but bars and taverns remain closed (this seems like a national measure, so I am not sure about the previous coding of 2T). See:https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/zambia/coronavirus (accessed 14th September 2020, web archive unavailable)
notes_E2: The government has waived tax penalties and fees on the outstanding tax liabilities resulting from CoVID-19, suspended customs duties and VAT on some medical supplies and medical related commodities, removed provisions relating to claim of VAT on imported spare parts, lubricants and stationery to ease pressure on companies. The government had set up an Epidemic Preparedness Fund amounting to 57 million kwacha (0.02% of GDP) and had approved a COVID-19 Contingency and Response Plan with a budget of 659 million kwacha (0.2% of GDP)  https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: http://archive.is/sg5DX  Presidential statement  25 June.  “ALL THE BUSINESSES INCLUDING BARS AND NIGHTCLUBS, SCHOOLS, COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES WILL EVENTUALLY REOPEN AND RESUME OPERATIONS ONCE WE GO THROUGH THIS PERIOD. THE WORLD HEALTH ORGANISATION (WHO), AND THE CENTRE FOR DISEASE CONTROL (CDC), THROUGH THE MINISTRY OF HEALTH, HAVE WARNED ABOUT A SPIKE DURING THIS COLD SEASON IF WE RELAX THE MEASURES THAT WE HAVE PUT IN PLACE.”  “AS I CONCLUDE, I WISH TO ENCOURAGE YOU, FELLOW COUNTRYMEN AND WOMEN, TO CONTINUE ADHERING TO THE SET GUIDELINES AND SOCIAL MEASURES AS FOLLOWS:(A) MANDATORY USE OF FACE MASKS BY EVERYONE IN PUBLIC; (B) AVOID UNNECESSARY CROWDING AND ENSURE SOCIAL DISTANCING; (C) PROVISION OF FACILITIES FOR HAND HYGIENE AND SANITATION; (D) REGULAR CLEANING AND DISINFECTION OF PUBLIC AMENITIES; (E) OBSERVANCE OF PERSONAL HYGIENE AND COUGH ETIQUETTE; AND (F) AVOIDING UNNECESSARY MOVEMENTS.”
notes_C6: No new update

name: Zimbabwe
notes_H1: From today (Friday), in Zimbabwe Covid-19 awareness messages will be broadcast on two national radio stations in three local languages, reaching five million people (this is sponsored by Goal Global, an NGO)  https://web.archive.org/web/20200504143836/https://www.goalglobal.org/stories/irish-humanitarian-aid-agency-goal-leading-fight-against-spread-of-covid-19-in-zimbabwe/
notes_H3: "The Ministry of Health in Zimbabwe is currently tracing people who might have been in contact with the country's prominent journalist who died of Covid-19." [https://web.archive.org/web/20200521125322/https://www.msn.com/en-za/news/africa/covid-19-death-zim-tracing-people-who-came-into-contact-with-deceased-man/ar-BB11CzZY]
notes_H2: "Zimbabwe currently has one COVID-19 testing centre situated at the National Microbiology Reference Laboratory. [...] Some people are worried to the extent of questioning if the country has the required manpower and enough machines to do the job expeditiously." [https://web.archive.org/web/20200521132359/http://www.mohcc.gov.zw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=253%3Acovid-19-testing-in-zimbabwe&catid=79%3Aslider&Itemid=435&highlight=WyJ0ZXN0aW5nIiwidGVzdCIsInRlc3RzIiwidGVzdGVkIl0%3D]  "With kits unavailable, neither doctors nor suspected sufferers are being tested." [https://web.archive.org/web/20200521132458/https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2020/apr/09/doctors-sue-zimbabwe-government-over-lack-of-covid-19-protective-equipment]
notes_C7: “Starting Monday March 30, 2020, and subject to further review, Zimbabwe will be under a total lockdown for a period of 21 days,” Mnangagwa said. “This means all our citizens are required to stay at home except, of course, in respect of essential movements relating to seeking health services, to purchase and procure food and medicines and other critical services supplies.”   GVT “staying home means- only go outside for food and health reasons. Do not meet or visit others, even friends and family”  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.newsday.co.zw/2020/03/mnangagwa-imposes-21-day-lockdown/   /web/20200425192306/https://twitter.com/MoHCCZim/status/1244265605429149698/photo/1
notes_C8: Cros hoarder services stopped except for commercial cargo.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210104135235/https://iharare.com/zimbabwe-tighten-covid-19-lockdown/
notes_C4: Only essential businesses can remain open and all gatherings such as wedding ceremonies or religious services are banned, with the exception of funerals, which are limited to 30 people.
notes_C1: "only exams classes to open now the rest remains closed"  http://web.archive.org/web/20210104135235/https://iharare.com/zimbabwe-tighten-covid-19-lockdown/
notes_H6: wear faces masks always and offenders to be prosecuted.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210104135235/https://iharare.com/zimbabwe-tighten-covid-19-lockdown/
notes_C2: only essentials services, hospitals, pharmacies and supermarkets to operate. Only opening at 8am and closing at 6pm.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210104135235/https://iharare.com/zimbabwe-tighten-covid-19-lockdown/    Operating hours are changed after first announcement.  Only essential services such as supermarkets, hospitals and pharmacies will be allowed to operate from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m., and most Zimbabweans are required to stay at home.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111110036/https://www.africanews.com/2021/01/05/30-day-lockdown-for-zimbabwe-in-light-of-a-spike-in-covid-19-cases/
notes_E1: $200 approved to be transferred to each "poor person" to assist with coronavirus-related expenses. One time cash transfer.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200506022954/https://www.newsday.co.zw/2020/04/needy-people-to-get-200-lockdown-cushion/
notes_C3: Although all public gatherings are required to be cancelled, religious gatherings are restricted to 50 people.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C6: Starting 22 July, security forces will enforce a curfew between 6pm-6am local time. All non-working people will be required to stay at home, except to buy groceries and seek medical attention. Business hours will be limited to 8am to 3pm, apart from those performing essential services.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200730220048/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/07/zimbabwe-imposes-curfew-spike-coronavirus-infections-200722052647613.html
notes_C5: The Zimbabwean government announced a lockdown starting from 30 March. This lockdown has now been extended until 3 May. Public transport is now very limited.  Zimbabwean authorities on Monday began enforcing a three-week lockdown   In the township of Mbare, the usually bustling terminus for long-distance buses was deserted with only municipal street cleaners sweeping the empty bus ranks. We have been waiting here for more than two hours but there are no buses," Jawure told AFP while standing with his wife and daughter beside a bulging suitcase.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200504135902/https://www.news24.com/Africa/Zimbabwe/coronavirus-zimbabwe-begins-21-day-total-lockdown-20200330  https://web.archive.org/web/20200504140036/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/zimbabwe/return-to-the-uk

name: Taiwan
notes_H1: Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) is activated to serve as a coordinator of all epidemic responses and update the public about COVID-19. Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20200405093236/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Bulletin/Detail/32NPG1QXFhAmaOLjDOpNmg?typeid=9 ; https://web.archive.org/web/20200407070520/https://www.ocac.gov.tw/OCAC/Eng/Pages/Detail.aspx?nodeid=329&pid=15730946
notes_H3: Taiwan centers for disease control  https://web.archive.org/web/20200414072715/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/File/Get/LO4IJGwYKrJ5urP3CQeLbw  On January 23, 2020, level 2 of the CECC was established due to the fact that the first case of COVID-19 was confirmed on January 21, 2020.  3. Surveillance and Laboratory Diagnosis: (1)We began to identify people who developed fever, cough or other acute respiratory symptoms and who had a past 14-day travel history or close  contact with the above mentioned people. They are all required to report to the health authorities and provide a lab specimen for further laboratory diagnosis. (2)When a person seeks medical attention using his or her National Health Insurance (NHI) card, the person’s travel history to areas affected by COVID-19 will display on the system because immigration data is linked to the National Health Insurance Administration. This system helps remind a physician to pay attention to past 14-day travel history and inquire and examine the person accordingly. This can effectively prevent failing to detect a potential case.(3)Since February 16, 2020, we have enhanced COVID-19 case finding by proactively seeking out patients with severe respiratory symptoms who had tested negative for influenza and retested them for COVID-19. In addition, patients who are highly suspected as COVID-19 infection by the physicians as well as medical staff with pneumonia or cluster are also subject to provide specimens for further laboratory diagnosis. (4)In order to have specimens tested quickly, we have improved our laboratory diagnosis capacities from 12 laboratories for 520 cases per day to 34 laboratories for 3,200 cases per day.
notes_H2: "On May 23, the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) announced that it gradually eased restrictions on applicants for coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) testing considering that domestic coronavirus situation is under control.  The decision allows members of the public to undergo COVID-19 testing at their own expense at designated hospitals due to emergency situations, as well as work and studying abroad requirements, and obtain documents proving they have done the testing. Members of the public who are eligible for requesting COVID-19 testing at their own expense are as follows: 1.    Those under home isolation or quarantine who need to attend a funeral of a deceased first or second degree relative or visit such relative with serious illness; 2.    Those who need to visit other countries/regions for an emergency involving their relatives overseas, including accidents or serious illness; 3. Those requesting COVID-19 testing for work; 4.  Those requesting COVID-19 testing for studying abroad; 5. Foreign nationals, mainland Chinese, Hong Kong or Macao residents requesting COVID-19 testing for departure; 6.    Family members of those listed above.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200526054841/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/zvqg0FiEVgQDWcL3ftogcA?typeid=158"
notes_C8: http://archive.is/kNP0H  Taiwan Centers for Disease Control  “From June 22, short-term business travelers are allowed entry and can apply for shortened home quarantine period”
notes_C1: Strict policies of Covid prevention in schools has since been relaxed, with no recent school closures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201218101936/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Category/Page/0vq8rsAob_9HCi5GQ5jH1Q
notes_H6: TAIPEI (Taiwan News) — Taiwan Health Minister and Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) head Chen Shih-chung (???) on Wednesday (Aug. 5) announced eight public settings where mask-wearing will be compulsory, in response to the country's increased coronavirus cases over the last few weeks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201012161730/https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3981125
notes_E2: The Bank of Taiwan (BOT) has made financial assistance measures available to loan clients who are experiencing payment difficulties due to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Until June 30, BOT's existing borrowers who have previously repaid principal and interest on schedule can apply for up to a six-month principal repayment extension. Borrowers must submit documents showing suffering and economic impact from COVID-19, such as proof of revenue decline, non-voluntary unemployment, or leave without pay. Borrowers must continue paying monthly interest during the extension period.  Loan Extension: Companies or individuals can apply to defer principal repayment or extend loan. Credit card payment deferral at public banks: Individuals can apply to defer card payment without penalty and interest.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200722174919/https://www.mof.gov.tw/eng/singlehtml/f48d641f159a4866b1d31c0916fbcc71?cntId=4ea6929857b04241aa6df34003fd9c25  https://web.archive.org/web/20200722174815/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/taiwan-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html
notes_E1: Starting from 21 April, companies suffering a 50% reduction in income when compared to the same period over the past two years qualify to apply for salary subsidies.   The government will subsidise 40% of wages of an employee up to a limit of NT$20,000 per month for three months.  Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20200511214349/https://thetaiwantimes.com/taiwans-unheralded-covid-19-financial-response/2587 ; https://web.archive.org/web/20200425120520/https://udn.com/news/story/120974/4508657
notes_C3: If social distancing rules are observed, large scale events are no longer subject to the advisory capacity limit of 100 persons indoor or 500 persons outdoor.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200518140732/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Bulletin/Detail/zX8MpqpJoy-T9U5XVYdrSg?typeid=9

name: Kosovo
notes_H1: It is not clear when the official website was launched, this coding is based on the assumption that it was around the declaration of public health emergency - 15 March 2020.  Main government Covid-19 related website: https://www.kosova.health/en/
notes_H3: No change found.
notes_H2: The health ministry in Kosovo has private testing clinics in the whole country, which are eligible to conduct PCR- and serological tests. Hence, the availability of testing facilities has increased substantially, allowing all citizens to be tested when required.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122110254/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-situation-in-kosovo.html
notes_C7: Kosovo is divided into 3 risk category areas. Individuals in a high risk area may not move from their area after the curfew goes in to effect.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115194251/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kosovo/coronavirus
notes_C8: Arrivals must either have a current negative test (<72 hours old). Arrivals without a negative test must go into quarantine for 7 days      https://web.archive.org/web/20201122110254/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-situation-in-kosovo.html
notes_C4: Gatherings restricted to max. 50 people     https://web.archive.org/web/20201122110254/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-situation-in-kosovo.html
notes_C1: From 18-Jan - Nusery schools and all Primary and Middle schools are now open.
notes_H6: Unable to find sources to confirm date detailed below so have coded from July 5:    The government of Kosovo made wearing mask mandatory on July 5 in order to slow the spread of COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201015100253/https://euronews.al/en/kosovo/2020/07/31/thousands-fined-in-kosovo-for-not-wearing-mandatory-face-mask    A summary from the United Nations Kosovo Team says that measures coming into force on July 13:    ' Masks are mandatory in all activities outside of the apartments and houses, for all individuals'    https://web.archive.org/web/20201015100616/https://unkt.org/2020/07/16/recap-ministry-healths-governemnt-measures-entering-force-13-july-2020/
notes_C2: "Shops, cafes, bars, restaurants and hotels are all permitted to open. However, workplaces and businesses still face a number of restrictions and may be operating with reduced opening hours and capacity.    Sports, cultural and recreational facilities throughout Kosovo are closed".     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200921224255/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kosovo/coronavirus
notes_E2: Quote: "? Lease subsidies  Further financial support is available for lessors in the  form of a lease subsidy of up to (50%) of the value of  the lease for small and medium-sized enterprises, for  April and May. Total value: €12million.  The lessee, after completing and uploading the form  through the EDI electronic system, no later than 15  May 2020, must prove that the lease contract was  concluded before 1 March 2020. They must prove  that their activity has been negatively affected by the  emergency situation.  In order to receive a subsidy of up to 50% for the  payment of rent, the lessor must have a bank account  in one of the commercial banks of Kosovo.  For this measure, the tenants who have prepaid  annual rent will not benefit, only those who have the  obligation of unpaid rent for two months from the  beginning of the pandemic."  Link: https://assets.ey.com/content/dam/ey-sites/ey-com/en_al/generic-content/pdf/ey-government-support-package-albania-and-kosovo.pdf  Property tax  Pursuant to Kosovo Law on the Tax on  Property (essentially taxing  companies/individuals based on  properties held), a decision has been  issued on the postponement of  issuance of property tax bills, including  the postponement of payment of first  installment for 2020 and  postponement of deadline for filing of  complaints on property tax bills and  certificates of assessed values.  Customs duties and VAT  All production business entities  registered in Kosovo (or their  contractors), who deal with the import  of raw materials, including wheat and  flour, for the production of bread and  bread products are exempt from  customs duties and VAT on these  supplies. The impact of these  measures on the businesses should be  considered on a case by case basis.  Business tax  The deadline for filing tax returns,  reports and payments, as well as  handling and adjudicating claims for  refunds related to the implementation  of applicable tax legislation, has been  extended from 31 March 2020 until  30 April 2020.
notes_E1: Quote: "Salary compensation  Financial support to companies in financial distress as  a result of their decline in activity due to a public  health emergency situation, as follows:  • Coverage of monthly salaries of employees in the  amount of €170 per employee, for April and May.  Total value: €41million;  In order to benefit from this measure, the following  criteria must be met:  — The employer, through the electronic EDI system,  must complete and upload the form and list  designed by TAK (Tax Authorities of Kosovo), no  later than 15 May 2020.  — The employer must prove that their activity was  negatively affected directly or indirectly by the  health emergency situation with the decisions of  the Government of Kosovo to prevent the spread  of the virus, proving financial difficulties through  the cash book, bank balance sheet and other  similar evidence.  — The employee can only benefit from this scheme  from their primary employer if they have more  than one employer, for the period to February  2020."  Link: https://assets.ey.com/content/dam/ey-sites/ey-com/en_al/generic-content/pdf/ey-government-support-package-albania-and-kosovo.pdf
notes_C3: As part of the reintroduced lockdown restrictions which began on 28th July 2020, the Kosovar government has banned: public gatherings of more than five people in squares or parks, sporting, recreational and cultural activities. Ahead of the Eid-al-Adha celebrations, public markets involving the sale of vehicles, animals, and animal slaughter outside of authorised premises are also banned.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200729120810/https://www.wmdt.com/i/the-latest-kosovo-adopts-previous-lockdown-restrictions/  https://web.archive.org/web/20200729122702/https://prishtinainsight.com/new-measures-introduced-in-effort-to-contain-covid-19/
notes_C6: There are curfews in place from 21:00-05:00.  Persons over the age of 65 are only allowed to leave the house during the hours of 06:00-10:00 and 16:00-19:00.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201107200109/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/
notes_C5: As of 29 July, Public transportation is now required to operate at half capacity to enable riders to follow social distancing guidelines while traveling. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200809121054/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Kosovo.pdf
